i# Pre-production stills, including rehearsals and preparations therefor, after Employment but before the starting date of such employment, shall not start the ^consecutive days of employment of a day performer; such performer shall be paid [.for the day or days on which he renders services in connection with pre-production uitills.
& TRAVEL TIME - RULES AND DEFINITIONS
ft A. Travel ,10 Location --No Service? Rendered on Day_Qf Departure
If a day performer is transported to location and such traveling is L commenced on any day on which he does not render services, he shall be l^ompensated at a day's pay.
B. Pay for Day of Arrival
If a day performer is transported to or from location' and he does not L’amve at the destination on the day of departure, any travel time past midnight of [Ithe day preceding the day of arrival shall not be work time or travel time for any purpose whatsoever with respect to the day of arrival, but such day performer shall ^nevertheless be entitled to not less than a foil day's pay for the day of arrival, ^hether or not he renders any services on such day.
. C. Pay foUntervening Days QfJravgl ft
If a day performer is transported to or from location and does not arrive at the destination on the day following the day of departure, he shall be 'entitled to one (1) day of pay for each intervening day of travel,
' M D- Travel irom Location
If a day performer departs from location, he shall be entitled to a foil Shy of pay for such day of departure, but if he has not otherwise rendered services Kasuch day, his travel time on such day shall not be counted as work time or B	-222 -
Schedule A
travel time for any purpose. If a day performer departs from location on a day on which he has rendered services, then, for the purpose of computing his pay for the day of departure, his travel time, if any, past midnight of such day shall not be work time or travel time for any purpose unless he arrives at the destination and renders services on the day next following the day of departure; but if, in such , event, he does arrive at the destination and renders services on the day next following the day of departure, his travel time past midnight of the day of . departure shall be included in his travel time for the purpose of computing his pay for the day of departure; it being understood that for the purpose of computing his pay for the day of departure as aforesaid, such performer shall in no event be entitled to more than one (1) day of pay on account of all such travel time,
E. Travel Provisions When Recalled for Retakes. Added Scenes, etc.
Any day performer living within the City of Los Angeles or its environs, who is outside such area when he is recalled by the Producer for any of, the purposes specified in Section 28 hereof (including performers who are entitled to the provisions of the following paragraph), shall be provided with transportation or reimbursed for the cost of transportation only, from the place where he is when recalled to the place designated by the Producer, by the particular mode of transportation specified by the Producer, regardless of any other mode of transportation the performer may actually use. Return	$
transportation shall be furnished or the performer shall be reimbursed for such return transportation, as above set forth, only if the performer shall so return within one (1) week from the date of dismissal by Producer.	J
Any day performer living within the City of Los Angeles or its < environs, who is at a place beyond a radius of one hundred fifty (150) miles from 5 the intersection of Beverly Boulevard and La Cienega, Los Angeles, California, j when he is recalled by Producer for any of the aforesaid reasons, shall be placed J on salary as of the day he is directed to and does report to the place designated by| Producer, and shall remain on salary each day until dismissed, except for the	|
provisions relating to seventh days in the workweek and holidays. If, after	$
dismissal, the performer remains in this locality or delays his return, unless by the| Producer's request, and is again recalled by the Producer, he shall not be entitled to any payment for the time intervening between his dismissal and his recall. The performer shall be entitled to travel time compensation based on the same rate paid
-223 -
Schedule A
for his principal engagement for the period of time, and only for the period of time, that is required in traveling to and from the said place designated by the Producer by the particular mode of transportation specified by the Producer, regardless of any other mode of transportation the performer may actually use. Such travel time compensation shall be computed in accordance with the travel time allowance provisions for day performers as provided in this subsection E. The said travel time allowance for the day performer’s return to the place of original departure shall be paid only if the performer shall so return within one (1) week from the date of dismissal by Producer.
If the Producer designates the mode of transportation and the day of departure and the performer follows such directions, there shall be no lapse in payment for days intervening between end of travel and commencement of work.
In the event the Producer does not specify the mode of transportation, then the travel time allowance shall be based upon the most expeditious mode of transportation possible, including travel by commercial airlines. The performer need not fly, but if he elects not to fly when requested to do so, it shall not increase the travel time allowance as specified above.
There shall be no duty on the Producer to procure return transportation for the performer so long as Producer pays for the same.
To illustrate the foregoing, a performer, a resident of Los Angeles, is temporarily in San Francisco. Within three (3) months from the close of his principal engagement, he is recalled by the Producer as follows: On a Monday, the Producer directs the performer to report at the Los Angeles studio of Producer at 11.00 a.m. on the following Thursday for retakes. The performer elects to travel x by train. He departs from San Francisco on Wednesday night, arriving at Los Angeles Thursday morning and reports at 11:00 a.m. The Producer dismisses the ' performer at 2:00 p.m. on the same day. The performer elects to return to San Francisco by train. The performer shall be entitled to one (1) day of pay at the ' same rate as was paid for his original engagement, plus the cost of transportation 1 by commercial airline.
In the foregoing example, if the performer had been dismissed at 6:00 p.m. with an hour off for lunch (six (6) hours work, four (4) hours travel), the
- 224 -
Schedule A

performer would have been entitled to pay for one (1) day plus two (2) hours time and one-half. The performer shall not be entitled to a travel allowance ofAl more than eight (8) hours in any period of twenty-four (24) hours; and the performer shall not be entitled to any travel time allowance for a period of travel jr for which he is otherwise paid.
When principal photography takes place in New York, the provisions of this subsection E. of Schedule A shall apply to performers living in New York ? and absent therefrom, and shall be applied to other cities in the same manner by^-analogy.	&
An out-of-state performer who is recalled for any of the purposes specified in subsection E. of this Schedule A shall not be required to remain in tins) locality after dismissal unless he is carried on salary during the period he is so ' |-required to wait.
Transportation shall mean first-class transportation.
F. Studio Zone
(1) With respect to studios situated in Los Angeles, California, its environs, the "studio zone" shall include all territory within the radius of thirty* (30) miles from the intersection of Beverly Boulevard and La Cienega Boulevard, ; Los Angeles, California, and such other territory (such as the present Columbia & Ranch and Disney Studio) as is generally recognized as being within the studio zone. With respect to studios not situated in Los Angeles or its environs, a similar territory as the studio zone and similar rules in relation thereto shall be agreed upon between the Union and the Producers, and in default of such agreement, such) territory and such rules (which shall conform as nearly as possible to the rules ’< herein set forth) shall be determined by arbitration under Section 9 of the General / Provisions whenever the situation arises.
(2) With respect to studios situated in New York, New York, thej "studio zone" shall include all territory within the radius of eight (8) miles from Col umbus Circle.	>

(3) The Los Angeles Thirty Mile Studio Zone
Performers may be required to report anywhere within such o zone provided that, when the place of reporting is elsewhere than the producer's studio, the following shall apply:
(a) Performers shall be paid $.30 per mile mileage allowance 'figiired from the studio to the place of reporting and back, except that no mileage •allowance is required:

With respect to any television series, such “point may be changed by Producer at the beginning of each season. G.	Location and Overnight Location	|
Location shall mean any place of work not at the Producer's studio J which is outside the studio zone. Overnight location shall be any location where^ the performer is lodged or offered lodging by the Producer at or near the location^ for one (I) or more nights, or any location which takes overnight to reach by ordinary means of transportation.	d
H.	Near Lotion
A near location shall be any place which can be reached from the Jr Producer's studio within twenty-four (24) hours of travel by ordinary means of J transportation. If the Producer instructs the performer to fly to a location and the£ trip takes less than twenty-four (24) hours by air, the same shall be deemed to be a, near location.
I.	Distant Location
■$>
A distant location shall be any place which cannot be reached from f the Producer's studio within twenty-four (24) hours of travel by ordinary means of I transportation.
-22’-	|
Schedule A	4
| J. Place of Reporting and Dismissal
|	Except when already at an overnight location, performers shall be
|required to report only at the Producer's studio or within the studio zone, and shall ibe dismissed only at the place of reporting within the studio zone or the Producer's istudio. When the performerJs returning from such overnight location, he shall be ^dismissed only at the Producer's studio or the place of reporting within the studio |zone, and not at the overnight location.
K. Travel Time is Work Time
S	Except as otherwise provided in this Agreement, all time spent by any
^performer in traveling at the request of the Producer between any place at which Rhe is required to and does report and any location, both to and from, shall be travel Rhine and, as such, shall be work time, subject to all deductions, limitations and ^exceptions for which provision is made in this Agreement.
8 L. Maximum Travel Time
L rgi'
&..	Time spent in traveling shall not be included as travel time or work |!time to the extent of more than eight (8) hours in any twenty-four (24) hours.
S M. Intervening Time between Dismissal and Travel
(I)	Time intervening between the completion of a performer's hwork on any day and the commencement of travel on the same day shall be travel l time except as otherwise provided in this Agreement.
(2)	Travel to Overnight Location: Except as otherwise provided in kthis Agreement, the period of time intervening between the performer's dismissal Hfbr the day and the commencement of travel to an overnight location on the same Pqay shall be travel time. This provision shall not affect the day performer's right to ^minimum of one (1) day of pay for such day.
I
L	(3) Travel from Overnight Location: The period intervening
Lbetween the performer's dismissal for the day and the commencement of travel on
- 228 -
Schedule A
the same day from an overnight location shall, as to day performers, be travel time except as in this Agreement otherwise provided.
N.	Trarjsportau.Qn an^Lodging Furnished
The Producer shall furnish reasonable transportation to and from location and shall furnish reasonable meals and, (when the Producer requires a performer to stay overnight), lodging to the performer on location. Separate rooms shall be provided to performers transported to overnight locations unless such rooms are not available.
In the event Producer believes that separate rooms will not be available at a particular location, Producer will notify the Union and the performer prior to departure, with reasonable time for each to investigate to determine f whether the foregoing requirement can be complied with by Producer.
T
O.	Deduction q£ Allowable Meal Periods
Reasonable meal periods shall be given during traveling, and allowable meal periods of not less than one-half (16) hour nor more than one (1) ! hour each shall be deducted from travel time, provided a reasonable meal is made,^ available.
P.	Deduction of Travel Time Otherwise Compensated For
Any travel time for which the performer is compensated as work time shall not be paid for as travel time.
Q.	Computation Qf Overtime .Caused by Travel Time
On a day on which a performer travels only, the performer shall be ; compensated at a day of pay. On a day on which the performer travels and woi overtime caused by such will be compensated at time and one-half and not at double time.

-229-
R.	Transportation and Travel Time on Overnight Locations to and from Hotel pr Qamp
On overnight locations, the Producer shall provide transportation to and from the hotel or camp and, except as in this Agreement otherwise provided, the time to and from the hotel or camp shall be travel time. The rest period may be t reduced to ten (10) hours (under Section 1O.D.(2)).
S.	TravebQ.pi from Overnight Locations op BoalOlJjain Where Sleeping Accommodations are Provided
When more than one (1) night of travel, by ordinary means of transportation, is required to reach a location and the performer is given a berth on a boat or train, the time spent in traveling to or from such location shall not be work time or travel time for the purpose of computing the twelve (12) hour rest period or for the purpose of computing the eight (8) hour day; it being agreed, however, that time spent in traveling on the day of arrival at such location, after 9:00 a.m. of such day, shall be counted for the purpose of computing the eight (8) hour day if the performer works on such day and, provided further, that the C interval between the completion of travel on such day and the commencement of L work shall not be considered travel time or work time for any purpose. Nothing ; herein contained shall be construed to interrupt the performer's right to remain on £ salary if the performer is otherwise entitled thereto.
T.	Overnight Trip to or from Location
When an overnight trip to or from location is required, and the same takes at least seven (7) hours to reach and the performer is given a berth on a boat or train, the time spent in such traveling to or from such location, whether at the
^beginning, during or at the end of the engagement, shall not be work time or travel I time for the purpose of computing overtime and the rest period.
| U. Traveling on the Seventh Day in die Workweek and Certain Holidays i	The holidays herein referred to are New Year's Day, Presidents' Day,
|Good Friday, Memorial Day, July Fourth, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, the ^Friday after Thanksgiving and Christmas Day. When a day performer travels on
- 230 -
I'	Schedule A
any seventh day in the workweek, or if a day performer travels on any of said holidays, he shall receive time and one-half for such travel time.
Engagement of Performers - Other Areas
(1)	If a performer, residing or working in any area in which SAG maintains a branch, is brought to Producer's base or distant location in a different area of the United States for any purpose, the performer shall receive transportation and a $75 per day allowance from the time he commences travel at Producer's request until the time his salary commences.
x
F.
(2)	If Producer is photographing on a location in the United States X and brings a performer to such location from anywhere in the United States, such ’ performer shall be provided transportation to and from such location.
(3)	Except as otherwise provided in (1) and (2) above, nothing X herein contained shall prevent a Producer from engaging a performer outside of California (if such performer has not gone out of California for the purpose of evading this rule) to report in California or to report at any location and, in any such case, the Producer shall not be required to pay for or provide transportation of such performer to the place of reporting, or to pay such performer for any time spent in traveling thereto; nor shall the Producer be required to pay for or provide transportation of such performer, at the end of the engagement back to the place where such performer was engaged, or to pay such performer for any time spent in& traveling back to the place where such performer was engaged; such performer 1 < may be dismissed on location. This does not limit the second sentence of subsection F. hereof.	-h
days.
(4)	Performers shall not be held on a per diem longer than three (3)^
W.
(1) Nothing in this Section 32 shall be deemed to break the continuous employment of a day performer.
-231 -
Schedule A
'j&	(2) This Agreement uses the expressions "reasonable
transportation" and "first-class transportation." The terms are intended to be
rf synonymous. The type of transportation required can best be illustrated by
'^ examples: Bus transportation for a relatively short distance (Hollywood to Lake "a Arrowhead) meets these requirements; bus transportation for a long distance $ (Hollywood to San Francisco) does not. Pullman accommodations to
San Francisco, or any other long distance, meet these requirements; deluxe rtf transportation (e.g., Super Chief) is not required; Transportation on a commercial
airline without sleeper accommodations is first-class transportation. First-class J transportation shall be provided on commercial airlines when the performer is .^required to fiy at the request of the Producer. The foregoing shall apply to jet
flights as well as to prop-driven aircraft. The foregoing shall not apply when first-class transportation is not available or six (6) or more of the company are being transported. Charter flights may be used which provide substantially equivalent ^accommodations. Notwithstanding the foregoing, first-class air transportation 5-need not be provided with respect to auditions and interviews.
X
p3. RIGHT TO NAME OR CHARACTER
No Producer shall, after the termination of the performer's employment, ^prevent such performer from continuing the use of any stage or screen name used vby such performer. The name of a role owned or created by the Producer, such as
' Jar/an or Charlie Chan, belongs to the Producer and not to the performer. ■
5S4. RATE NOT SPECIFIED
Whenever this Schedule states that a performer shall receive compensation fjor work done before he is employed, if he is not employed, and no rate is
'specified in this Schedule, such compensation shall be computed upon the agreed rate of compensation, if there was such an agreed rate of compensation and, if not,
..upon the performer's established compensation. Disputes between the performer •/and the Producer under this provision are subject to conciliation and arbitration.
Schedule A
-232-
35.
EOF PAYMENT

Paychecks shall be mailed or delivered to the performer within five (5) working days after completion of his day's work, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays excepted.
36.	USE OF "DOUBLE”
The provisions of Section 36 of Schedule B shall apply to day performers employed at or above a salary of $1,300.00 per day.
37.	DIALOGUE REPLACEMENT WORK
A.	Except as provided in subsection E. below:	&
(1)	a performer who is engaged to perform dialogue replacement J work shall be paid one day of pay at the applicable day performer minimum rate | for the following work:	$
(a)	unlimited non-synchronized lines; and
(b)	a maximum of five (5) synchronized lines for each of up
to three (3) characters.
(2)	Such performer shall be paid an additional day’s pay for any part consisting of more than five (5) synchronized lines and for each set of up to three (3) additional characters with up to five (5) synchronized lines per character,
B.	For purposes of this provision, a "synchronized line" means an
identifiable word or words "covering" the mouth movements of a specific on-camera performer. A line shall consist of not more than ten (10) words. Part of a' '^ line shall be considered a line. Moans, groans, screams, exclamatory sounds (e.g^ "ooh," "aah," etc.) and the like shall not be considered words except when scripted^
and synchronized with an on-camera performer.

-233 -
Schedule A
C,	Prior to any session at which such work is performed, Producer shall advise the performer whether any vocally stressful work (e.g., screamed lines) is contemplated. If the performer is not informed of vocally stressful work prior to the session, the performer may refuse to do such work.
D.	The foregoing shall not apply to lines spoken for a scripted or storyboarded off-camera character (e.g., a narrator, Hal the Computer ("2001: A Space Odyssey"), KITT the car ("Knight Rider"), Carlton the doorman ("Rhoda"), football game announcer ("The Longest Yard") or Charlie ("Charlie’s Angels")).
E.	Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary:
(1)	Producer may employ a performer to speak an unlimited
E number of synchronized lines for a single character, for which Producer shall pay | performer the applicable minimum compensation.
(2)	Producer shall not be obligated to engage performers employed
under this Agreement to speak improvised lines in the nature of "omnies," as that term is commonly understood in the motion picture industry, except that a ^performer who is directed to speak lines "covering” one (1), two (2) or three (3) ^specific on-camera performers shall be employed under this Agreement.
& F. A member report shall be completed by performers doing dialogue •|replacement work and shall be signed by a Producer representative. A copy will f^be sent to SAG. The report shall contain the information set forth in Exhibit I ^hereto.
Schedule A

SCHEDULE B
TELEVISION FREELANCE PERFORMERS WHOSE WEEKLY GUARANTEED SALARY IS $4,400 OR LESS PER WEEK AND WHO ARE GUARANTEED LESS THAN $32,000 PER TELEVISION PICTURE AND THEATRICAL FREELANCE PERFORMERS WHOSE WEEKLY GUARANTEED SALARY IS $5,500 OR LESS PER WEEK AND WHO ARE GUARANTEED LESS THAN $60,000 PER THEATRICAL PICTURE (LESS THAN $65,000 PER THEATRICAL PICTURE WITH RESPECT TO CONTRACTS ENTERED INTO ON OR AFTER JANUARY 1,2002)
U. DEFINITION
A television freelance performer is a performer employed for a specific ^.television motion picture in a designated role on a weekly basis at a salary of |$4,400 or less per week but no less than $2,206 per week ($2,272 per week for the |period July 1, 2002 through June 30, 2003 and $2,352 per week for the period July 1,2003 through June 30, 2004) and who is guaranteed less than $32,000 per P; television picture. A theatrical freelance performer is a performer employed for a ^specific theatrical motion picture in a designated role on a weekly basis at a salary Jof $5,500 or less per week but no less than $2,206 per week ($2,272 per week for tjthc period July 1, 2002 through June 30, 2003 and $2,352 per week for the period ^ July 1, 2003 through June 30,2004) and who is guaranteed less than $60,000 per ^theatrical picture (less than $65,000 per theatrical picture with respect to contracts ^entered into on or after January 1, 2002).

SCHEDULE B INCLUDED IN INDIVIDUAL CONTRACTS

It is agreed that the conditions of this Schedule shall govern the ^employment of freelance performers and shall become a part of the contract with \tiie freelance performer.
it

BY
4. STARTING PATE	|
A.	The phrase "on or about," as used in a freelance performer's contract, shall allow a latitude of twenty-four (24) hours, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays	|
and holidays, either prior to or after the date specified in the contract, as the | commencement of the term thereof.	*
B.	If a freelance contract is delivered to the performer at least seven (7) days before the starting date, the "on or about" clause may be used. If a contract is delivered to a performer less than seven (7) days before the specified starting date, a definite starting date must be specified and the "on or about" clause shall not be used: Toillustrate: If the starting date of a performer is on the eighth day of the month, and the contract is delivered to the performer on the first day of the month, the "on or about" clause may be used, but if the contract is delivered to the

I
| performer on the second day of the month, the "on or about" clause may not be |iised.
| C. In any case when it is impracticable or impossible to fix any definite I starting date of any performer to be employed under a freelance contract because gof such performer’s activities on the stage or in radio or otherwise in the | amusement business (except motion pictures), the Union agrees to waive the ^requirement of a definite starting date in such freelance contract, provided that S'such freelance contract contains a reasonable provision for the fixing of the & starting date thereof and notice thereof. Any dispute between the Union and any i Producer with respect to the issuance of any such waiver shall be determined by | arbitration under Section 9 of the General Provisions hereof.
f D. In the event a performer is engaged in accordance with Section 6.B.
| hereof, but a start date has not yet been provided to the performer by the Producer, | performer may terminate such engagement in order to accept conflicting bona fide |. employment by a third party; subject, however, to the performer first giving | Producer the following minimum period during which Producer may specify a 1: start date which then becomes binding, which conflicts with the proffered third
£ party employment:
I	(1)	If performer informs Producer before noon of a business day,
g by the end of the same day; or
»	(2) If performer informs Producer at any other time, by noon of the
f next business day.
I 5.	MINIMGMAALARY.- GUARANTEE
*• if
<:	The minimum salary for a freelance performer shall be $2,206 per week for
the period July 1, 2001 through June 30,2002; $2,272 per week for the period
F July 1,2002 through June 30,2003; and $2,352 per week for the period July 1,.
j* 2003 through June 30, 2004. £
One (1) picture employment for a freelance performer shall guarantee at
I’ least one (1) week of employment. The guarantee provided in this paragraph shall

Schedule B
Schedule B
be subjecrto the rights of suspension and termination granted to the Producer by I the provisions of Sections 40,41 and 42 of this Schedule B.	f
6.	EXECUTION OF AGREEMENT - ENGAGEMENT - DELIVERY OF |
contract_____________________________<
A.	If said freelance contract is delivered by the Producer to the performer^ and if said freelance contract is executed without alteration by the performer and isT so returned to the Producer by noon of the next succeeding business day after its & delivery to the performer, it shall thereupon constitute a contract binding on both parties even though not executed by the Producer, but the Producer, on demand, > shall deliver a signed copy to the performer.	>
B.	Freelance performers under this Schedule B shall be considered W definitely engaged in any of the following events:
(1)	When the performer is given written notice of acceptance;
(2)	When a form contract signed by Producer is delivered to | performer or when an unsigned contract is delivered by Producer to performer and & is executed by performer as so delivered and returned to Producer;
(3)	When a script is delivered to the performer by Producer; & however, this does not include the delivery of a script for a test, audition or interview nor the submission of a script for the purpose of permitting the	;
performer to determine if he desires the engagement;	|
(4)	When a performer is fitted for work; this shall not apply to	I
wardrobe tests; or	1
(5)	When the performer is given a verbal call by Producer or an |: authorized company representative, which is accepted.

SC.	Delivery of Contracts
(J) To the extent that the agreement reached between the Producer |and the performer can be reflected on the form required by the collective ^bargaining agreement plus Producer's standard riders to be filed with the Union, |Producer shall deliver a copy of such contract to the performer not later than the ^first day of performer’s employment. When the agreement cannot be so reflected, ^Producer shall deliver a copy of such contract to the performer not later than the gfirst day of performer's employment or four (4) business days after such agreement Bhas been reached, whichever is later.
B	The present rule that a performer may not be required to sign
fl contracts on the set shall continue. Delivery to a performer's agent constitutes || delivery to the performer.
(2) When Producer chooses to deliver a copy of a contract to the performer on the set, an extra copy for retention by the performer shall be ^provided.
ijtr,
o	(3) Liquidated damages in the amounts provided in Section 31 .B.
ra of the General Provisions hereof for late payment shall be payable until a written contract is delivered to the performer.
h	(4) W-4 forms shall be presented to performer no later than the
K first day of employment. A W-4 form may be given to performer on the set on the Ff • first day of employment. W-4 forms shall be available on every set. It shall be the f# performer's responsibility to return a completed W-4 form to Producer in a timely K: manner. It is understood that when a performer fails to do so, there shall be no H retroactive adjustments to the withholding required by law. W-4 forms shall be H attached to three (3) day performer contracts.

Schedule B	Schedule B
'	(a)	Definition of Booking Slip. A booking slip is a
document containing a designation of the role, salary and number of days of guaranteed employment.
(b)	If performer is engaged after 6:00 p.m. on the day prior ' to the first day of performer's employment, the booking slip will be included with the script provided to performer. However, if the script was provided to performer prior to such date and hour, Producer need not provide such booking slip. J'
(c)	The foregoing requirements for delivery of a booking
slip shall not apply if performer’s contract has previously been delivered to performer or performer's agent.
7.	RATENQT5PECIFIED
Whenever this Schedule states that a performer shall receive compensation for work done before he is employed, if he is not employed, and no rate is specified in this Schedule, such compensation shall be computed upon the agreed rate of compensation, if there was such an agreed rate of compensation and, if not, upon the performer's established compensation. Disputes between the performer and the Producer under this provision are subject to conciliation and arbitration.
8.	STUDIO PAYROLL WEEK - TIME OF PAYMENT
A.	The studio payroll week shall be deemed to start at 12:01 a.m. on Sunday and end at 12:00 midnight of the succeeding Saturday.
B.	Compensation, including daily overtime, if any, earned by the performer under a freelance contract shall be payable on the regular studio pay day for services rendered up to and including the preceding Saturday.
-250-
Schedule B
j 9. THE PERFORMER’S WORKWEEK: STUDIO FIVE (5) DAY WEEK: OVERNIGHT LOCATION WEEK______________________________________
A.	Definitions - General
(1)	An "overnight location workweek," as used herein, shall be deemed to be a workweek consisting of six (6) overnight location days or six (6) days of any combination of studio and overnight location days, which combination includes a sixth day overnight location day.
Any workweek, other than such an overnight location workweek, for the purposes of this Section, shall be deemed to be a "studio workweek," The studio workweek shall consist of any five (5) days out of seven (7) consecutive days as designated by the Producer on each production unit. The sixth and seventh days in the designated workweek shall be the regular days off.
(2)	An "overnight location day," as used herein, shall be deemed to mean any of the following days, if the performer is on salary that day, as provided in the Basic Agreement:
(a)	Any day spent or worked by the performer on an overnight location or on an exploitation tour;
(b)	The day of departure for such location (provided the performer does not actually work in the studio on such day);
(c)	The day of return from such location (provided the performer does not actually work in the studio on such day);
(3)	For all purposes, the performer's weekly base rate shall be his weekly rate of salary as specified in his contract; the performer’s straight time hourly rate shall be one-forty-fourth (1/44) of his weekly base rate.
-251 -
Schedule B
B.	Studio Five (5) Day Workweek
(1)	The performer's studio workweek shall be a five (5) day
workweek.
(2)	The regular studio workweek shall be forty-four (44) cumulative hours commencing with the first day of the performer's workweek; weekly overtime shall be at one and one-half (IVi) times the straight time hourly rate for hours worked in excess of forty-four (44) hours in such workweek, as provided in Section 13 entitled '’Overtime."
(3)	Work on Six (6) or Seven (7) Days in a Workweek
If the performer works on six (6) or seven (7) days in the I workweek and performer is on a studio workweek, he shall in each case be entitled ] to premium pay in accordance with the following rules:
(i)	The performer shall receive a premium of an additional J one-half (14) day of pay for the sixth day worked, if the performer works six (6) { days within a studio workweek. The performer shall receive a premium of an	|
additional day of pay for the seventh day worked if the performer works seven (7) | days within a studio workweek (in addition to the one-half day of premium pay for 1 the sixth day worked in the workweek).	1
The following are examples of the foregoing:	§
(1)	If the performer works seven (7) days in his | workweek, he shall be entitled to an additional two (2) days of pay for work	j
beyond five (5) days plus one and one-half (1 l/a) days of premium pay or a total of | eight and one-half (8!4) days of pay. Hours worked on such sixth and seventh	1
days shall not be included in calculating performer's forty-four (44) hour week.	j
The other five (5) days in the week will constitute the workweek for such purpose, j
(2)	If the performer works six (6) days in his workweek, he shall be entitled to an additional day of pay for work beyond five (5) days plus one-half (14) day of premium pay, or a total of six and one-half (614)
-252-
Schedule B
I ft	<
£	1
(	I
£ days of pay. Hours worked on such sixth day, to and including ten (10) hours,	.!
I' shall not be included in calculating performer’s forty-four (44) hour week.	,
I	(ii) Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of
subparagraphs (i) and (ii) above, a sixth day worked on an overnight location shall	•
« not be a premium day.	I
i	;
J:	(iii) For work time in excess often (10) hours on any sixth or
1	seventh day in a workweek for which the performer receives a premium of one-f- half (x/i) day of pay or one (1) day of pay as above provided, the performer shall t, receive double the weekly straight time hourly rate, including overtime caused by make-up, hairdress, wardrobe or fittings.
r . C. Overnight Location Six (6) Day Workweek
(1)	The overnight location six (6) day workweek shall be forty-. eight (48) cumulative hours, commencing with the first day of the performer’s workweek, which forty-eight (48) hours include an additional four (4) hours overtime at the straight time hourly rate (whether worked or not).
(2)	If the time included in calculating the performer's forty-eight	i
(48) hour week, as above provided, exceeds forty-eight (48) hours, such excess time shall be paid for at the rate of one and one-half (114) times the weekly straight time hourly rate, except as otherwise provided in Section 13 entitled "Overtime."	I
(3)	Work on Seven (7) Days in a Workweek
(a) If a performer works seven (7) days in an overnight	I
location workweek, he shall be entitled to a premium of an extra day of pay for the seventh day of work within his workweek. For example, if the performer works	i
seven (7) days in his workweek, including a seventh day, he shall receive an	\
additional day of pay for work beyond six (6) days plus a premium of one (1) day of pay, for a total of eight (8) days of pay. Hours worked on such seventh day shall not be included in calculating the performer's forty-eight (48) hour week.
The other six (6) days in the week will constitute the workweek for such purpose.
-253 -
Schedule B
4?
,	(b) For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any seventh-
day, for which the performer receives a premium of one (1) day of pay as above^ provided, the performer shall receive double the weekly straight time hourly rate,;?} including overtime caused by make-up, hairdress, wardrobe or fittings. f

D. Premium Days - Holiday Weeks - “Hold” Days
A Schedule B performer shall be treated as having worked six (6) days in a studio workweek (seven (7) days in an overnight location workweek),f and shall be entitled to payment for the sixth day worked in a studio workweekjL (the seventh day worked in an overnight location workweek), whenever a holiday falls on a regularly-scheduled work day and the performer is required to work fiyc (5) days in the holiday week in a studio workweek (six (6) days in the holiday Ap week in an overnight location workweek).	:
4$
Whenever a performer is paid for a day or days not worked by reason of consecutive employment rules (a "hold day") in a week during which the performer also works, the performer shall be considered to have worked on the£ "hold day(s)" for purposes of determining whether the performer is entitled to^1-premium pay for a sixth or seventh day worked. As an example, if the sum of the number of hold days and the number of days worked by the performer in a studio workweek equals six (6), then the sixth day (whether worked or a hold day) shri| be paid as a sixth day worked. Similarly, if the sum of the number of hold days! and the number of days worked by the performer in the workweek equals seven?; (7), then the seventh day (whether worked or a hold day) shall be paid as a seven day worked.	1
E. Shift in Workweek
Once during the production of a motion picture, or in the case of J*' episodic television, once between hiatus periods (i.e., between the commenceme or resumption of production and a cessation of principal photography for the ser for at least one week), the Producer may shift the workweek for performers without incurring extra costs, by adding one (1) or two (2) days off consecutive: with the sixth and/or seventh days off in the prior workweek and/or by shifting a workweek commencing on a Tuesday to a workweek commencing on a Monday provided that the intervening Sunday is a day off.	f.
-254-
Schedule B
. If the Producer otherwise shifts the workweek such that the new workweek invades the preceding workweek, the Producer shall pay the premium the sixth and/or seventh day worked of the preceding workweek.
The performer shall be advised of any shift in the workweek prior to commencement of that workweek.
*1
4 F. Recall on the Sixth or Seventh Day in the Workweek
If a performer is recalled to work on a day or days that would Constitute the sixth and/or seventh day worked in a workweek by such performer that Producer (for which the performer received a premium of one-half (%) day Ct one (1) day of pay, as above provided) for any purpose mentioned in Section 30 Efdfihis Schedule B and, therefore, receives day performer conditions, the premium |for the sixth or seventh day so worked shall not exceed $950 for the first eight (8) [hours worked. Overtime in such case shall be paid at the same rate as for the first [tight (8) hours.
G. No Compounding
There shall be no compounding of the foregoing premiums and the tenalty or premium prescribed by Section 15 insofar as the same relates to the lijrty-six (36) or fifty-six (56) (or fifty-four (54)) hour rest period, or Section 27, it jeing understood that, if, for example, a performer works seven (7) days in a
Etudio workweek, he shall be entitled to only eight and one-half (8 !4) days of pay, mlns overtime, if any.

10, PERFORMER'S WEEK
The performer’s week in each instance shall commence on the day of the , week on which such performer is first placed on salary. In case of any suspensioi or interruption of such performer's employment at any time for seven (7) consecutive days or more, for any reason whatsoever, such performer’s week thereafter commence on the day of the week when he is again placed on salary^,
1L HQ URS PER DAY: WORK PAST MIDNIGHT
If the performer is working at midnight of any day, then his hours of wo^ for such day shall be computed until the performer has been dismissed subsequa to midnight, subject to all exceptions and deductions provided for in this Sc Hours of work for the following day shall, except as otherwise provided in this.. Schedule, be computed from the time that the performer, after having been dismissed subsequent to midnight, is next required to and does report. Nothing < herein shall derogate from the rule that when a freelance performer works after,/ 12:01 a.m. of any day, he has worked on that day for the purpose of the studio' (5) day week or overnight location six (6) day week, whichever is applicable;^ however, no premium shall be payable by reason of working past midnight into ) premium day (i.e., working past midnight into the sixth or seventh day workc^..^ the performer's workweek or a holiday). Daily overtime shall only commence^ accrue after ten (10) hours of work time, as more particularly provided in Sectioi 13 hereof.

'4?'
12. DAILY RATE OF COMPENSATION; PRORATING
Whenever it is necessary to prorate the workweek in order to determine , additional day of pay, such prorating shall be on the basis of one-fifth (1/5) of th performer's weekly base rate, for either the studio or overnight location workwe however, such proration shall not in any manner change the performer's weekly, base rate for either the studio or the overnight location workweek.
For the purpose of paying the performer at the end of a payroll week, tliaE portion of performer's studio workweek which is part of such payroll week shall - 256 -	।
tpaid on the basis of one-fifth (1/5) of the weekly base rate for each such day Eluding the sixth and seventh days) in that payroll week. This is exclusive of Overtime or premium pay, if any, due in such performer's workweek.
Weekly overtime shall not be prorated except on a fractional week at the nd'bf the performer's engagement; weekly overtime shall only be computed on basis of performer’s week, as fully set forth in Section 13, ''Overtime."

C.	Fifty-Six (561 Hour Rest Period
When the performer is given two (2) consecutive days off dura studio workweek, the thirty-six (36) consecutive hour rest period shall be^: increased to fifty-six (56) consecutive hours. However, when there is night shooting consisting primarily of exterior photography and the performer's ^ not earlier than 3:00 p.m, and he is dismissed in the studio at or before tnfchj on the fifth day of the workweek, such fifty-six (56) hour rest period, if dthr applicable, may be reduced to fifty-four (54) hours.
In lieu of the fifty-six (56) hour rest period, the performer may given a fifty-four (54) hour rest period when the call time for the first day a new workweek following the rest period is not earlier than 6:00 a.m. .I
D.	The above provisions regarding the rest period shall be subject following exceptions:
(I)	When the Producer is photographing on a location other,’ an overnight location, the eleven (11) or twelve (12) hour rest period may Ke; reduced to ten (10) hours if exterior photography is required on such location'., the day before and the day after such reduced rest period. When such reducts allowed on any day by reason of exterior photography on a nearby location,it: not be again allowed until after three (3) consecutive days have intervened. |

STUDY OF LINES OR SCRIPT
Study of lines or script, except during the period between reporting and’^ dismissal, shall not be counted as work time for any purpose.
23. PUBLICITY INTERVIEWS
■ ■
Publicity interviews held at a time mutually satisfactory to the performer^ and the Producer shall not be work time for any purpose unless held on a day pn ■ which the performer is otherwise working for the Producer. Such interviews^ publicity purposes held on any day on which the performer is otherwise working for the Producer shall not be counted as work time if held after the performer's', dismissal for the day, if such interview is held at a time mutually satisfactory performer and the Producer. If the interview is held during a meal period, itj not be deemed to constitute a violation thereof.
24. PUBLICITY gTILLg

A.	If the Producer should desire the services of a freelance peribn
making publicity stills either before the commencement of his term of employ or after the expiration thereof, the performer shaft render such services without compensation for one (1) day, as and when requested by the Producer, unless, performer is otherwise employed, but if otherwise employed, the performer, cooperate to the fullest extent in the making of such publicity stills. J
B. Publicity stills, after employment but before the starting date of su employment, shall not start the consecutive days of employment of a freelance’ performer.

representative of Producer, constitute a rehearsal. Rehearsals shall be counted as $ork time.
B.	Auditions, tests, interviews, make-up and wardrobe tests do not constitute rehearsals.

D.	Neither tests, auditions, fittings, publicity stills, pre-production stills, ^recordings nor training under subsection C. above, after employment but foie the starting date of such employment, shall start the employment period of ihperformer. Compensation, if any, for any of such services shall be as erwise provided in this Schedule.
Rehearsal shall not start the consecutive days of employment for a ormer employed under this Schedule who is engaged for a long-form vision motion picture or a theatrical motion picture, subject to the following: I-
(1)	The performer must be paid for rehearsal at the same rate as tography (pro rata of the weekly salary, but not less than day performer
when rehearsing for less than a week);
|p (2) The performer must be generally available for rehearsal, as iguished from professionally available;

(3)	The performer must be given an "on or about" start date; and
(4)	Consecutive employment applies during the rehearsal period.
NIGHT WORK
^ight work is defined as work between 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., except that &all for the day at 5:00 a.m. or thereafter shall not constitute night work.
1-
® ■
-273 -
Schedule B
These shall be no premium payable for night work, except that a performed (including a singer) who is called solely for the purpose of looping, singing or.^ automatic dialogue replacement (ADR) work during post-production shall receive premium pay for each straight time hour of night work equal to ten percent (10?^, of his hourly rate for such hours. However, such premium shall not be payable.^ a performer (or singer) if the looping, singing or ADR work is scheduled at nigfeC to accommodate the schedule of that performer (or singer).	. ,f 1
Such night premium pay shall not be paid on any overtime hours.
$
To the extent known, Producer shall provide advance notice, i.e., on the;dai prior, that night work will be required and whether such night work will involve 3 interiors or exteriors.	/
Dismissal - New York City. Any performer required to work at night and^ not dismissed by 9:30 p.m. will be provided transportation by Producer to Grandy Central Station, Penn Station or the Port Authority, unless such place of dismissal] is within a zone bordered by 34th Street on the south, 59th Street on the north,.and
Third and Eighth Avenues on the east and west, respectively.

-MJ?
A. Holidays
The nine (9) holidays hereinafter referred to are the following: ffejM Year's Day, Presidents' Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, July Fourth, Labor Daj Thanksgiving Day, the Friday after Thanksgiving and Christmas Day. Whenever any of said holidays falls on a Sunday, such holiday for all purposes of this Schedule B shall be deemed to fall on the Monday next succeeding.
B.	Studio Five (5) Day Workweek: Work on Holidays, or Holidays ani
Six (6) or Seven (7) DaySJO Workweek	fe;
(1)	If a performer works on any of the nine (9) holidays, or a |
holiday and six (6) or seven (7) days in a workweek, he shall, in each case (tlwtii

Schedule B
paratcly for the holiday and for the sixth or the seventh day, if he works on each sh respective day), be entitled to premium pay, in accordance with the following les:
I	Performer shall be entitled to a premium of one (1) additional
rof pay for work on a holiday. If performer works six (6) days within a studio rkweek, including work on a holiday, he shall receive one and one-half (1 7) is of premium pay; except that if such holiday is the sixth day worked in the rkweek, performer shall receive only one (1) day of premium pay. If performer )‘rks seven (7) days within a studio workweek, including work on a holiday, he all receive two and one-half (27) days of premium pay; except that if the liday is the sixth or seventh day worked in the workweek, performer shall ceive two (2) days of premium pay. The following are examples of the regoing:
(i)	If the performer works seven (7) days in his workweek, eluding work on such a holiday, which holiday is not the sixth or seventh day arked in the workweek, he receives two and one-half (2*7) days of premium pay us two (2) additional days of pay for two (2) days beyond his five (5) day week a’total of nine and one-half (97a) days of pay. I
(ii)	If the performer works seven (7) days in his workweek, eluding work on such a holiday (which is the sixth day worked in the workweek) 3 on the seventh day of the workweek, he receives two (2) days of premium pay S'two (2) additional days of pay for two (2) days beyond his five (5) day week vtotal of nine (9) days of pay. Hours worked on such sixth day holiday and the enth day shall not be included in calculating performer's forty-four (44) hour rkweek. The other five (5) days shall be used for this purpose.
(iii)	If the performer works six (6) days in his workweek, lading work on such a holiday (which did not fall on the sixth or seventh day of workweek), and on either the sixth or seventh day of the week, he receives one 1 one-half (114) premium days of pay plus one (1) additional day of pay for one day beyond his five (5) day week or a total of seven and one-half (77) days of

(4)	Notwithstanding the foregoing, a sixth day worked on an J overnight location shall not be a premium day, unless it is a holiday.

29. STUNT ADJUSTMENT
£
Unless otherwise bargained for at the time of his engagement, a freek performer shall receive an additional daily stunt performers applicable on any day on which he performs a stunt. In no event shall the performer r$ less than the stunt performer's daily minimum on the day the performer does stunt (no application to a freelance performer whose pro rata for the equivalent or more than the applicable daily stunt performer’s minimum sate
Overtime compensation shall be based on the performer's aggregate J compensation and shall be computed in the manner provided in Section'd)* Schedule B. To illustrate, suppose a freelance performer on a studio five,(S workweek is employed at $2,206.00 per week and a stunt is not bargained Wednesday, he does a stunt and works eleven (11) hours. For Wednesday^ shall be paid $1,087.20 straight time ($451.20pr<9 rata plus stunt perform^ minimum of $636,00 (the applicable rate as of 7/1/01)) plus $271.80 overtnj
During the week, he works forty-seven (47) hours, including the elevenTH on Wednesday. The one (1) hour overtime for which he was paid on WE separate and apart, is disregarded. The performer receives weekly overtim —* « - — - ~	- - - -
on $2,842.00, two (2) hours at time-and-one-half or $193.77.

C? Close-ups
The Union will freely grant waivers of continuous emplo, the making of close-ups made after the completion of the Director's first-tou of the photoplay, so that the performer shall be paid only for the day or’crfys which he renders such services.

In any case in which the engagement of a performer under a freelance! contract extends into or overlaps any other engagement of such performer^ freelance performer or day performer
(1)	because of any unanticipated delay in production or bona fitted mistake, or
(2)	because of any failure of such performer to disclose his otherS< I engagements at the time of accepting any engagement, or
(3)	in any case in which, as an accommodation to such performer^ performer is permitted to work concurrently in two (2) pictures,
s** it is agreed as follows: For any day or days on which such performer render services for the Producer of the picture in which he has first rendered his ser. he shall receive compensation from such first Producer. For any day orday^ which such performer renders services for the Producer of the second picture^ which he has rendered his services, he shall be compensated by the Producer such second picture. For any day or days on which the performer does ridtjre his services either for the first Producer or for the second Producer, he shall compensated by the second Producer, unless the first and second Producers^ between themselves (and notice thereof is given to the performer) that compensation for such additional day or days shall be paid by the first Prod The compensation to be paid by the first Producer shall be paid at the rateI, specified in the performer’s contract with the first Producer, and the compensst to be paid by the second Producer shall be at the rate specified in the perfdr^i contract with the second Producer; provided, however, that if the rate paid byf
.pducer is less than the rate specified in the performer's contract with the ^'Producer, the difference shall be paid by the second Producer and, ^cd further, that for any day or days on which the performer does not render es either for the first or for the second Producer, he shall be compensated at Jof compensation which is the higher of the two. This Section does not /such performer's right to receive compensation from both Producers when Performer, while employed by one Producer, makes retakes, added scenes, etc., -.-Other Producer after the expiration of his term of employment with such /Producer, in any case in which the performer is otherwise entitled thereto. Ingin this Section contained shall be deemed or construed in any way to limit VJudice any right or remedy of any Producer, either with respect to any of the agencies hereinbefore specified or otherwise. REPORTING PRIOR TO COMMENCEMENT OF EMPLOYMENT
A’ performer residing outside of the County of Los Angeles shall not be id to report for tests or wardrobe earlier than ten (10) days prior to the ^lencement of his employment, except when Producer agrees to pay enable compensation for the excess time over the ten (10) day period.
34. ■ damagejowardrobe
Any loss of or damage to costumes, wardrobe and other property turn by the performer necessarily arising through the performance of the perfonne services, or through lack of due care on the part of the Producer, shall be by the Producer to the performer. All costumes, wardrobe and other propert furnished by the Producer shall belong to the Producer and be returned to it, and any loss of or damage thereto arising through lack of due care on^l of the performer, or not necessarily arising through the performance of th^ performer’s services, shall be paid for by the performer to the Producer, of or damage to wardrobe, for which either party hereto may be liable, shall computed on the basis of depreciation schedules to be furnished from timet by the American Appraisal Company.
35.	DEFINITION OF ROLE
The term "role," as used in the Minimum Contract for Freelance P shall be deemed to refer to said role as written at the time the freelance con entered into, or as it may from time to time thereafter be rewritten or len shortened by the Producer in the exercise of its sole discretion and jud
36.	USE OF "DOUBLE
A. The Producer agrees that it will not "dub" or use a "doubled the performer, except under the following circumstances:
(1)	When necessary to expeditiously meet the requirement
foreign exhibition;

(2)	When necessary to expeditiously meet censorship requirements, both foreign and domestic;
(3)	When, in the opinion of the Producer, the failure to double for the performance of hazardous acts might result in physical irij performer;
-282-
Schedule B
$	(4) When the performer is not available; or
J
1.	(5) When the performer fails or is unable to meet certain
rements of the role, such as singing or the rendition of instrumental music or ^similar services requiring special talent or ability other than that possessed e performer.
'The performer does hereby agree that under either or any of the conditions jabove in subparagraphs (1) to (5), both inclusive, of this Section set forth, reducer shall have the right to double and/or dub not only the acts, poses, ipd appearances of the performer, but also the voice of the performer, and Jtrumental, musical and other sound effects to be produced by the performer, ch'extent as may be required by the Producer.
W
B. Pre-production
Upon the application of Producer, the Union agrees to liberally grant
'sso that there will be no continuous employment for a freelance performer ihat performer is doubled in pre-production. The Union may require, as a
ran of the issuance of such a waiver, one day of pay to the performer for ^fhat the performer is doubled.
In order to encourage the use of principals in pre-production, the hl liberally grant waivers to permit principals to appear in pre-production hout commencing their consecutive employment until principal iphy actually commences. This provision shall apply only to Hollywood-■fnestic production of theatrical motion pictures and features made mot first exhibition on television.

38.	STUDIO RULES
The performer agrees to be prompt in appearing for work as required by’ Producer, to perform services hereunder in a conscientious and painstaking?^ manner and in accordance with the reasonable instructions of the Producer/ar abide by the reasonable studio rules and regulations of the Producer. The. Producer shall have the exclusive right to the services of the performer durwg term hereof, and the performer agrees that during the term hereof the perform! will not render any services of any kind to or for any person, firm or corporate other than the Producer without first obtaining the express written consent of I Producer.	.
39.	RIGHTS GRANTED TO PRODUCER

The term "photoplay," as used in said freelance contract, shall be deem include motion pictures produced and/or exhibited with sound and voice recording, reproducing and/or transmitting devices, radio devices and all othe improvements and devices, including television, which are now or may hcrea be used in connection with the production and/or exhibition and/or transnrissi any present or future kind of motion picture production. The Producer shalll the right to photograph and/or otherwise produce, reproduce, transmit, exhibii distribute and exploit in connection with the said photoplay any and all of the performer's acts, poses, plays and appearances of any and all kinds hereunder, shall further have the right to record, reproduce, transmit, exhibit, distributed exploit in connection with said photoplay the performer's voice and all instrumental, musical and other sound effects produced by the performer in^J connection with such acts, poses, plays and appearances. The Producer shall; likewise have the right to use and give publicity to the performer's name and^ likeness, photographic or otherwise, and to recordations and reproductions of performer’s voice and all instrumental, musical and other sound effects produc by the performer hereunder, in connection with the advertising and exploitatio said photoplay. The rights in this Section granted to the Producer shall inure*! the benefit not only of the Producer, but also to the benefit of all persons who’ hereafter acquire from the Producer any right to distribute, transmit, exhibit^ advertise or exploit said photoplay.

The Producer may terminate the performer's employment at any time, '.prior to the commencement of production of said photoplay or during the e of production.

41.	ILLNESS OF PERFORMER (SUSPENSION OF SALARY AND
TERMINATION)
The Producer need pay no salary during any period that the performer incapacitated, by illness or otherwise, from performing the required services a freelance contract and, in the event of such illness or incapacity, the Prodi its option, may terminate such employment without further liability.
42.	EMERGENQLMS^^
If the production of the photoplay specified in the freelance contract ; necessarily prevented, suspended or postponed during the course of produc' reason of fire, accident, strike, riot, act of God or of the public enemy, or Vj executive or judicial order, or postponed by reason of the illness of any oflii member of the cast or of the director, one-half (l/a) salary shall be paid the^ performer for the first three (3) weeks of prevention, suspension or postpoh It shall be the duty of the Producer during the first week of any prevention/ suspension or postponement to notify the performer in writing whether the -Producer will entirely discontinue the production or furflier suspend or posi and, in the latter event, the Producer shall pay the performer one-half (!/j) s; during such further suspended or postponed period. At the end of three (3). from the date on which the Producer has stopped production, the performer' terminate said employment if the performer so elects, unless the Producer■ ] continues thereafter to pay the performer full weekly compensation. If the^? production of said photoplay is prevented, suspended or postponed for anyre hereinabove in this Section provided, then, and in that event, the Producer-mt terminate said employment at any time after the commencement of such prevention, suspension or postponement. If the Producer elects to terminate'sag employment by reason of the illness of any other member of the cast or of die. director, then the Producer shall be obligated to pay the performer such balanc any, as is then unpaid for services theretofore rendered by the performer and a one (1) week of compensation, upon the payment of which the Producer shall'
-286-
Schedule B

Earged of and from all liability whatsoever thereunder. If such termination be fem the happening of any other cause hereinabove in this Section set forth, fee Producer shall be obligated to pay the performer only such balance, if fe is then unpaid for services theretofore rendered by the performer and, upon Itjahent of such unpaid balance, if any, the Producer shall be discharged of Bom all liability whatsoever thereunder.
EWheri the production is suspended as a result of illness of another member Ee cast or the director, and such suspension continues for five (5) days or more, suspension may be effective as of the beginning of the event of illness, but if duration is less than five (5) days, the suspension is not.effective.
Resumed propvctjqn after tjerminabon
»If the Producer elects to terminate a performer's employment under a dance contract pursuant to its right to do so for any cause hereinabove in won 42 specified, and if, at any time more than three (3) weeks after such Ration, the Producer shall desire to resume the production of said photoplay, producer shall notify the performer of its election to resume production and, in Bjvent, the performer agrees to render his services in connection with such amed production as and when the Producer may request, unless the performer is erwise employed, but if otherwise employed, the performer will cooperate to feilest extent in trying to make his services available for the Producer in motion with such resumed production. If production is resumed within six (6) nths from the date of termination, the performer’s compensation shall be at the te'rate as that hereinabove specified and shall be payable only from the date of gmencement of the performer's services in such resumed production.

fe-A. Application of Rules ft
The provisions of this Section shall apply only to freelance tenners included in this Schedule B.
B, Studio Zone
(1)	With respect to studios situated in Los Angeles, California,^ its environs, the "studio zone" shall include all territory within the radius of th^ (30) miles from the intersection of Beverly Boulevard and La Cienega Boulevardj Los Angeles, California and such other territory (such as the present Columbia^ Ranch and Disney Studio) as is generally recognized as being within the studio^ zone. With respect to studios not situated in Los Angeles or its environs, a similaj territory as the studio zone and similar rules in relation thereto shall be agreed upon between the Union and the Producers and, in default of such agreement, territory and such rules (which shall conform as nearly as possible to the rules herein set forth) shall be determined by arbitration under Section 9 of the General Provisions whenever the situation arises.	srl

* «3
(2)	With respect to studios situated in New York, New York, tHej "studio zone” shall include all territory within the radius of eight (8) miles froih^j Columbus Circle.	™
(3)	The Los Angeles Thirty (30) Mile Studio Zone
Performers may be required to report anywhere within such^ studio zone provided that, when the place of reporting is elsewhere than the Producer's studio, the following shall apply:	.
(a) Performers shall be paid $.30 per mile mileage allow^g figured from the studio to the place of reporting and back, except that no milrag allowance is required:

D. Near Location
&H.
A near location shall be anyplace which can be reached from the^ Producer's studio within twenty-four (24) hours of travel by ordinary means of^ transportation. If the Producer instructs the performer to fly to a location and the; trip takes less than twenty-four (24) hours by air, the same shall be deemed to bet near location.
E.	Distant Location
1
L
K.
A distant location shall be any place which cannot be reached from^i the Producer’s studio within twenty-four (24) hours of travel by ordinary mean^fi transportation.
F.	Place of Reporting and Dismissal
Except when already at an overnight location, performers shall be|* required to report only at the Producer's studio or within the studio zone, and $ be dismissed only at the place of reporting within the studio zone or the Prodii<T studio. When the performer is returning from such overnight location, he shall be dismissed only at the Producer's studio or the place of reporting within the zone and not at the overnight location. The provisions of this subsection F. shall not be deemed to limit provisions of subsection U. hereof.
G.	Travel Time is Work Time
Except as otherwise provided in this Schedule, all time spent by performer in traveling at the request of the Producer between any place at whicii he is required to and does report and any location, both to and from, shall be tn time, and, as such, shall be work time, subject to all deductions, limitations and exceptions for which provision is made in this Agreement.
-290-
Maximum Travel Time
Time spent in traveling shall not be included as travel time or work Erne to the extent of more than eight (8) hours in any twenty-four (24) hours.
Intervening Time between Dismissal and Travel
. .	(1)	Time intervening between the completion of a performer's
fork on any day and the commencement of travel on the same day shall be travel k, except as otherwise provided In this Agreement.
.	(2) Travel to Overnight Location: Except as otherwise provided in
©Agreement, the period of time intervening between the performer's dismissal r the day and the commencement of travel to an overnight location on the same ay shall be travel time.
(3) Travel from Overnight Location: The period intervening the performer's dismissal for the day and the commencement of travel on e same day from an overnight location shall not be work time or travel time for ^purpose.

Travel on Seventh Day
The six (6) day week, as set forth in this Schedule, does not apply in
jicase in which the performer travels seven (7) consecutive days, whether or not ‘seventh day falls within the same week.
Transportation and Lodging Furnished
The Producer shall furnish reasonable transportation to and from

M.	Deduction of Travel Time Otherwise Compensated For
Any travel time for which the performer is compensated as worker shall not be paid for as travel time.	ill
■ W’ N.	Computation of Overtime Caused by Travel Time
On a day on which a performer travels only, the performer shall be-compensated at a day of pay. On a day on which the performer travels and’w«i overtime caused by such travel will be compensated at time and one-half andhp at double time.	j
O. Travel Time re Distant Locations at Beginning or End of P

, Of Employment
The time spent in traveling to a distant location at the beginning of performer's term of employment shall not be work time or travel time for any|H purpose. The time spent in traveling from a distant location at the end of a . V; performer's term of employment shall be travel time, except as in this Agreemen otherwise provided. If the performer arrives at the distant location at or before^ 1:00 p.m., his compensation shall begin with that day (whether he works that.da or not), and any work or travel that day after such arrival shall be work time'or^ travel time, as the case may be, except as in this Agreement otherwise provided the performer arrives at the distant location after 1:00 p.m., such day shall not^ work time or travel time for any purpose, unless the performer actually workspr such day after such arrival, in which case his compensation shall begin with tart

£ P. Transportation and Travel Time on Overnight Locations to and from Qtel or Camp
h On overnight locations, the Producer shall provide transportation to d from the hotel or camp and, except as in this Schedule otherwise provided, the kto and from the hotel or camp shall be travel time. The rest period may be iuced to ten (10) hours (under Section 14.D.(2)).
f Q. Travel to or from Overnight Locations on Boat or Train When leeping Accommodations are Provided
| When more than one (1) night of travel, by ordinary means of ■ansportation, is required to reach a location, and the performer is given a berth n a boat or train, the time spent in traveling to or from such location shall not be ork time or travel time for the purpose of computing the twelve (12) hour rest enod or for the purpose of computing the ten (10) hour day; it being agreed, ibwever, that time spent in traveling on the day of arrival at such location, after :00 a.m. of such day, shall be counted for the purpose of computing the ten (10) bur day if the performer works on such day and, provided further, that the iterval between the completion of travel on such day and the commencement of vork shall not be considered travel time or work time for any purpose. Nothing gerein contained shall be construed to interrupt the performer's right to remain on salary if the performer is otherwise entitled thereto.
R.
Overnight-Trip to or from Location

When an overnight trip to or from location is required, and the same
takes at least seven (7) hours to reach and the performer is given a berth on a boat pr train, the time spent in such traveling to or from such location, whether at the beginning, during or at the end of the engagement, shall not be work time or travel .time for the purpose of computing overtime and the rest period.

S.	Travel on Holidays and the Seventh Day in the Workweek

T. Travel Pursuant to Recall for Added Scenes, etc.
Any freelance performer living within the City of Los Angeles or its environs, who is outside such area when he is recalled by the Producer for any of the reasons set forth in Section 30 hereof (including performers who are entitled the provisions of the following paragraph), shall be provided with transportation; or reimbursed for the cost of .transportation only, from the place where he is wfie recalled to the place designated by the Producer, by the particular mode of ■' £ transportation specified by the Producer, regardless of any other mode of £ transportation the performer may actually use. Return transportation shall be furnished or the performer shall be reimbursed for such return transportation, as above set forth, only if the performer shall so return within one (1) week from th date of dismissal by Producer.
Any performer living within the City of Los Angeles or its environs who is at a place beyond a radius of one hundred fifty (150) miles from the intersection of Beverly Boulevard and La Cienega, Los Angeles, California, whi he is recalled by Producer for any of the aforesaid reasons, shall be placed salary as of the day he is directed to and does report to the place designated byf Producer, and shall remain on salary each day until dismissed, except for the provisions relating to the sixth or seventh days in the workweek and holidays??! after dismissal, the performer remains in this locality or delays his return, unless by the Producer’s request, and is again recalled by the Producer, he shall not be/ entitled to any payment for the time intervening between his dismissal and hisv

1 <.6
The performer shall be entitled to travel time compensation based on the rate for his principal engagement for the period of time, and only for the ' xi of time that is required in traveling to and from the said place designated by ^Producer by the particular mode of transportation specified by the Producer, egardless of any other mode of transportation the performer may actually use. ji travel time compensation shall be computed in accordance with the travel e allowance provisions for day performers as provided for in Schedule A. The id travel time allowance for the performer's return to the place of original ^rture shall be paid only if the performer shall so return within one (1) week the date of dismissal by Producer.
If the Producer designates the mode of transportation and the day of e and the performer follows such directions, there shall be no lapse in iyment for days intervening between end of travel and commencement of work.
In the event the Producer does not specify the mode of transportation, len’the travel time allowance shall be based upon the most expeditious mode of tion possible, including travel by commercial airlines. The performer 3 not fly, but if he elects not to fly when requested to do so, it shall not the travel time allowance as specified above.
There shall be no duty on the Producer to procure return tion for the performer so long as Producer pays for the same.

To illustrate the foregoing, a performer, a resident of Los Angeles, is warily in San Francisco. Within three (3) months from the close of his icipal engagement, he is recalled by the Producer as follows: On a Monday, .^Producer directs the performer to report at the Los Angeles studio of Producer Vl’:00 a.m. on the following Thursday for retakes. The performer elects to travel jrain. He departs from San Francisco on Wednesday night, arriving at Los igeles Thursday morning, and reports at 11:00 a.m. The Producer dismisses the dormer at 2:00 p.m. on the same day. The performer elects to return to San ©cisco by train. The performer shall be entitled to one (1) day of pay at the ae rate as was paid for his original engagement, plus the cost of transportation ^commercial airline.
Transportation shall mean first-class transportation.

^V.
General
(1) Nothing in this Section 44 shall be deemed to break the
itmuous employment of a freelance performer.
w
|	(2) This Agreement uses the expressions "reasonable
asportation" and "first-class transportation." The terms are intended to be wnymous. The type of transportation required can best be illustrated by arnpjes: Bus transportation for a relatively short distance (Hollywood to Lake towhead) meets these requirements; bus transportation for a long distance plywood to San Francisco) does not. Pullman accommodations to San Kjcisco, or any other long distance, meet these requirements; deluxe asportation (e.g., Super Chief) is not required. Transportation on a commercial Eewithout sleeper accommodations is first-class transportation. First-class asportation shall be provided on commercial airlines when the performer is |£red to fly at the request of the Producer. The foregoing shall apply to jet OTS'as well as to prop-driven aircraft. The foregoing shall not apply when first-grinsportation is not available or six (6) or more of the company are being ported. Charter flights may be used which provide substantially equivalent Bgpnodations. Notwithstanding the foregoing, first-class air transportation Ballot be provided with respect to auditions and interviews.

SCHEDULE C
:n ACTORS GUILD, INC. minimum freelance contract
TELEVISION FREELANCE PERFORMERS WHOSE WEEKLY^ GUARANTEED SALARY IS MORE THAN $4,400 PER WEEK AND WIJj ARE GUARANTEED LESS THAN $32,000 PER TELEVISION PICTURf AND THEATRICAL FREELANCE PERFORMERS WHOSE WEEKL^ GUARANTEED SALARY IS MORE THAN $5,500 PER WEEK AND-WHI ARE GUARANTEED LESS THAN $60,000 PER THEATRICAL PICTU^ (LESS THAN $65,000 PER THEATRICAL PICTURE WITH RESPE&I
CONTRACTS ENTERED INTO ON OR AFTER JANUARY 1,2002)|
' Continuous Employment - Weekly Basis - Weekly Salary -One (1) Week Minimum Employment
^g-THIS AGREEMENT, made this between_____________________
feinafter called "Producer," and remailer called "performer."
day of_
1.
DEFINITION
For the purposes of this Schedule C, the words "freelance performer" slO be defined as follows: For television productions, a freelance performer is performer employed for a specific picture in a designated role, on a weeklyhasig at a salary of more than $4,400 per week and whose guarantee is less than $32^ per television picture; for theatrical productions, a freelance performer is performer employed for a specific picture in a designated role, on a weekly basig at a salary of more than $5,500 per week and whose guarantee is less than $60^00 per theatrical picture (less than $65,000 per theatrical picture with respect tq^-l
contracts entered into on or after January 1, 2002).
