• | STARTING DATE
KtA. The phrase "on or about," as used in a freelance performer's contract, ©fallow a latitude of twenty-four (24) hours, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays ndjiolidays, either prior to or after the date specified in the contract as the Eranencement of the term thereof,
&
If a freelance contract is delivered to the performer at least seven (7)
rbefore the starting date, the "on or about" clause may be used. If a contract is vered to a performer less than seven (7) days before the specified starting date, finite starting date must be specified and the "on or about" clause shall not be h'VTo illustrate: If the starting date of a performer is on the eighth day of the gj^.and the contract is delivered to the performer on the first day of the month, or about" clause may Be used, but if the contract is delivered to the
Ser on the second day of the month, the "on or about" clause may not be
BGL In any case in which it is impracticable or impossible to fix any tite starting date of any performer to be employed under a freelance contract Ige"of such performer's activities on the stage or in radio or otherwise in the sement business (except motion pictures), the Union agrees to waive the
-308-

Schedule C
requirement of a definite starting date in such freelance contract, provided that such freelance contract contains a reasonable provision for the fixing of the starting date thereof and notice thereof. Any dispute between the Union and any' ’ Producer with respect to the issuance of any such waiver shall be determined arbitration under Section 9 of the General Provisions hereof.
D. In the event a performer is engaged in accordance with Section 6:’K * hereof, but a start date has not yet been provided to the performer by the Producer^ performer may terminate such engagement in order to accept conflicting bona fide employment by a third party, subject, however, to the performer first giving Producer the following minimum period during which Producer may specify a start date which then becomes binding, which conflicts with the proffered third?
party employment:
(1)	if performer informs Producer before noon of a business dayy

by the end of the same day; or

next business day.
5.	GUARANTEE
&

One (1) picture employment for a freelance performer shall guarantee at * least one (1) week of employment. The guarantee provided in this paragraph shal be subject to the rights of suspension and termination granted to the Producerby' the provisions of Sections 37, 38, and 39 of this Schedule C.
6.	EXECUTION OF AGREEMENT - ENGAGEMENT - DELIVERY^ OF CONTRACT_______________________________
A. If said freelance contract is delivered by the Producer to the performs and if said freelance contract is executed without alteration by the performer an d i so returned to the Producer by noon of the next succeeding business day after'itsi delivery to the performer, it shall thereupon constitute a contract binding on both!

Schedule C
jarties even though not executed by the Producer, but the Producer, on demand, "all deliver a signed copy to the performer.
k B. A freelance performer under this Schedule C shall be considered ^finitely engaged in any of the following events:
&	(1)	When the performer is given written notice of acceptance;
t‘:	(2)	When a form contract signed by Producer is delivered to
irformer or when an unsigned contract is delivered by Producer to performer and executed by performer as so delivered and returned to Producer;
|	(3) When a script is delivered to the performer by Producer;
however, this does not include the delivery of a script for a test, audition or mterview nor the submission of a script for the purpose of permitting the former to determine if he desires the engagement;
(4)	When a performer is fitted for work; this shall not apply to wardrobe tests; or
(5)	When the performer is given a verbal call by Producer or an uthorized company representative, which is accepted.
X
j- C. Delivery fi>f Contra^
.	(1)	To the extent that the agreement reached between the Producer
nd the performer can be reflected on the form required by the collective bargaining agreement plus Producer's standard riders to be filed with the Union, 'reducer shall deliver a copy of such contract to the performer not later than the rstday of performer's employment. When the agreement cannot be so reflected, reducer shall deliver a copy of such contract to the performer not later than the st'day of performer's employment or four (4) business days after such reemcnt has been reached, whichever is later.
■

ritracts on the set shall continue. Delivery to a performer's agent constitutes ivery to the performer.

D. Delivery of Booking Slip
A copy of the "booking slip" shall be provided to performerria^_ than the day next preceding the first day of performer's employment. tTH
(a)	Definition of Booking Slip. A booking slip is a document! containing a designation of the role, salary and number of days of guarantee^ employment.
(b)	If performer is engaged after 6:00 p.m. on the day priori! first day of performer's employment, the booking slip will be mcluded ww script provided to performer. However, if the script was provided to pe^fbm prior to such date and hour, Producer need not provide such booking slip.TQ
(c)	The foregoing requirements for delivery of a bookings'® not apply if performer's contract has previously been delivered to performer;
performer's agent.

RATE NOT SPECIFIED ■
Whenever this Schedule states that a performer shall receive compensation irk done before he is employed, if he is not employed, and no rate is ted in this Schedule, such compensation shall be computed upon the agreed compensation, if there was such an agreed rate of compensation and, if not, e performer's established compensation. Disputes between the performer ^Producer under this provision are subject to conciliation and arbitration.
STUDIO PAYROLL WEEK - TIME OF PAYMENT
The studio payroll week shall be deemed to start at 12:01 a.nu on fland end at 12:00 midnight of the succeeding Saturday.
■- Compensation, including daily overtime, if any, earned by the per under a freelance contract shall be payable on the regular studio pay day ices rendered up to and including the preceding Saturday.

B. studio Five (5)j)ay Workweek	-1#

(3)	Work on Six (6) and/or Seven (7) Days in a Workweek k | ‘ '-#1 If the performer works on six (6) or seven (7) days irid&g workweek and performer is on a studio workweek, he shall, in each case/be3
entitled to premium pay in accordance with the following rules:	'4^
(i)	The performer shall receive a premium of an addition one-half (!4) day of pay for the sixth day worked, if the performer works six (i days within a studio workweek.
The performer shall receive a premium of an addirior day of pay for the seventh day worked if the performer works seven (7) days;!

•Ty'
|tliih a studio workweek (in addition to the one-half (14) day of premium pay for e/sixth day worked in the workweek)..
The following are examples of the foregoing:
&	(I)	If the performer works seven (7) days in his
nkweek, he shall be entitled to an additional two (2) days of pay for work ^ond five (5) days plus a premium of one and one-half (114) additional days of jpor $1,425, whichever is the lesser sum (r.e, eight and one-half (814) days, or retf(7) days plus $ 1,425, whichever is the lesser).
K	(2)	If the performer works six (6) days in his
ffkweek, he shall be entitled to an additional day of pay for work beyond five |days plus a premium of one-half (!4) day of additional pay or $475, whichever Belesser sum (i.e., six and one-half (614) days, or six (6) days plus $475, gcHever is the lesser).
(ii)	Notwithstanding the foregoing, a sixth day worked on an might location shall not be a premium day.
(iii)	For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any sixth or jetjth day in a workweek for which performer receives a premium as above guided, the performer shall receive double the straight time hourly rate provided faction 13, including overtime caused by make-up, hairdress, wardrobe and subject to the provisions of Section 13.E. hereof.

(3)	Work on Seven (7) Days in a Workweek
(a)	If a performer works seven (7) days in an overnight^ | location workweek, he shall be entitled to a premium of an extra day of pay fdrJ seventh day of work within his workweek. For example, if the performer worksl seven (7) days in his workweek, he shall receive an additional day of pay forwoB beyond six (6) days plus one (1) day of premium pay or $950, whichever isfihej lesser sum (i.e., eight (8) days, or seven (7) days plus $950, whichever is the^B lesser).
■
(b)	For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any sevam day for which performer receives a premium as above provided, the performer9 shall receive double the straight time hourly rate provided in Section 13, incite overtime caused by make-up, hairdress, wardrobe and fittings, subject, howe'rqB the provisions of Section 13.E. hereof.
D. Premium Days - Holiday Weeks - "Hold" Days	^iB
A Schedule C performer shall be treated as having worked six'(6«B days in a studio workweek (seven (7) days in an overnight location workweekM and shall be entitled to payment for the sixth day worked in a studio workwedB (the seventh day worked in an overnight location workweek), whenever a-hqltfB falls on a regularly-scheduled work day and the performer is required to W^^B (5) days in the holiday week in a studio workweek (six (6) days in the holida^B week in an overnight location workweek).	"
Whenever a performer is paid for a day or days not worked byrc^B of consecutive employment rules (a "hold day") in a week during which tbe^^B performer also works, the performer shall be considered to have worked on4^M "hold day(s)" for purposes of determining whether the performer is entitled premium pay for a sixth or seventh day worked. As an example, if the sunfqfiB number of hold days and the number of days worked by the performer iifastt^B workweek equals six (6), then the sixth day (whether worked or a hold day^^B be paid as a sixth day worked. Similarly, if die sum of the number of hobd^^^B and the number of days worked by the performer in the workweek equals^s^^H (7), then the seventh day (whether worked or a hold day) shall be paid day worked.

S‘E.	Shift in Workweek
j Once during the production of a motion picture, or in the case of sodic television, once between hiatus periods (i.e., between the commencement Resumption of production and a cessation of principal photography for the series ^fleast one week), the Producer may shift the workweek for performers iout incurring extra costs, by adding one (1) or two (2) days off consecutive frthe sixth and/or seventh days off in the prior workweek and/or by shifting a rkweek commencing on a Tuesday to a workweek commencing on a Monday, prided that the intervening Sunday is a day off.
fl
If the Producer otherwise shifts the workweek such that the new rkweek invades the preceding workweek, the Producer shall pay the premium jthcsixth and/or seventh day worked of the preceding workweek.
The performer shall be advised of any shift in the workweek prior to nmencement of that workweek.
Recall on the Sixth or Seventh Day in the Workweek
If a performer is recalled to work on a day or days that is (are) the Kand/or seventh day worked in a workweek by such performer (for which the graper received a premium of one-half (H) day or one (1) day of pay, as above Sued)for any purpose mentioned in Section 27 of this Schedule and, therefore, EipSiday performer conditions, the premium for work on the sixth or seventh Bworked shall not exceed $950.
Bp% For work on holidays and six (6) or seven (7) days in a workweek Biand after a holiday, see Section 25 of this Schedule C.

10.	PERFORMER'S WEEK
The performer’s week in each instance shall commence on the day of f week on which such performer is first placed on salary. In case of any or interruption of such performer's employment at any time for seven (7).^ consecutive days or more, for any reason whatsoever, such performer's week, thereafter commence on the day of the week when he is again placed onsaja^

11.	HQURS PE_R DA^WJQRK.PA_STMIDNI£HT
If the performer is working at midnight of any day, then his hours oif tg for such day shall be computed until the performer has been dismissed subsex to midnight, subject to all exceptions and deductions provided for in thiSfSd^ Hours of work for the following day shall, except as otherwise provided im „ Schedule, be computed from the time the performer, after having been sq^b dismissed subsequent to midnight, is next required to and does report. Nqthin herein shall derogate from the rule that when a freelance performer works" 12:01 a.m. of any day, he has worked on that day for the purpose of the	.
(5) day week or overnight location six (6) day week, whichever is applicable^ however, no premium shall be payable by reason of working past midnight inti premium day (i.e., the sixth or seventh day worked in the performer’s wqrkwg| a holiday). Daily overtime shall only commence to accrue after ten (10)^ho\ work time, as more particularly provided in Section 13 hereof.

Schedule C
Subject to the overtime provisions, when the total engagement for any week s services is night work and when the last day of such week goes idnight, the work past midnight does not count as an additional day. For uipose, night work is defined as a call for 4:00 p.m. or later.

AILY RATE QF COMPENSATION; PRORATING
Whenever it is necessary to prorate the workweek in order to determine an _J day of pay, such prorating shall be on the basis of one-fifth (1/5) of the mer's weekly base rate, for either the studio or overnight location workweek; ja; such proration shall not in any manner change the performer's weekly ate for either the studio or the overnight location workweek.
ith respect to prorating the performer's workweek for the purpose of JHe performer at the end of a payroll week, that portion of performer's workweek which is part of such payroll week shall be prorated on the basis irfifth (1/5) of the weekly base rate for each such day (excluding the sixth ehth days) in that payroll week. This is exclusive of any overtime or jumpay, if any, due in such performer's workweek.
VERUME
Overtime shall be computed and paid pursuant to the following: ’ ■
Daily overtime shall be paid at double time for each one-tenth (1/10) r portion thereof worked in excess of ten (10) hours in any day, figured on basis of $4,400 for television performers and $5,500 for theatrical
feB-iTravg) Time
W
, ,’1^’To the extent that any daily overtime is caused by travel time at the ting or at the end of the day, such overtime shall be computed as provided in f41 hereof relating to travel time.
4
A
Schedule D \ Schedule E
Schedule C
C.	- For purposes of this Section, one-tenth (1/10) hour of pay at string time for television performers shall be $10.00 and at double time $20.00; oneJ tenth (1/10) hour of pay at straight time for theatrical performers shall be. S125 and at double time $25.00.
'11
D.	Any such performer whose contract for employment in a motiqd] picture contains a provision giving such performer a percentage or other^^ participation in the receipts, revenues or profits of the motion picture shall.&a the required overtime at the time of employment; provided, however, such^a performer may agree in such contract that the overtime payments so made credited against such participations when and if received by the performer.’,
E.	Effect of Error in Computation
Any failure through error to pay all or any part of ovenimcu^J compensation shall give the performer no right except to collect the amount^ .S3
F.	Date When Due
■ .	. Wil
The overtime accruing under the provisions of this Section shal! payable not later than the studio pay day of the calendar week next following expiration of the performer's week in which such overtime accrues,
G.	Guaranteed Employment not Affected

Whenever a performer receives overtime or an additional dayofi pursuant to the provisions of this Schedule, such overtime or additional;davg shall not be deemed to reduce such performer's guaranteed employincnt arW compensation.

(A; Twelve (12) Hour Rest Period
y The performer shall be entitled to a twelve (12) hour consecutive rest rffrom the time he is finally dismissed until his first call thereafter, whether iiake-up, wardrobe, hairdress or any other purpose. However, for a performer joyed on a theatrical motion picture, the rest period may be reduced to eleven hours on any two (2) non-consecutive days in an overnight location week.
£B: Thirtv-Six (36) Hour Rest Period
• I' The performer shaft be entitled to one rest period in each week of prix (36) consecutive hours; provided, however, that if the performer is not to work on the twenty-four. (24) hours constituting the first day of any week and has not worked for Producer during the twelve (12) hours jdiately preceding such day, or if the performer is not required to work on the iylfour (24) hours constituting the last day of any workweek and does not aorthe Producer during the twelve (12) hours immediately succeeding such meri the thirty-six (36) hour rest period requirement shall be satisfied of the fact that twelve (12) hours thereof may be in the preceding or gpjng week. When the performer works on seven (7) days in any week and SHnaddition to his base pay, an extra day of pay therefor, the performer rotfce given a thirty-six (36) hour rest period for such week, but must Suedo receive his twelve (12) hour rest periods.
$ Fifty-Six (56) H<?ur Rest Period
S' When the performer is given two (2) consecutive days off during a workweek, the thirty-six (36) consecutive hour rest period shall be ed^to fifty-six (56) consecutive hours. However, when there is night igconsisting primarily of exterior photography and the performer's call is jieinthan 3:00 p.m. and he is dismissed in the studio at or before midnight [ayjsuch fifty-six (56) hour rest period, if otherwise applicable, may be fifty- four (54) hours.

It
-320-
Schedule C
-319-
Schedule C
- In lieu of the fifty-six (56) hour rest period, the performer may given a fifty-four (54) hour rest period when the call time for the first day of the new workweek following the rest period is not earlier than 6:00 a.m.
D. The above provisions regarding the rest period shall be subject to ti following exceptions:
(1)	When the Producer is photographing on a location other thffij an overnight location, the twelve (12) hour rest period may be reduced to ten (jv| hours if exterior photography is required on such location on the day before the day after such reduced rest period. When such reduction is allowed on any,dav| by reason of exterior photography on a nearby location, it may not be again.	-a
allowed until after three (3) consecutive days have intervened.
(2)	When a performer arrives at his place of lodging on an overnight location after 9:00 p.m, and does not work that night, the rest period^ with respect to the first call following such arrival may be ten (10) hours instead^ eleven (11) or twelve (12) hours, but the first call must be at the place of lodging:
(3)	When more than one (1) night of travel (by ordinary means.o^ transportation) is required to reach a location and the performer is given a berth oi a boat or train for each night of traveling, the time spent in such traveling, to j from such location, shall not be work time or travel time for the purpose of .< computing the eleven (11) or twelve (12) hour rest period.	.
(4)	When an overnight trip to or from a location is required, andPJ the same takes at least seven (7) hours to reach, and the performer is given a berth on a boat or train, or if the performer elects to travel by first-class plane O accommodations, the time spent in such traveling to or from such location shalhjj not be work time or travel time for the purpose of computing the eleven (11) or|l twelve (12) hour rest period.
(5)	The first call at the lodging for work (including make-up, ,,
hairdress, wardrobe or travel) determines the time of first call for the next dayfq^ the purpose of computing the rest period.
' ‘E. The performer may waive the rest period without the Union's consent $fcif he does so, he shall be entitled to one (1) day of pay or S950, whichever is he-jesser sum. A performer may be required to waive the rest period if the notation, in case of the twelve (12) hour rest period, is not over two and one-half T/z) hours or, on an overnight location, not over two (2) hours. The performer ray:in any case, be required to waive the thirty-six (36) hour or fifty-six (56) (or fifty-four (54)) hour rest period. In any case in which the performer waives either ^st period, the payment of one (1) day of pay, not exceeding $950, shall be iutomatically incurred. The payment may not be waived without the consent of Hie Union.
hf F. . Whenever it is provided in this Schedule that there shall be no $Kgpoundiqg of any premium pay and the payment for breach of the thirty-six [36)hour or fifty-six (56) (or fifty-four (54)) hour rest period, it is expressly Understood that the twelve (12) hour rest period between calls, and the payment fdr'violation thereof, remains in effect.
T
G. Any performer who is required to travel by air in excess of four (4) scheduled hours to a location may not be called for work without a ten (10) hour nst period. The ten (10) hour rest period shall commence from the time of arrival Bihe hotel, provided the performer goes directly to the hotel designated by the Producer. Failure to provide such ten (10) hours constitutes a rest period violation.

Any call by the Producer for make-up, hairdress or wardrobe is a call to work and not within the exception made within this subsection.

17. MEAL PERIODS
A. Allowable meal periods shall not be counted as work time foriaaj purpose. A meal period shall not be less than one-half (72) hour nor more ttiaq (1) hour in length. The performer's first meal period shall commence within sj. (6) hours following the time of his first call for the day ; succeeding meal peridi J
£
pithe same performer shall commence within six (6) hours after the end of the receding meal period. There will be a twelve (12) minute grace period, which is not.to be a scheduled grace period, prior to imposition of any meal penalty, provided that the six (6) hour period between meals has not been extended as permitted by the following sentence. If, upon the expiration of such six (6) hour period, the camera is in the actual course of photography, it shall not be a violation ^complete such photography. If, on location or while traveling to or from Kjcation, the delay is not due to any fault or negligence of the Producer or its agents or persons employed by it to render the catering service by contract, or if May is caused by common carriers such as railroads, there shall be no penalty for eolation of the above provisions. If the caterer is chosen carefully, and is delayed ^reaching the location beyond the required time for commencing a meal period, Efere'shall be no penalty for the violation; but if such delay shall continue beyond m^half (Vi) hour, work shall cease and the time intervening between such fcssation of work and the meal period shall be work time.
W)
2. S S’
©
,	. The performer shall be entitled to a non-deductible meal appropriate
iie.time of day of fifteen (15) minutes in duration within two (2) hours of the former’s call time, during which performer will be freed of all activity. If the former is given a non-deductible meal, a notation indicating the start and finish epf that meal shall be made on the production report. The first deductible meal iodshall commence within six (6) hours thereafter.
If, by reason of a long make-up, wardrobe or hairdress period of a |oriner, application of the rule would require calling a meal period for such former at a time earlier than that required for the rest of the set, Producer shall me required to call such meal period if food, such as coffee and sandwiches, is de available to such performer before the time for his set call, it being ferstood that no deduction shall be made from work time for such period; it is ^understood, however, that such performer shall be given a meal period fonsix (6) hours from the time such food is made available to the performer.
Outside the studio, when the crew is provided a meal or a meal rance (as .distinguished from per diem or penalty), the performers (other than ^receiving a per diem allowance for meals on overnight locations) will be jKiecJ either a meal or a meal allowance when they have satisfied the same sand conditions for entitlement to such meal or meal allowance as the crew.

19. WARDROBE FITTINGS	<
A. For purposes of computing daily overtime:
Time spent in fittings on the same day that the performer works shall be work time and part of the performer’s continuous day, the same as wardrobe^ but to the extent that overtime is caused by such fittings, overtime shall be paid'“-
B. A freelance performer who is fitted but not offered a written contract of employment for the role in the picture for which he was fitted at his prior, agreed salary (or, if there has been no agreement, at his usual salary) shall receive: one (1) day of pay for each day on which he was fitted. If there has been no agreed salary before the fitting, and if the performer and Producer cannot agreed
the salary rate at which he shall receive the day of pay shall be determined by
-327-
Schedule C
^conciliation and, if conciliation fails, by arbitration; but in no event shall the day gf pay be in excess of weekly scale. The provisions of this Section shall not apply ^fittings for tests, auditions or interviews.
C.	Fittings, after employment but before the starting date of such employment, shall not start the consecutive days of employment of a freelance (performer.
D.	There shall be a voucher provided at all wardrobe fittings to be signed ®.the performer indicating time in and time out.
?20. STORY, SONG AND PRODUCTION CONFERENCES
Story, song and production conferences on any day on which the performer as not otherwise working shall not be counted as work time for any purpose. This ^provision shall not be construed to interrupt the continuous employment of a d^elance performer.
STUDY OF LINES OR SCRIPT
Study of lines or script, except during the period between reporting and ^dismissal, shall not be counted as work time for any purpose.
t22i • PUBLICITY INTERVIEWS
Publicity interviews held at a time mutually satisfactory to the performer 'and the Producer shall not be work time for any purpose unless held on a day on [which the performer is otherwise working for the Producer. Such interviews for tpubiicity purposes held on any day on which the performer is otherwise working [for the Producer shall not be counted as work time if held after the performer's BSrnissal for the day, if such interview is held at a time mutually satisfactory to toerformer and Producer. If the interview is held during a meal period, it shall not fife deemed to constitute a violation thereof.

24.	REHEARSAL TIME
A.	The reading of lines, acting, singing or dancing, in preparation for? performer’s performance, in the presence and under the supervision of a JFJ representative of Producer, constitutes a rehearsal. Rehearsals shall be counted a work time.
■
B.	Auditions, tests, interviews, make-up and wardrobe tests do notJO constitute rehearsals.
C.	The Union agrees to freely grant waivers for the training of a ‘ performer in a particular skill such as horseback riding, fencing, etc. j Compensation, if any, shall be agreed to between the performer and the Producer, subject to the approval of the Union.	_
D.	Neither tests, auditions, fittings, publicity stills, pre-production stdli pre-recordings nor training under subsection C. above, after employment but’.^ before the starting date of such employment, shall start the employment period A such performer. Compensation, if any, for any of such services shall be as otherwise provided in this Schedule.	JT?

^ WORK ON HOLIDAYS AND SIX (6) OR SEVEN (7) DAYS IN A & WORKWEEK. BEFQREANDAFTER___________________________
A.	The nine (9) holidays hereinafter referred to are the following: New ar’s Day, Presidents' Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, July Fourth, Labor Day, inksgiving Day, the Friday after Thanksgiving and Christinas Day. Whenever (ofsaid holidays falls on a Sunday, such holiday, for all purposes of this lediile C, shall be deemed to fall on the Monday next succeeding, and the sixth [seventhdays in the workweek preceding shall be deemed a sixth and seventh r before such holiday.
$ .
(1)	a performer works on any of the nine (9) holidays or a iday and six (6) or seven (7) days in a workweek, he shall, in each case (that is, tarately for the holiday and for the sixth or seventh day, if he works on each ^respective day), be entitled to premium pay, in accordance with the following
Performer shall be entitled to a premium of one (1) additional yof pay for work on a holiday. If performer works six (6) days within a studio rkweek, including work on a holiday, he shall receive one and one-half (1 ’/i) fsof premium pay; except that if such holiday is the sixth day worked in the
-330-

Schedule C
t
&
workweek, performer shall receive only one (1) day of premium pay. If performer works seven (7) days within a studio workweek, including work on a holiday, hejA; shall receive two and one-half (2/2) days of premium pay; except that if the 4-1 holiday is the sixth or seventh day worked in the workweek, performer shall £ | receive two (2) days of premium pay. The following are examples of the foregoing:

•J. •*
(i)	If the performer works seven (7) days in his workweek,^
including work on such a holiday, which holiday is not the sixth or seventh day V worked in the workweek, he receives two and one-half (2%) days of premium plus two (2) additional days of pay for two (2) days beyond his five (5) day week!’, or a total of nine and one-half (97i) days of pay.	,
(ii)	If the performer works seven (7) days in his workweek,^, including work on such a holiday (which is the sixth day worked in the workweek).; and on the seventh day in the workweek, he receives two (2) days of premium pay,; plus two (2) additional days of pay for two (2) days beyond his five (5) day weekS or a total of nine (9) days of pay.
(iii)	If the performer works six (6) days in his workweek, including work on such a holiday (which did not fall on the sixth or seventh day of the workweek), and on either the sixth or seventh day of the week, he receives one and one-half (1 l/x) premium days of pay plus one (1) additional day of pay for onef (1) day beyond his five (5) day week or a total of seven and one-half (7/2) days ofih pay.
(iv)	If performer works five (5) days or less in his workweek^ he receives a premium of an extra day of pay for each day worked which is a , I holiday.	‘jv

&

op-	(ii)	If the performer works only six (6) days or less in his
^workweek, including work on a holiday, the performer receives one (I) premium 'day of pay, or a total of seven (7) days of pay for that week.

Seventh day for which the performer receives a premium as above provided, the ^performer shall receive double the straight time hourly rate as provided in Section 413, including overtime caused by make-up, hairdress, wardrobe or fittings, subject, ^however, to the provisions of Section 13.C. hereof.

26. WORK PAST MIDNIGHT ON LAST DAY	>
Tsy
When a performer works past midnight on the last day of his engagemen' he shall be compensated for services rendered past midnight by the payment gf one-fifth (1/5) of his weekly rate as his base for that day.	'\£,
T'
Subject to the overtime provisions, when the total engagement for any/ of the performer's services is night work and when the last day of such week-; past midnight, the work past midnight does not count as an additional day. F this purpose, night work is defined as a call for 4:00 p.m. or later.

RETAKES, ADDED SCENES, LOOPING. ETC
A. If, after the expiration of the term provided by the freelance contract, Producer should desire the services of the performer in making retakes, or in g added scenes or sound track, or in making any process shots, cies or trick shots, or in making trailers, or in making any change or changes in said photoplay, or in making any foreign version or versions of said
photoplay, then and in either of said events, the performer agrees to render such ervices in connection therewith as and when the Producer may request, unless the lertormer is otherwise employed, but if otherwise employed, the performer will ooperate to the fullest extent. If commenced within four (4) months (six (6) oonths for theatrical motion pictures, pilots or long-form television motion Jictures (including multi-part closed-end series)) after the expiration of the term ’ f, such services shall be at the same rate of compensation as set forth in the . s contract, except that compensation for such services shall be paid only inhe days on which the performer is actually so employed, and except also that applicable conditions governing the employment of day performers under the c Agreement shall apply to the computation of time in connection with such

jrvices. It is agreed, however, that if, prior to the commencement of the rendition ^uch services, the Producer shall have agreed in writing to guarantee the crforiner at least one (1) week of work or one (1) week of compensation in
nnection therewith, then and in that event, such services shall be upon the same msand at the same rate of compensation as elsewhere in this Schedule set forth, th compensation to be paid from the time when the performer's services are first miered in connection therewith until the completion of the performer’s services connection therewith.
Performer may be recalled to loop (record sound track) after mpletion of principal photography at one-half (%) of the performer's pro rata aly salary for a four (4) hour looping session. If the session exceeds four (4) igr^a full day of pro rata salary shall be payable.
’ The performer’s contract shall not include guarantees for looping, kes,'added scenes, process transparencies, trick shots, trailers, changes or ignversions (subject to availability) outside the period of consecutive loyment.

,C. Clo$e-ups
The Union will freely grant waivers of continuous employment for* the making of close-ups made after the completion of the Director's first rough ci of the photoplay, so that the performer shall be paid only for the day or days upor which he renders such services.

28.	OVERLAPPING ENGAGEMENT
■fl
In any case in which the engagement of a performer under a freelance contract extends into or overlaps any other engagement of such performer as freelance performer or day performer
(1)	because of any unanticipated delay in production or bona fide
mistake, or
(2)	because of any failure of such performer to disclose his other engagements at the time of accepting any engagement, or
(3)	in any case in which, as an accommodation to such performer, sue performer is permitted to work concurrently in two pictures,	. -
it is agreed as follows: For any day or days on which such performer renders bi services for the Producer of the picture in which he has first rendered his service he shall receive compensation from such first Producer. For any day or days oh’ which such performer renders services for the Producer of the second picture in which he has rendered his services, he shall be compensated by the Producer of-such second picture. For any day or days on which the performer does not rent his services either for the first Producer or for the second Producer, he shall be compensated by the second Producer, unless the first and second Producer agif between themselves (and notice thereof is given to the performer) that ? compensation for such additional day or days shall be paid by the first Produc The compensation to be paid by the first Producer shall be paid at the rate j specified in the performer's contract with the first Producer, and the compens;
to be paid by the second Producer shall be at the rate specified in the perform contract with the second Producer; provided, however, that if the rate paid by
-335-
Schedule C
list Producer is less than the rate specified in the performer's contract with the econd Producer, the difference shall be paid by the second Producer and, irovided further, that for any day or days on which the performer does not render ervices either for the first or for the second Producer, he shall be compensated at le rate of compensation which is the higher of the two. 31.	DAMAGE TO WARDROBE
Any loss of or damage to costumes, wardrobe and other property furnished i by the performer necessarily arising through the performance of the performer’s^ services, or through lack of due care on the part of the Producer, shall be paid fqr& by the Producer to the performer. All costumes, wardrobe and other property furnished by the Producer shall belong to the Producer and be returned promptiya to it and any loss of or damage thereto arising through lack of due care on the part< of the performer, or not necessarily arising through the performance of the rj Jg performer’s services, shall be paid for by the performer to the Producer. Any lo5$& of or damage to wardrobe, for which either party hereto may be liable, shall be jY computed on the basis of depreciation schedules to be furnished from time to tiw by the American Appraisal Company.	,
32.	DEFINITION OF ROLE

The term "role," as used in the Minimum Contract for Freelance Performer^ shall be deemed to refer to said role as written at the time the freelance contract is entered into, or as it may from time to time thereafter be rewritten or lengthened ot. shortened by the Producer in the exercise of its sole discretion and judgment. eCf
33.	USE OF "DOUBLE”	jkg
A. The Producer agrees that it will not "dub” or use a "double" in lieu on the performer, except under the following circumstances:
(1)	When necessary to expeditiously meet the requirements of i
foreign exhibition;
(2)	When necessary to expeditiously meet censorship	1
requirements, both foreign and domestic;
(3)	When, in the opinion of the Producer, the failure to use a JJrj double for the performance of hazardous acts might result in physical injury to‘^3 performer;	^3
ScbcdulcC
-337-
Ff	(4)	When the performer is not available; or
|||.	(5)	When the performer fails or is unable to meet certain
^requirements of the role, such as singing or the rendition of instrumental music or [other similar services requiring special talent or ability other than that possessed |by the performer.
The performer does hereby agree that under either or any of the ^conditions hereinabove in subparagraphs (1) to (5), both inclusive, of this Section ^et forth, the Producer shall have the right to double and/or dub not only the acts, Ipdses, plays and appearances of the performer, but also the voice of the performer, |and all instrumental, musical and other sound effects to be produced by the [performer, to such extent as may be required by the Producer.
h|-
3; B. Pre-production
. Upon the application of Producer, the Union agrees to liberally grant ^waivers so that there will be no continuous employment for a freelance performer |when that performer is doubled in pre-production. The Union may require, as a ►condition of the issuance of such a waiver, one day of pay to the performer for ^each-day that the performer is doubled.
p'Ajr
;	In order to encourage the use of principals in pre-production, the
► Union will liberally grant waivers to permit principals to appear in pre-production shots without commencing their consecutive employment until principal
^photography actually commences. This provision shall apply only to ^Hollywood-based domestic production of theatrical motion pictures and features |nade primarily for first exhibition on television.
RIGHT TQ MAME OR CHARACTER
h-f
| No Producer shall, after the termination of the performer's employment, [prevent such performer from continuing the use of any stage or screen name used fcbyjsuch performer. The name of a role owned or created by the Producer, such as i-Tarzan or Charlie Chan, belongs to the Producer and not to the performer.

35. STUDIO RULEg

Producer, to perform services hereunder in a conscientious and painstaking manner and in accordance with the reasonable instructions of the Producer, andto abide by the reasonable studio rules and regulations of the Producer. The Producer shall have the exclusive right to the services of the performer during the’; term hereof, and the performer agrees that during the term hereof the performer^ will not render any services of any kind to or for any person, firm or corporation^-/ other than the Producer without first obtaining the express written consent of-the? Producer.

38.	ILLNESS OF PERFORMER (SUSPENSION OF SALARY AND? TERMINATION)_____________________________
The Producer need pay no salary during any period that the performer is incapacitated, by illness or otherwise, from performing the required services u a freelance contract, and in the event of such illness or incapacity, the Produce
its option, may terminate such employment without further liability.

39.	EMERGENCY SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION

If the production of the photoplay specified in the freelance contract be necessarily prevented, suspended or postponed during the course of productid reason of fire, accident, strike, riot, act of God or of the public enemy, or by$a executive or judicial order, or postponed by reason of the illness of any other member of the cast or of the director, one-half (!4) salary shall be paid the performer for the first three (3) weeks of prevention, suspension or postponen It shall be the duty of the Producer during the first week of any prevention, 'K suspension or postponement to notify the performer in writing whether the Producer will entirely discontinue the production or further suspend or postpo and, in the latter event, the Producer shall pay the performer half salary during such further suspended or postponed period. At the end of three (3) weeks fro: the date on which the Producer has stopped production, the performer may$^ terminate said employment if the performer so elects, unless the Producer continues thereafter to pay the performer full weekly compensation. If the production of said photoplay is prevented, suspended or postponed for any reas hereinabove in this Section provided, then and in that event, the Producer nily terminate said employment at any time after the commencement of such prevention, suspension or postponement, If the Producer elects to terminated employment by reason of the illness of any other member of the cast or of tlicF" director, then the Producer shall be obligated to pay the performer such balance, any, as is then unpaid for services theretofore rendered by the performer, and^ls one (1) week of compensation, upon the payment of which the Producer shallot
-341 -
Schedule C
&
Application of Rules
of and from all liability whatsoever thereunder. If such termination be on the happening of any other cause hereinabove in this Section set forth, die Producer shall be obligated to pay the performer only such balance, if -as is then unpaid for services theretofore rendered by the performer and, upon t of such unpaid balance, if any, the Producer shall be discharged of ■from all liability whatsoever thereunder.
When the production is suspended as a result of illness of another member cast or the director, and such suspension continues for five (5) days or more, Suspension may be effective as of the beginning of the event of illness, but if ration is less than five (5) days, the suspension is not effective.
S RESUMED PRODUCTION AFTER TERMINATION

39 specified, and if, at any time more than three (3) weeks after such iination, the Producer shall desire to resume the production of said photoplay, Producer shall notify the performer of its election to resume production and, in eyent,.the performer agrees to render his services in connection with such
production as and when the Producer may request, unless the performer is arwise employed, but if otherwise employed, the performer will cooperate to illest extent in trying to make his services available for the Producer in
on with such resumed production. If production is resumed within six (6) Maths from the date of termination, the performer's compensation shall be at the prate as that hereinabove specified and shall be payable only from the date of
cement of the performer's services in such resumed production.

(i)	if the performer is employed on a long-fdrnv television motion picture; or

Union of the point so designated. With respect to any television series, such y be changed by Producer at the beginning of each season. Commencing ;the ten (10) mile radius, a mileage allowance will be paid as provided p.^The Union will not unreasonably refuse a request from the Producer that report to a location which is a reasonable distance beyond the Los les thirty (30) mile zone.
(b)	Distances shall be clearly stated on the performer's
Setion time report.
(c)	If, during the term of this Agreement, the International x of Theatrical Stage Employes, through its collective bargaining negotiates with Producer a more favorable mileage allowance than the thirty cents ($.30) per mile allowance, then, in such event, from such the Union will be entitled to the benefit of such increase.
(d)	The mileage allowance may be paid as a portion of the s payroll check, provided it is separately identified as such mileage hursement.

atically terminate on June 30,2004,

D. Near Location
A near location shall be any place which can be reached from ttfg Producer's studio within twenty-four (24) hours of travel by ordinary means of transportation. If the Producer instructs the performer to fly to a location and trip takes less than twenty-four (24) hours by air, the same shall be deemed td near location.
E. Distant Location
A distant location shall be any place which cannot be reachedfr the Producer's studio within twenty-four (24) hours of travel by ordinary
transportation.
F. Place Qf Reporting and Dismissal
I.


Except when already at an overnight location, performers shall b required to report only at the Producer's studio or within the studio zone,"an be dismissed only at the place of reporting within the studio zone or the Prod studio. When the performer is returning from such overnight location, hefs dismissed only at die Producer's studio or the place of reporting within die zone, and not at the overnight location. The provisions of this subsection!^ be subject to and shall not be deemed to limit the provisions of subsection^ hereof.	■

G. Travel Time is Work Time
Except as otherwise provided in this Schedule, all time spent by-performer in traveling at the request of the Producer between any place at win he is required to and does report and any location, both to and from, shall be time and, as such, shall be work time, subject to all deductions, limitations bn exceptions for which provision is made in this Agreement.
-345-
J. H. Mayinw Travel Time
Time spent in traveling shall not be included as travel time or work to the extent of more than eight (8) hours in any twenty-four (24) hours.
Intervening Time between Dismissal and Travel
(1) Time intervening between the completion of a performer's ck’on any day and the commencement of travel on the same day shall be travel except as otherwise provided in this Agreement.
(2) Travel to Overnight Location: Except as otherwise provided in Agreement, the period of time intervening between the performer's dismissal ' day and the commencement of travel to an overnight location on the same still be travel time.
(3) Travel from Overnight Location: The period intervening the performer's dismissal for the day and the commencement of travel on tame day from an overnight location shall not be work time or travel time for ^purpose.
Travel on Seventh Day
" The six (6) day week, as set forth in this Schedule, does not apply in in which the performer travels seven (7) consecutive days, whether or not day falls within the same week.

-349-
Schedule C
If the Producer designates the mode of transportation and the day of and the performer follows such directions, there shall be no lapse in for days intervening between end of travel and commencement of work.
In the event the Producer does not specify the mode of transportation, h the travel time allowance shall be based upon the most expeditious mode of
9
s.
There shall be no duty on the Producer to procure return tion for the performer so long as Producer pays for the same.
To illustrate the foregoing, a performer, a resident of Los Angeles, is temporarily in San Francisco. Within three (3) months from the close of his rincipal engagement, he is recalled by the Producer as follows: On a Monday, the Producer directs the performer to report at the Los Angeles studio of Producer ;j 1:00 a.m. on the following Thursday for retakes. The performer elects to travel lytrain. He departs from San Francisco on Wednesday night, arriving at ‘ s Angeles Thursday morning, and reports at 11:00 a.m. The Producer dismisses Sic performer at 2:00 p.m. on the same day. The performer elects to return to San Francisco by train. The performer shall be entitled to one (1) day of pay at the same rate as was paid for his original engagement, plus the cost of transportation ‘ commercial airline.

Transportation shall mean first-class transportation.
In the foregoing example, if the performer had been dismissed at 6:00 i.m/with an hour off for lunch (six (6) hours work, four (4) hours travel), the former would have been entitled to pay for one (1) day plus two (2) hours at and one-half. The travel allowance contemplated by this paragraph shall entitle the performer to time and one-half. The performer shall not be entitled to a ravel allowance of more than eight (8) hours in any period of twenty-four (24) ours; and the performer shall not be entitled to any travel time allowance for a nod of travel for which he is otherwise paid.

V.	General
(1)	Nothing in this Section 41 shall be deemed to breakfoj continuous employment of a freelance performer.	MS
11
-351-
Schedule C	•?' S
■	(2) This Agreement uses the expressions "reasonable
msportation" and "first-class transportation." The terms are intended to be noriymous. The type of transportation required can best be illustrated by ample: Bus transportation for a relatively short distance (Hollywood to Lake yowhead) meets these requirements; bus transportation for a long distance lollywood to San Francisco) does not. Pullman accommodations to San antisco, or any other long distance, meet these requirements; deluxe msportation (e.g., Super Chief) is not required. Transportation on a commercial without sleeper accommodations is first-class transportation. First-class msportation shall be provided on commercial airlines when the performer is wired to fly at the request of the Producer. The foregoing shall, apply to jet ms.as well as to prop-driven aircraft. The foregoing shall not apply when pmss transportation is not available or six (6) or more of the company are |igfransported. Charter flights may be used which provide substantially Bwalent accommodations. Notwithstanding the foregoing, first-class air msportation need not be provided with respect to auditions and interviews.

(Note Sections 41 _U.(1) and Be
services of the performer, at commencement of the term of Sient, are to be rendered at a place which cannot be reached from the studio within twenty-four (24) hours of travel by ordinary means of Eation, then and in that event, compensation shall not commence to accrue fcf	-352-

(Note Sections 41.U.(1) and (2) above.) i
43.	GUARANTEE NOT AFFECTED BY ADDITIONAL DAY OF PAY
Whenever a performer receives an additional day or days of pay pursuant^ the provisions of this Schedule, such additional day or days of pay shall not bejte deemed to reduce such performer’s guaranteed employment or compensation.
44.	INTERVIEWS AND AUDITIONS
A.	A performer employed under Schedule B or C shall not be kept waiting for an interview or audition for more than one (1) hour after the time scheduled for the interview or audition. The type of interview or audition refeifc to is an interview or audition for a specific picture, not a general or get-acquaintci type of interview. If the performer is more than five (5) minutes late, the above;,', rule shall not be applicable. It is not the intent of this provision to limit the duration of the interview or audition itself. If a performer is detained for more^, than the permitted period, he shall be compensated for the excess time he is required to wait at his straight time hourly rate in one-half (14) hour units. If nb^ salary has been agreed upon before the interview or audition, and if the performer and Producer cannot agree on the applicable salary, the salary rate at which suchi performer shall be compensated for such excess time shall be determined by conciliation and, if conciliation fails, by arbitration in accordance with the . applicable provisions of the Basic Agreement. However, claims for violation^ this subsection A. must be filed by the Screen Actors Guild not later than fifteen,^ (15) days after the date of the alleged violation.
-353-
SchedulcC
B.	If parking space is not provided or readily available, Producer will Validate or reimburse parking costs incurred by performers in connection with interviews.
<
C.	The latest version of the script will be made accessible to the (perfonner in the casting office twenty-four (24) hours in advance of a scheduled reading or immediately after the scheduling of the interview, whichever last rOCCUTS.
&
A;
D,	For scheduled interviews (other than general or get-acquainted type ■interviews) and auditions conducted and confirmed by the casting office (or, if ;Producer has no casting office, in the office of Producer's casting representative), sign-in sheets shall be required at the place where the performer is first directed to Report. Copies of such sheets shall be kept by Producer for thirty (30) days and, during that time, such sheets will be made available to the Union upon request. The sign-in sheet shall indicate whether parking was provided.
Sign-in sheets for scheduled interviews and auditions shall include lie following information: performer's name; social security number; name of role; performer’s agent (if any); whether the interview or audition was videotaped; .whether parking was provided; whether the script was available; actual call; waiting time; and performer’s initials.
I
%-,E. A person authorized to effectively recommend selection shall be iresent at any second or subsequent interview/audition for a specific role.
<<
y ■ F.	If a performer who has been individually interviewed or auditioned
or'a specific role desires to have the videotape of such interview or audition srased, the Producer will do so upon written request of the performer. If two (2) ff more performers are so interviewed dr auditioned together on the same videotape, the Producer will erase such tape upon the written request of all such performers. In either case, the erasure will take place after completion of the casting process.
:G. In connection with auditions or interviews, Producer shall have the right to state its intention with respect to the terms and conditions of employment forithe role. Performers who do not intend to accept such terms and conditions b 4	-354-
Ai'	Schedule C
Schedule D	Schedule E
shall nevertheless have the right to audition or interview and negotiate for better terms and conditions at the time of hiring.

SCHEDULE D
MULTIPLE PICTURE PERFORMERS RECEIVING $4,400 OR LESS PER | WEEK AND GUARANTEED LESS THAN $32,000 PER TELEVISION t
PICTURE OR RECEIVING $5,500 OR LESS PER WEEK AND	T
GUARANTEED LESS THAN $60,000 PER THEATRICAL PICTURE > ($5,500 OR LESS PER WEEK AND GUARANTEED LESS THAN $65,000 |
PER THEATRICAL PICTURE WITH RESPECT TO CONTRACTS	g
ENTERED INTO ON OR AFTER JANUARY 1,2002)	ft
1.
DEFINITION
A multiple picture performer, for the purposes of this Schedule D, is a performer who is employed for two (2) or more pictures per year, whose contract with respect to services in the production of motion pictures is non-exclusive, and, in addition, (A) whose compensation for any television motion picture is at the rate of $4,400 or less per week or equivalent compensation on a picture or other basis, and who is guaranteed less than $32,000 per television picture; and (B) whose compensation for any theatrical motion picture is at the rate of $5,500 or ■ less per week or equivalent compensation on a picture or other basis, and who is guaranteed less than $60,000 per theatrical picture (less than $65,000 per theatrical picture with respect to contracts entered into on or after January 1, 2002). A multiple picture performer contract may be for a period of years, provided that the contract calls for at least two (2) pictures in any yearly period.
2.
MUM COMPENSATION
mlaj
$
The minimum salary for a multiple picture performer shall be $2,206 per week for the period July 1,2001 through June 30,2002; $2,272 per week for the period July 1, 2002 through June 30, 2003 and $2,352 per week for the period July 1, 2003 through June 30,2004.

r responsibility to return a completed W-4 form to Producer in a timely maimer. It
| is understood that when a performer fails to do so, there shall be no retroactive I' adjustments to the withholding required by law.

s Section 43, "Resumed Production after Termination," when the multiple
1 picture performer is guaranteed $10,000 or more for his services in a photoplay.

3 It is agreed that the conditions of this Schedule, including the incorporation w by reference in Section 3 hereof, shall become a part of the contract with the ^multiple picture performer to whom this Schedule applies.
is. REPLACEMENT OF PERFORMER
5
In the event that a performer is replaced in the role, the performer, or
^ performer's agent, shall be notified of this fact at the time of the replacement.

SCHEDULEE
CONTRACT PERFORMERS WHOSE WEEKLY GUARANTEED SALARY IS $4,400 OR LESS PER WEEK FOR TELEVISION MOTION ^PICTURES OR WHOSE WEEKLY GUARANTEED SALARY IS $5,500 OR J LESS PER WEEK FOR THEATRICAL MOTION PICTURES


A contract performer is a performer employed under a contract for ^television motion pictures or theatrical motion pictures or both (in which latter [case such contracts are sometimes referred to as "combination term contracts"), Which contract is for a term of at least ten (10) out of thirteen (13) weeks and finch may not specify any role, picture or series, unless otherwise requested by .■the performer and approved by the Union. The Union agrees it will liberally grant waivers in the event of such request. The Producer and the performer may agree '/on any overall term of hiring in excess of ten (10) guaranteed weeks, provided that the guaranteed number of weeks is in the same proportion to the overall period as ’ten (10) out of thirteen (13)."
A CLASSIFICATIONS OF CONTRACT PERFORMERS - TERM t CONTRACT________________________________________
I
•& A. When a performer is employed for two (2) or more pictures per year tor other specified period (hereinafter referred to as the "employment period") and jhe contract is exclusive with respect to his services in the production of motion pictures, the performer shall be classified, for the purpose of this Agreement, as a /pterin contract performer" and his classification as a term contract performer with ■-respect to "hours" shall be determined in accordance with the following formula:
The total guaranteed' compensation of the performer shall be divided ■ 4>y the proportionate number of weeks in the employment period that forty (40) .Shears to fifty-two (52). For example: if the employment period is one year, the ^guaranteed compensation shall be divided by forty (40) weeks; if the employment
-365 -
Schedule E
-364-
Schedulc E
period is six (6) months, the guaranteed compensation shall be divided by twenty^ (20) weeks, etc. If the resulting figure reflects a compensation of more than $4,400 per week for television motion pictures or more than $5,500 per week far| theatrical motion pictures, the provisions of Schedule F shall apply to the employment. If the resulting figure is $4,400 per week or less for television motion pictures or $5,500 per week or less for theatrical motion pictures, the provisions of Schedule E shall apply to the employment.
When a performer who, under the above formula, has been classified so as to receive the provisions of Schedule E receives compensation in addition to his minimum guaranteed compensation, which additional compensation, when “j added to his total minimum guaranteed compensation and divided by the said proportionate number of weeks in the employment period, would raise the performer above the $4,400 breaking point for television motion pictures or above^ the $5,500 breaking point for theatrical motion pictures, then such performer, from that time forward, shall receive the provisions of Schedule F instead of Schedule E for the balance of the employment period in question. The so-called "breaking point" for a performer whose employment period is one (1) year shall $ $ 100,000; for an employment period of six (6) months, $50,000; for an employment period of three (3) months, $25,000, etc.
B.	The employment period of ten (10) out of thirteen (13) weeks may n6t£
be used in the same term contract except during the first year; thereafter, the contract shall guarantee a minimum period of employment of twenty (20) out of ‘ twenty-six (26) weeks. This subsection is subject to Section 12(c) of the 2001 Screen Actors Guild Television Agreement.
3.
SCHEDULE E INCLUDED IN INDIVIDUAL CONTRACTS
It is agreed that the terms, conditions and exceptions of this Schedule shall ■ become a part of the contract of a contract performer while he is receiving $4,400 or less per week for a television motion picture or is receiving $5,500 or less per week for a theatrical motion picture.	J
Ui
: ■ ’ W-4 forms shall be presented to performer no later than the first day of employment. A W-4 form may be given to performer on the set on the first day of loyment.
W-4 forms shall be available on every set. It shall be the performer’s responsibility to return a completed W-4 form to Producer in a timely manner. It [is understood that when a performer fails to do so, there shall be no retroactive adjustments to the withholding required by law.
& o a
[4. MINIMUM SALARY OF CONTRACT. PERFORMERS
J	The minimum weekly salary for contract performers, other than "beginners,"
%is as follows:

If performer is guaranteed ten (10) but no more than nineteen (19) weeks -$1,893 for the period July 1,2001 through June 30, 2002; $1,950 for the period $July 1,2002 through June 30,2003; and $2,018 for the period July 1, 2003 ^through June 30, 2004.
If performer is guaranteed twenty (20) or more weeks - $1,576 per week for jthe period July 1, 2001 through June 30, 2002; $1,623 for the period July 1,2002 through June 30, 2003; and $1,680 for the period July 1, 2003 through June 30,
I
^5. COMBINATION TERM CONTRACTS
A.	Performer employed under a combination term contract and used in a ^television series in a continuing role:
(1)	If a performer is used in a continuing role in a one-half (!6)
^bour television series, he shall be adjusted for the duration of such services to the series contract salaries and applicable rerun, theatrical, Supplemental Market, kbasic cable and foreign telecast rates.
•fl

-366-
-367-
Schedule E
©
Schedule E

(2)	If performer is used in a continuing role in a one (1) hour or * one and one-half (114) hour television series, he shall be adjusted for the duration of such services to the weekly freelance salary rate and applicable rerun, theatric Supplemental Market, basic cable and foreign telecast rates, it being understood! this connection that such adjustment shall not result, with respect to his serviceri any episode in such series, in his receiving less than a week of freelance salary.^
(3)	If Producer uses the performer in a greater number of episoffia than the number of weeks of employment guaranteed under this subsection A*pb| in a combination of this provision and subsection B. below, the performer shall h paid the weekly freelance salary and applicable rerun, theatrical, Supplemental | Market, basic cable and foreign telecast rates for each additional episode in whi^ his services are used. If the performer is employed beyond the guaranteed pen^ of employment, he shall be paid an amount equal to the weekly freelance salaro each additional week or episode, whichever is the greater.
B.	Performer employed under a combination term contract and usedjng television episode, but not a continuing role:	JI
(I)	A term performer who is guaranteed a minimum of twenty (3| out of twenty-six (26) weeks, who works in a television episode or episodes,’ bui| who does not have a continuing role in a series, shall not be used in more thatr|| fifteen (15) television episodes during such period. If he is used in more than 3 fifteen (15) such episodes, he shall be paid an additional week of salary and^a applicable rerun, theatrical, Supplemental Market, basic cable and foreign tele’oS rates for each such additional episode.
■
(2)	A term performer who is guaranteed a minimum of ten (KM of thirteen (13) weeks, who works in a television episode or episodes but whoW does not have a continuing role in a series, if used in more than seven (7) suclia episodes, shall be paid an additional week of salary and applicable rerun, 'joB theatrical, Supplemental Market, basic cable and foreign telecast rates foreaclM such additional episode.
(3)	If such performer is used beyond the guaranteed periodbi employment, he shall be paid an amount equal to his weekly salary for each\ additional week or episode, whichever is greater.
- 368 -
Schedule E	f
(4)	For all such term performers who do not appear in a continuing »e, the applicable rerun, theatrical, Supplemental Market, basic cable and foreign ilecast rates per episode shall be based on the applicable weekly rate.
C.	Applicable television weekly freelance salary, series contract salary, :nm, theatncal, Supplemental Market, basic cable and foreign telecast rates iferred to above are those rates provided by the applicable Screen Actors Guild elevision Agreement in effect when such services were rendered in such vision films.
D.	When a term contract performer is assigned to regular employment in levi&on and Producer avails himself of the layoff rights provided for term Eifract performers, Producer may not also exercise its hiatus rights provided in s collective bargaining agreement covering the employment of term contract formers in television.
^FE. A separate clause shall be inserted in all combination term contracts, :cifymg separate compensation for services, reruns, theatrical exhibition, fplemental Market and basic cable use and foreign telecasting of television tiori pictures for each contract term or option period.
‘j*F. No advance payments may be made for reruns, theatrical; or foreign last rights nor may overscale salary be credited against any sums due the ormer under the contract; As to term contracts in existence on February 1, flMwidirig for advances against reruns, no such advances may be applied st reruns, except reruns of episodes made within the contract period or option
during which such advances were made.
:G. Other Conditions for Combination Term Contracts
K x-
■ (1)	If a performer employed under a combination term contract
rms, in any single employment week during such term, services in rehearsals ;ordings or before the camera, in both a television motion picture film and a leal motion picture film hereunder, such performer shall receive, as bnal compensation for such week, an amount not less than the applicable
yterin contract minimum.
4'	. -369 -
Schedule E
(2)	If a performer under a combination term contract renders^ services in any single employment week in principal photography in either aj television motion picture or a theatrical motion picture and also renders saw such week in retakes, added scenes, sound track, process shots, transparencies trick shots, trailers, changes or foreign versions of the photoplay (heremaftdl referred to as "retakes, etc."), in the other field, such performer shall be paid^ addition to his weekly term contract salary, one-fifth (1/5) of the minimum [ot contract weekly rates for each day on which he renders services on such rctal^ etc.
(3)	If the performer renders services in any week in both a television motion picture and a theatrical motion picture, he shall be paid as m subsection G. provided, even though he is also placed on layoff at any time^S such week.
(4)	If a performer who is on layoff is recalled for retakes, etc^ either television motion pictures or theatrical motion pictures, or both, he sh^ paid one-fifth (1/5) of the minimum term contract weekly rates for each dayrin each field on which he renders such services.
(5)	If a performer renders services in either a television motion picture or a theatrical motion picture in any week and also renders services^ retakes, etc. in the same week in the other field, and is placed on layoff prior^c end of such week, he shall be paid, in addition to the weekly salary due, an^m equal to one-fifth (1/5) of the minimum term contract weekly rates for eacKdg which he renders services in such retakes, etc.	., J3|
(6)	When a performer employed under a combination term cont renders services in any week in both theatrical motion pictures and television s motion pictures, for the purpose of determining whether Schedule E or Schedm applies and making the computations therein, the performer's weekly salaryjyl for such week shall be deemed to be his aggregate weekly salary, as heremiyjj provided.

SI
O' Pefiniim
j-A "beginner" is defined as:
(1)	A person under the age of thirty (30) with no professional me as a performer prior to a date twelve (12) months before the .encement of the term of his employment and, for such person, chorus work kground actor work, even though he was adjusted as a background actor for mglines, shall not constitute professional experience as a performer; or
(2)	A person thirty (30) years of age or over who has had no jsional experience as a performer prior to the commencement of the term of nployment and, for such person, chorus work or background actor work shall itute professional experience as a performer.
R;
For the purpose of the foregoing definitions, little theatre work jigtbe considered to be professional experience as a performer.
(3)	A person employed as a beginner under a term employment gkc^shail not, for the purpose of the minimum compensation provisions of this zraph, continue to be a beginner under such employment contract after the Bif twelve (12) months from the commencement of the term of such
t contract. If a person has been employed as a beginner under a term toytnent contract, such person may not, after the expiration of twelve (12) msfrom the date of the commencement of the term of such employment [act>be again employed as a beginner by the same or any other Producer ss awaiver is obtained from the Union.

c.
Employment in Television or Theatrical Pictures
A beginner used by Producer in a television motion picture shall be’|' adjusted to the non-beginner’s applicable term contract rates and adjustments, if .§ any, herein provided, for the time he performs such services in such television f motion picture and to the applicable rerun, theatrical, Supplemental Market, basid' cable and foreign telecast rates. v
If Producer uses a beginner in a theatrical motion picture produced by: Producer, or in which Producer has a financial interest, the performer shall remain’ a beginner.
D.
Lpanzfflitg
A beginner loaned-out to a television Producer for a television motion picture in which Producer has no financial interest shall be paid the television freelance rate during the time he performs such services and applicable rerun, <1® theatrical, Supplemental Market, basic cable and foreign telecast rates. Whenhe^ returns to Producer, he returns as a beginner.
A beginner who is loaned-out to a television Producer for a television motion picture in which Producer has a financial interest shall be paid at the weekly rate specified in Section 4 of this Schedule for the time he performs such£ services and applicable rerun, theatrical, Supplemental Market, basic cable and foreign telecast rates. When he returns to Producer, he returns as a beginner.
A beginner loaned-out for a theatrical motion picture remains a beginner during such services.

£7. RATE NOT SPECIFIED
.*4 Whenever this Schedule states that a performer shall receive compensation for work done before he is employed, if he is not employed, and no rate is
^specified in this Schedule, such compensation shall be computed upon the agreed <yate of compensation, if there was such an agreed rate of compensation and, if not, ' upon the performer's established compensation. Disputes between the performer /aid the Producer under this provision are subject to conciliation and arbitration. \
Lt THE PERFORMER’S WORKWEEK: STUDIO FIVE (5) DAY
W WEEK: OVERNIGHT LOCATION WEEK___________________________________
A. Definitions - General
(1)	An "overnight location workweek," as used herein, shall be
■ ‘Seemed to be a workweek consisting of six (6) overnight location days or six (6) /(lays of any combination of studio and overnight location days, which combination ^includes a sixth day overnight location day.
Any workweek other than such an overnight location
i.	workweek, for the purposes of this Section, shall be deemed to be a "studio Lworkweek." The studio workweek shall consist of any five (5) days out of seven »Q7) consecutive days as designated by the Producer on each production unit. The E sixth and seventh days in the designated workweek shall be the regular days off. I® ■
H (2) An "overnight location day, "as used herein, shall be deemed to [igean any of the following days, if the performer is on salary that day, as provided Lin the Basic Agreement:
(a)	Any day spent or worked by the performer on an ^overnight location or on an exploitation tour;
(b)	The day of departure for such location (provided the |performer does not actually work in the studio on such day);
■
&	- 373 -
Schedule E
(c)	The day of return from such location (provided the performer does not actually work in the studio on such day);
(3)	For all purposes, the performer’s weekly base rate shall be hif weekly rate of salary as specified in his contract, the performer’s straight time 4 hourly rate shall be one forty-fourth (1/44) of his weekly base rate.	«
B. Studio Five (5) Day Workweek	S
K
(1)	The performer’s studio workweek shall be a five (5) day workweek.	o
(2)	The regular studio workweek shall be forty-four (44) cumulative hours commencing with the first day of the performer's workweek; p-weekly overtime shall be at one and one-half (114) times the straight time hourly^ rate for hours worked in excess of forty-four (44) hours in such workweek, excepl as otherwise provided in Section 11, entitled "Overtime.*’	-4M
(3)	Work on Six (6) or Seven (7) Days in the Workweek
If the performer works on six (6) or seven (7) days in the 'v workweek and performer is on a studio workweek, he shall, in each case, be^M entitled to premium pay in accordance with the following rules:	4MI
■4!
(i)	The performer shall receive a premium of an additional one-half (14) day of pay for the sixth day worked if the performer works six (6)1 days within a studio workweek. The performer shall receive a premium of an’.*! additional day of pay for the seventh day worked if the performer works seven days within a studio workweek (in addition to the one-half day of premium pay® the sixth day worked in the workweek).
The following are examples of the foregoing:
(1)	If the performer works seven (7) days in his:<jl
workweek, he shall be entitled to an additional two (2) days of pay for work^-B beyond five (5) days plus one and one-half (1 !4) days of premium pay or a totalffl eight and one-half (814) days of pay. Hours worked on such sixth and seveqgtffl -374-	jt 3
Schedule E	£ JB
11 not be included in calculating performer's forty-four (44) hour week and the sr five (5) days in the week will constitute the workweek for such purpose.
(2)	If the performer works six (6) days in his arkweek, he shall be entitled to an additional day of pay for work beyond five [days plus one-half ?/») day of premium pay, or a total of six and one-half (6/2) .ys of pay. Hours worked on such sixth day, to and including ten (10) hours, ail be included in calculating performer's forty-four (44) hour week.
(ii)	Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of ibparagraph (i) above, a sixth day worked on an overnight location shall not be a fa: .	,
tjmum day.
(iii)	For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any sixth or day in a workweek for which the performer receives a premium of
ifc-half (16) day of pay or one (1) day of pay as above provided, the performer all receive double the weekly straight time hourly rate, including overtime used by make-up, hairdress, wardrobe or fittings.
.	(iv) If the time included in calculating the performer's
tty-four (44) hour week, as above provided, exceeds forty-four (44) hours, such cess time shall be paid for in one-tenth (1/10) hour units at the rate of one and ie£half times the weekly straight time hourly rate, or at the rate of straight time to
eJextent the same is caused by make-up, hairdress and wardrobe.
WL’ ■ ■
Overnight Location Six (61 Day Workweek
(1)	The overnight location six (6) day workweek shall be
y-eight (48) cumulative hours, commencing with the first day of the ormer's workweek, which forty-eight (48) hours include an additional four (4)
fs overtime at the straight time hourly rate (whether worked or not).
(2)	If the time included in calculating the performer's forty-eight
hour week, as above provided, exceeds forty-eight (48) hours, such excess §tiali be paid for at the rate of one and one-half times the weekly straight time /■rate, except as otherwise provided in Section 11, entitled "Overtime.”
