5. WORK ON SIX OR SEVEN DAYS IN THE WORKWEEK - SINGLE X PICTURE TELEVISION ENGAGEMENT LESS THAN $50,000 „ 1
A.	The following rules relating to work on six (6) or seven (7) days in . X the workweek shall apply to a performer under this Schedule employed on $ television motion pictures for a single picture erigagement at a guaranteed J compensation of more than $32,000 per television picture but less than $50^000. ..
B.	Studio Five (5) Day Workweek
(1)	The performer's studio workweek shall be a five (5) day
workweek. The studio workweek shall consist of any five (5) days out of seven j (7) consecutive days as designated by the Producer on each production unit. The < sixth and seventh days in the designated workweek shall be the regular days off.
'■	■ J
-429-
Schedule F

if. (2) (i) Work on Six (6) or Seven (7) Days in the Performer’s ^Workweek
H	If a performer works six (6) or seven (7) days in a studio
kworkweek, he shall, in each case, be entitled to premium pay in accordance with rfhe following rules:
The performer shall receive a premium of an additional ^one-half (VS) day of pay if the performer works six (6) days within a studio 'workweek.
|/;	The performer shall receive a premium of an additional
F: oay of pay if the performer works seven (7) days within a workweek (in addition the one-half day of premium pay for the sixth day worked in the workweek).
b?
The following are examples of the foregoing:
if	(A) If the performer works seven (7) days in his
^workweek, he shall be entitled to an additional two (2) days of pay for work ’^beyond five (5) days, plus a premium of one and one-half (1 Yi) additional days of ffipay or J 1,425, whichever is the lesser sum (i.e., eight and one-half (814) days of Ipay, or seven (7) days of pay plus $1,425, whichever is the lesser);
11	(B) If the performer works six (6) days in his
tiworkweek, he shall be entitled to an additional day of pay for work beyond five
(5) days plus a premium of one-half (14) day of additional pay or $475, whichever pj is the lesser sum {i.e., seven and one-half (714) days of pay, or six (6) days of pay | |plus $475, whichever is the lesser).
R;	(ii) Notwithstanding the foregoing, a sixth day worked on an
^overnight location shall not be a premium day. ■
(iii) For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any sixth or ^ seventh day in a workweek for which performer receives a premium as above ^provided, and in the event performer is subject to the overtime provisions of this ^ Schedule F as provided in Section 8, performer shall receive double the straight B time hourly rate provided therein, including overtime caused by make-up,
-430-
Schedule F
hairdress, wardrobe-and fittings, subject, however, to the provisions of Section 8.D.
C.	Overnight Location Six i6) Day Workweek
(1)	The performer's "overnight location workweek," as above defined, shall be a six (6) day workweek.
(2)	(i) Work on Seven (7) Days in the Performer's Workweek .
If the performer works on seven (7) days in an overnight location workweek, he shall receive an additional day of pay for work beyond six (6) days plus one (1) day of premium pay or $950, whichever is the lesser sum (i.e., eight (8) days of pay, or seven (7) days of pay plus $950, whichever is the lesser).
(ii)	For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any seventh day, for which performer receives a premium as above provided, and in the event performer is subject to the overtime provisions of this Schedule F as provided in Section 8, performer shall receive double the straight time hourly rate provided therein, including overtime caused by make-up, hairdress, wardrobe and fittings, subject, however, to the provisions of Section 8.D.
D.	Shift in Workweek
Once during the production of a motion picture, or in the case of episodic television, once between hiatus periods (i.e., between the commencement or resumption of production and a cessation of principal photography for the series for at least one week), the Producer may shift the workweek for performers without incurring extra costs, by adding one (1) or two (2) days off consecutive with the sixth and/or seventh days off in the prior workweek and/or by shifting a workweek commencing on a Tuesday to a workweek commencing on a Monday, provided that the intervening Sunday is a day off.
If the Producer otherwise shifts the workweek such that the new workweek invades the preceding workweek, the Producer shall pay the premium for the sixth and/or seventh day worked of the preceding workweek.
-431 -
Schedule F
The performer shall be advised of any shift in the workweek prior to commencement of that workweek.
E.	Recall on the Sixth or Seventh Day in a Workweek
If the performer is recalled on a day that is the sixth or seventh day worked in the performer's workweek for retakes, added scenes, etc., the premium for work on such days shall not exceed $950.
F.	No Compounding
There shall be no compounding of any premium provided by this Section and the penalty or premium prescribed by Section 9 of this Schedule insofar as such Section relates to the thirty-six (36) hour, fifty-six (56) or fifty-four (54) hour rest period, or Section 6 of this Schedule.
G.	Union Branches
Any area in which the Union maintains a branch shall be deemed a five (5) day workweek area for performers employed in such area, when principal photography for a feature is substantially photographed in such area. The scope of such areas is defined in General Provisions, Section 14, entitled "Preference of Employment."
H.	Rooms on Overnight Locations
Performers transported to overnight locations shall be provided separate rooms unless such rooms are not available.
o

■

ipatipn in the receipts, revenues or profits of a motion picture shall be paid paired overtime at the time of employment; provided, however, such pier, may agree in such contract that the overtime payments so made may be fcd against such participations when and if received by the performer.
■
Twelve (12) Hour Rest Period
• J.
The performer shall be entitled to a twelve (12) hour consecutive rest dfrom the time he is finally dismissed until his first call thereafter, whether ake-up, wardrobe, hairdress or any other purpose. However, for a performer iyed on a theatrical motion picture, the rest period may be reduced to eleven lours on any two (2) non-consecutive days in an overnight location week: p
Thirty-Six (36) Hour Rest Period
The performer shall be entitled to one (1) rest period in each week of £.six(36) consecutive hours; provided, however, that if the performer is not jedjto work on the twenty-four (24) hours constituting the first day of any jKpk and has not worked for Producer during the twelve (12) hours aiiateiy preceding such day, or if the performer is not required to work on the fcfour (24) hours constituting the last day of any workweek and does not KKthe Producer during the twelve (12) hours immediately succeeding such Emthe thirty-six (36) hour rest period requirement shall be satisfied jgsspf the fact that twelve (12) hours thereof may be in the preceding or E&g .week. When the performer works on seven (7) days in any week and Epaddition to his base pay, an extra day of pay therefor, the performer got Iw given a thirty-six (36) hour rest period for such week, but must ^to receive his twelve (12) hour rest periods.
*
Fifty-Six (56) Hour Rest Period
■tjp-When the performer is given two (2) consecutive days off during a ■workweek, the thirty-six (36) consecutive hour rest period shall be
KW	- 438 -
Schedule F
increased to fifty-six (56) consecutive hours. However, when there is night shooting consisting primarily of exterior photography and the performer's callW not earlier than 3:00 p.m, and he is dismissed in the studio at or before midni[ on Friday, such fifty-six (56) hour rest period, if otherwise applicable, may reduced to fifty-four (54) hours.
In lieu of the fifty-six (56) hour rest period, the performer may be'E given a fifty-four (54) hour rest period when the call time for the first day of the workweek following the rest period is not earlier than 6:00 a.m.
■ :■$
D. The above provisions regarding the rest period shall be subject to following exceptions:
(1)	When the Producer is photographing on a location other tha an overnight location, the twelve (12) hour rest period may be reduced to teri'(' hours if exterior photography is required on such location on the day before the day after such reduced rest period. When such reduction is allowed oh anydj by reason of exterior photography on a nearby location, it may not be again allowed until after three (3) consecutive days have intervened.
(2)	When a performer arrives at his place of lodging on an j overnight location after 9:00 p.m. and does not work that night, the rest period; with respect to the first call following such arrival may be ten (10) hours insi twelve (12) hours, but the first call must be at the place of lodging.
(3)	When more than one (1) night of travel (by ordinary m transportation) is required to reach a location and the performer is given a b a boat or train for each night of traveling, the time spent in such traveling, to from such location, shall not be work time or travel time for the purpose of-Ji computing the twelve (12) hour rest period.
(4)	When an overnight trip to or from a location is required; the same takes at least seven (7) hours to reach, and the performer is given aitf on a boat or train, or if the performer elects to travel by first-class plane | accommodations, the time spent in such traveling to or from such location Sial not be work time or travel time for the purpose of computing the twelve" (I^Ik rest period.	' ;
(5)	The first call’at the lodging for work (including make-up, irdress, wardrobe or travel) determines the time of first call for the next day for »purpose of computing the rest penod.
< E. The performer may waive the rest period without the Union's consent, mtlif he does so, he shall be entitled to one (1) day of pay or $950, whichever is lesser sum. A performer may be required to waive the rest penod if the jolation, in the case of the twelve (12) hour rest period, is not over two and one-
(2'A) hours or, on an overnight location, not over two (2) hours. The former may, in any case, be required to waive the thirty-six (36) hour or fifty-x(56) (or fifty-four (54)) hour rest period. In any case in which the performer waives either rest period, the payment of one (1) day of pay, not exceeding $950, shall be automatically incurred. The payment may not be waived without the
t of the Union.
"4 F. Whenever it is provided in this Schedule that there shall be no pounding of any premium pay and the payment for breach of the thirty-six 6),hour or fifty-six (56) (or fifty-four (54)) hour rest period, it is expressly tood that the eleven (11) or twelve (12) hour rest period between calls, and payment for violation thereof, remains in effect.
I . .
... Any performer who is required to travel by air in excess of four (4) doled hours to a location may not be called for work without a ten (10) hour ^period. The ten (10) hour rest period shall commence from the time of arrival hotel, provided the performer goes directly to the hotel designated by the tucer. Failure to provide such ten (10) hours constitutes a rest period ation. ■	.	-•

Allowable meal periods shall not be counted as work time for any
A meal period shall not be less than one-half fA) hour nor more than one iourin length. The performer's first meal period shall commence within six lours following the time of his first call for the day; succeeding meal periods jesaine performer shall commence within six (6) hours after the end of the xding meal period. not to be a scheduled grace period, prior to imposition of any meal penalty, J provided that the six (6) hour period between meals has not been extended as’O permitted by the following sentence. If, upon the expiration of such six (6) houq period, the camera is in the actual course of photography, it shall not be a violatia to complete such photography. If, on location or while traveling to or from 1; 1 location, the delay is not due to any fault or negligence of the Producer or its1 agents or persons employed by it to render the catering service by contract, orif* delay is caused by common carriers such as railroads, there shall be no penaltyfo! violation of the above provisions. If the caterer is chosen carefully, and is delayei in reaching the location beyond the required time for commencing a meal period^ there shall be no penalty for the violation; but if such delay shall continue beyord one-half (14) hour, work shall cease and the time intervening between such yM cessation of work and the meat period shall be work time.
The performer shall be entitled to a non-deductible meal appropriate to the time of day of fifteen (15) minutes in duration within two (2) hours of the 1 performer's call time, during which performer will be freed of all activity. Ifthel performer is given a non-deductible meal, a notation indicating the start and'finis time of the meal shall be made on the production report. The first deductible'mea period shall commence within six (6) hours of the end of such non-deductiblr< j
meal.

If, by reason of a long make-up, wardrobe or hairdress period of performer, application of the rule would require a meal period for such perforin^ at a time earlier than that required for the rest of the set, Producer shall not lx required to call such meal period if food, such as coffee and sandwiches, is made available to such performer before the time for his set call, it being understood no deduction shall be made from work time for such period; it is further <	]
understood, however, that such performer shall be given a meal period within six (6) hours from the time such food is made available to the performer: 41’ I

13. TOURS AND PERSONAL APPEARANCES
A. As to all term contract performers under this Schedule F, if the performer is not working in a picture, he shall receive a day of pay at straig for each day, including travel days, in which he is engaged in tours or pers appearances.
B.	First-class transportation and reasonable expenses shall be paid performers on tours and personal appearances.
C. Producer shall cooperate to ensure that performers on tour af personal appearances are allowed adequate rest periods.
D. One personal appearance of any such performer requested by Producer in connection with the opening of any picture in which such perfc has performed, one rehearsal in connection therewith and any period imine prior thereto which otherwise would not be work time, shall not be workhr any purpose. Personal appearances requested of any such performer bythe Producer in connection with any benefit approved by the Theatre Aut! ** so long as the same has the sanction of the Union, or by any similar agenoj substituted therefor which at the time has the sanction of the Union, ret connection therewith and any period immediately prior thereto which otfre would not be work time, shall not be work time for any purpose.

a
Playoff for a contract performer shall be for at least one (1) consecutive object to recall for retakes and added scenes as more particularly provided of this Schedule. If the unused portion of any layoff shall be less i((l) week, such unused layoff may be availed of by the Producer at any ■billy in one (1) consecutive period.
er &
I Services Which Break the Layoff
S: The rendition by a performer of any of the following services shall ^layoff; Principal photography, including recording and rehearsals in cm therewith; auditions; tests; story, song and production conferences at the request of the Producer; publicity stills connected with which are made at the request of the Producer; fittings; hairdress; wardrobe; and radio and personal appearances made at the direction of ijeer. Training or coaching of the performer shall break the layoff unless a granted therefor; the Union agrees, upon the request of the performer, to t such waivers.

ScheduleF
terms of an in
. When the performer has had less than one (1) week of layoff pf the commencement of such services, the performer shall be deemed not to Ha.’ been on layoff and his regular salary shall continue to accrue during the. intervening period. When the performer has had a week or more of layoff^ commencing any of such services, then the performer shall be placed on the time of commencing such services unless the Union has agreed to issue, waiver therefor.	*
B.‘ Services Which Do Not Break the Layoff
(1)	A performer may be required to render services in retake^ added scenes while on layoff, and such services shall not be deemed to interg break the layoff; however, the performer shall be entitled to pay at one-six of his weekly rate for the day or days upon which he renders such services.
X ■■ ■ •
(2)	A performer may be requested to render the following^ which shall not break the layoff: Submission of scripts to the performer at studio or elsewhere; publicity interviews and publicity stills in connection^ therewith; fashion stills; consultation on proposed hairdress, make-up, anti wardrobe; "music voice key;" and radio or personal appearances not made direction of the Producer. The performer shall not be entitled to any co
for rendering the services enumerated in this subsection (2).

may not be changed to the detriment of the performer by the employment contract without the approval of the Union.
18.	REHEARSAL TIME
A. The reading of lines, acting, singing or dancing, in prep performer’s performance, in the presence and under the supervision qfaj representative of Producer, constitutes a rehearsal. Rehearsals shall be
work time, except that as to deal performers, this shall be a matter of
bargaining.

-445-
-446-
Schedule F


Auditions, tests, interviews, make-up and wardrobe tests do not tute rehearsals.
.6: .The Union agrees to freely grant waivers for the training of a pier in a particular skill such as horseback riding, fencing, etc.
sation, if any, shall be agreed to between the performer and the Producer, to the approval of the Union.
Neither tests, auditions, fittings, publicity stills, pre-production stills, nor training under subsection C. above, after employment but the starting date of such employment, shall start the employment period of erformer. Compensation, if any, for any of such services shall be as age provided in this Schedule,
Eqmmercials
All commercials shall be bargained for separately by the performer under the terms of the industry-wide Screen Actors Guild Contract in effect at the time of such bargaining.
Employment agreements in effect on July 1,2001 shall be excluded ^foregoing provision and shall be governed by the Television Agreement 'tyhen such employment contract was entered into.

|	SCHEDULE G-I
. PROFESSIONAL SINGERS EMPLOYED BY THE DAY
Jl. definitions
I
A. Professional Singer
'M	A professional singer is a person who is employed primarily to sing
^either as a solo or in a group requiring unison or harmony. Non-professional ^singing, such as by background actors, is excluded from this definition. A ^professional singer is herein referred to as a singer.
Fl B, The provisions of this Schedule shall not apply to a person who is O'employed either as a day performer, freelance performer, contract performer, mnultiple picture performer or deal performer.
Ifi. SCHEDULE G-I INCLUDED IN INDIVIDUAL CONTRACTS
H The provisions of this Schedule shall be deemed incorporated in the ^individual contract of employment between Producer and each singer covered ^hereunder; the Producer and the individual singer shall each be bound thereby.
gl MINIMUM WAGE
R

C.	Step-Out Category
(I)	If a solo or duo is called upon to step out of a group to to fifteen (15) cumulative bars during a session, he (they) shall be paid an adjustment of fifty percent (50%) of the solo/duo rate in addition to tlie^
appropriate group rate for that day.

t J id "tl
It
1
(2)	If a solo or duo is called upon to step out of a group to sing |(16) or more cumulative bars, or remain more than one (1) hour after the tasbeen released, to perform a solo or duo of any length, he (they) shall be g$ull solo/duo rate in addition to the appropriate group rate for that day.
Ej% (3) Any member of a group who steps out to perform as part of a ggioup to sing over four (4) consecutive bars shall be paid at the smaller reefer that day. Such re-classification shall not operate to reduce the size j|e|ill group with respect to fees payable to the remainder of the group.

B; W-4 forms shall be available on every set. It shall be the performer’s ty to return a completed W-4 form to Producer in a timely manner. It gstood that when a performer fails to do so, there shall be no retroactive gmts to die withholding required by law. W-4 forms shall be attached to rfprmer contracts.

SCHEDULE G-n
PROFESSIONAL SINGERS EMPLOYED BY THE WEEK ON | TELEVISION MOTION PICTURES AT $4,400 OR LESS PER WEEK ’
PROFESSIONAL SINGERS EMPLOYED BY THE WEEK ON THEATRICAL MOTION PICTURES AT $5,500 OR LESS PER WEEK’U

DEFINITION
A.	Professional Singer
A professional singer is a person who is employed primarily to sing1 either as a solo or in a group requiring unison or harmony. Non-professional singing, such as by background actors, is excluded from this definition. A professional singer is herein referred to as a singer.
B.	The provisions of this Schedule shall not apply to a person who is employed either as a day performer, freelance performer, contract performer, multiple picture performer or deal performer.
2.
SCHEDULE G-II INCLUDED IN INDIVIDUAL CONTRACTS
The provisions of this Schedule shall be deemed incorporated in the individual contract of employment between Producer and each singer covered hereunder employed by the week on television motion pictures at $4,400 or less per week and who is guaranteed less than $32,000 per television picture and in the-: individual contract of employment between Producer and each singer covered hereunder employed by the week on theatrical motion pictures at $5,500 or less per week and who is guaranteed less than $60,000 per theatrical picture ($65,000^?
per theatrical picture with respect to contracts entered into on or after January 1 / 
2002); the Producer and the individual singer shall each be bound thereby.
W-4 forms shall be presented to performer no later than the first day of employment. A W-4 form may be given to performer on the set on the first day of$; employment.
-468 -
Schedule G-II
® W-4 forms shall be available on every set. It shall be the performer's sponsibility to return a completed W-4 form to Producer in a timely manner. It understood that when a performer fails to do so, there shall be no retroactive ijustments to the withholding required by law. W-4 forms shall be attached to ree-day performer contracts.
MIWIMXM5ALABX£ER3IEEK

Groups 9 or more	1,841	1,896	1,962

g	Sweetening with or without overdubbing (per day) an additional one
jhundred percent (100%) of the pro rata daily rate.
i ■ Overdubbing only (per day) an additional thirty-three and one-third percent (33-1/3%) of the pro rata daily rate.

C.	A singer called out of a choral group and required to sing five (5) Van or more shall be paid an additional sum of $39 ($40 effective July 1, 2002 and $41 effective July 1, 2003) for that day.	;

group to sing over four (4) consecutive bars shall be paid at the smaller group fee’; for that day. Such reclassification shall not operate to reduce the size of the . overall group with respect to fees payable to the remainder of the group. S <
4.	’’CONSECUTIVE EMPLOYMENT" AND "RIGHT TO THE ROLE’’.;
N-QT APPLICABLE____________________________________________
Singers employed by the week are not entitled to consecutive employment^ nor to the right to the role, it being agreed that such singers may be subsequently'; used in the picture without payment of compensation for intervening time.
5.	QNE (1) WEEK GUARANTEE - RE-EMPLOYMENT	Jj
A.	The initial period of employment will be one (1) week in duration, ^; subject to suspension or earlier termination as provided in Section 11 of this Schedule. The employment of such singer may be terminated at any time after the initial week. Any period beyond one (1) week may be prorated on a daily basis.;
-470-
Schedule G-n
FIVE (5) MINUTE BREAKS
B.	Any such singer employed by the week may be subsequently loyed in the same picture on a weekly basis pursuant to the terms of this chedule, with an initial period of such re-employment of one (1) week, or on a ly basis pursuant to the provisions of Schedule G-I.
6.| PHONOGRAPH RECORDS AND TAPE
There shall be separate bargaining at the time of employment between a finger and Producer for the use of sound track on phonograph records or tape; otherwise, such rights may not be acquired. Singers' contracts for phonograph r cbrds or tape recordings shall contain a separate clause to be initialed at the time f employment providing for the use of sound track on records or tape recordings to be not less than the AFTRA rate.
Singers shall be given a five (5) minute rest period in each hour of recording.
■8. AVAILABILITY FOR RECALL AFTER EMPLOYMENT
£ The Producer may not agree with any specialty singer that the specialty tiger will hold himself available for any day after the termination of an original od of employment unless the Producer agrees at the same time to employ the ty singer for such day. It is agreed, however, that the specialty singer may recalled by the Producer and will report, at any time prior to the completion of
production of the photoplay for which he was originally employed, on the same sms and conditions (except as to the original term of employment), provided that he is not then otherwise employed.
-471-
Schedule G-n
9.	RETAKES. ADDED SCENES. ETC,
A singer employed by the week may be recalled by the Producer and su singer will report for services in connection with retakes, added scenes, chang sound track, process shots, transparencies, trick shots, trailers, foreign version and mouthing to playback of the singer's own voice. Compensation shall be p to the singer only for the day or days on which he is actually so employed. If 1 services are commenced within four (4) months (six (6) months for theatrical.1 motion pictures, pilots or long-form television motion pictures (including multi part closed-end series) after the prior termination of employment, compensatiq therefor shall be at the daily rate originally agreed upon.
The performer's contract shall not include guarantees for looping, retakest added scenes, process transparencies, trick shots, trailers, changes or foreign < versions (subject to availability) outside the period of consecutive employment^
10.	SPECIALTY SINGERS - USE OF RECORDING; USE OF PHOTOGRAPHY IN OTHER PHOTOPLAYS___________________________
This Section shall apply only to a specialty singer, defined as a singer employed for a solo or employed as a part of a "name1’ group.
A.	If any part of the recording by any specialty singer of any individual
song or other musical composition be included by the Producer in any photoplay f (as finally cut and released), in connection with the production of which‘such recording was obtained, the Producer shall not thereafter include in any other photoplay or photoplays or make any other use of any part of the photography such singer accompanying such recording of that particular song or musical	f
composition, or use, in connection with any other photoplay or photoplays, or otherwise, the name of such singer in connection with such recording; but the aforesaid limitations upon the use of such singer’s name shall not apply to any 4 other photoplay or photoplays in connection with which such singer is employed^ to perform additional services, nor shall the aforesaid limitations be deemed to limit the right of the Producer to include all or any part of such recording in any -ft other photoplay or photoplays if no part of the photography of such singer < accompanying such recording be included therein and (provided such singer be J
- 472 -
Schedule G-II
at employed in connection with such other photoplay) if the name of such singer hot used in connection with such recording. If no part of the recording by any singer of any individual song or other musical composition be included by ^Producer in the photoplay (as finally cut and released) in connection with the reduction of which such recording was obtained, then in such event, the Producer Behave either of the following options:
(1)	The Producer may include in any other photoplay all or any gt of such recording of that particular song or musical composition together with ^photography of the singer accompanying such recording and may use, in section therewith, the name of the singer; but in such event, the Producer may include any part of such recording of that particular song or musical imposition or any photography accompanying the same in any other photoplay or dfotoplays, or make any other use thereof; or
E.*.*T,.
(2)	The Producer may use all or any part of the recording of such individual song or other musical composition in any other photoplay or photoplays font not otherwise), but may not then or thereafter use for any purpose any potography of such singer accompanying the same, and may not use the name of ’such singer in connection with any such use of the recording or otherwise; but the aforesaid limitation upon the use of the singer's name shall not apply to any other (photoplay or photoplays in connection with which such singer is employed to ■perform additional services.
B.
.	The Producer's rights in and to any such recording and in and
kip the photography of any such singer accompanying any such recording, and in ^and to the use of such singer's name and likeness in connection therewith, shall not kbe limited or qualified by this Section nor the Codified Basic Agreement of 2001, [except as expressly provided. All or any of the aforesaid limitations may be ^waived by the Union at any time and from time to time. With respect to the photoplay in which the photography and recording is authorized to be used by the | foregoing provisions hereof, the Producer shall have the right to produce, [reproduce, transmit, exhibit, distribute and exploit any and all of the singer's acts, t.poses, plays and appearances of any and all kinds and shall have the right to ^record, reproduce, transmit, exhibit and exploit in connection with the photoplay singer’s voice and all instrumental, musical and other sound effects produced bhy the singer in connection with such acts, poses, plays and appearances. In 1

connection withany photoplay in which the Producer is authorized to use solely^ the recordings of the singer as above provided, the Producer shall have the right record, reproduce, transmit, exhibit, distribute and exploit the singer's voice and & all instrumental, musical and other sound effects produced by the singer in	I5
connection with such recording, but without the use of the singer’s name or	,X'
photography except with respect to the singer’s name when the singer is again .3/ employed as above provided. The term ’’photoplay," as used above, shall be | ; deemed to include motion pictures (not including so-called "slot machine movies^ produced and/or exhibited with sound or voice recording, reproducing and/or.. transmitting devices, radio devices and all other improvements and devices, 3 including television, which are now or hereafter may be used in connection with^ the production and/or exhibition and/or transmission of any present or future kindp of motion picture production. Whenever the Producer, under the foregoing, has’T the right to use the singer's name, the Producer shall likewise have the right to use.\ and give publicity to the singer's name and likeness, photographic or otherwise, > and to recordations and reproductions of the singer’s voice and all instrumental, »!;■ musical and other sound effects produced by the singer in connection with the Jw advertising and exploitation of said photoplay. The rights in this Section granted! to the Producer shall inure to the benefit not only of the Producer but also to the < benefit of all persons who may hereafter acquire from the Producer any right to 51 distribute, transmit, exhibit, advertise or exploit said photoplay.	;
B.	Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein contained, the rights^ hereinbefore granted to the Producer to use the photography of any such singer accompanying any recording by such singer of any individual song or other . j musical composition or his name in a photoplay, other than the photoplay in connection with the production of which such recording was obtained, may not exercised unless there shall be included in or endorsed upon such singer's employment contract or confirmation of employment, and separately signed or initialed by such singer, a statement in the following form:
"The singer realizes that as to any individual song or recording not used in the photoplay for which the singer is employed, the Producer may use the recording thereof forever in other photoplays, or may use the recording, name and photography thereof . in other photoplays (so long as no part is used twice) without additional compensation to the singer."

EMERGENCY SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION
Producer may terminate the employment of a singer employed by the week tfor any of the following reasons: If the production of the photoplay specified in :tfie singer's contract be necessarily prevented, suspended or postponed during the 'course of production, by reason of fire, accident, strike, riot, act of God or of the .public enemy, any executive or judicial order, illness of any other member of the
ist or of the director, or the disability, failure or default of such singer. In the rent that such singer's employment be terminated prior to the expiration of the rat week of the singer's term of employment for any of the above-named reasons her than the disability, failure or default of such singer, such singer shall be
■entitled to the balance of his first week of compensation. In the event of termination by reason of the disability, failure or default of such singer, the producer shall be obligated to pay such singer the balance, if any, that is then impaid for services theretofore rendered, and the Producer shall be discharged of id from any and all liability whatsoever under said contract.
It shall be the duty of the Producer, during the first week of any such ition, suspension or postponement, to notify the singer in writing whether je Producer will entirely discontinue the production or further suspend or postpone it.
% " '
M. RESUMED PRODUCTION AFTER TERMINATION
>%■ If the Producer has elected to terminate or suspend a singer's employment 'under a weekly contract pursuant to its rights under Section 11 of this Schedule, ,;and the Producer shall desire to resume the production of said photoplay, the ■ Producer shall notify the singer of its election to so resume and, in such event, the ■'singer agrees to render his services in connection with such resumed production as gid when the Producer may request, unless the singer is otherwise employed, but if otherwise employed, the singer will cooperate to the fullest extent in trying to ‘make his services available to the Producer in connection with such resumed production. If production is resumed within six (6) months from the date of 'termination, the singer's compensation shall be at a daily rate equal to one-sixth ;(i/6) of the weekly rate specified in the singer’s original employment contract and I

2.	DAILYRATEjQF COMPENSATION^ ADDITIONAL p/cp
A.	Except as provided in subsection B. hereof in the case dfpreg pay, and except for a waiver of the twelve (12) hour rest period, whenev^ weekly stunt performer is entitled to an additional day of pay, this shaft ng fifth (1/5) of his weekly base rate plus an amount equal to the aggregate^ additional amounts, if any, payable to him for stunts performed by hirnciitf such day.	.
B.	Whenever a weekly stunt performer is entitled to prenuum|)l premium pay shall be an amount equal to one-fifth (1/5) of his aggregat^ adjusted weekly compensation, in the event performer is on a studio'.workv one-sixth (1/6) of his aggregate or adjusted weekly compensation, in .the a performer is on an overnight location workweek, except in those instances which the amount of premium pay is limited to a maximum of $950^^
W-4 forms shall be presented to performer no later thau^fe@ of employment. A W-4 form may be given to performer on the set omthem of employment.
W-4 forms shall be available on every set. It shall be the performer’s isibility to return a completed W-4 form to Producer in a timely manner. It erstood that when a performer fails to do so, there shall be no retroactive merits to the withholding required by law. W-4 forms shall be attached to ^'performer contracts.

NANCIAL AGREEMENT
phe stunt performer and the Producer shall agree upon the compensation to id ib such performer for the stunt before it is performed, except that the oing rule shall not apply in those instances in which the stunt is performed on Uidh where no ready means of communication is available between the the offices of the Union and the Producer, In the instance last jpned, the parties shall agree upon the compensation to be paid before the Hs performed if they may readily do so; however, it is expressly agreed that Ktion shall not be delayed for the purpose of first determining the jnsation for a stunt.
is
miEjSQT SPECIFIED
^Whenever this Schedule states that a performer shall receive compensation ffirk’done before he is employed, if he is not employed, and no rate is Bed in this Schedule, such compensation shall be computed upon the agreed ^compensation, if there was such an agreed rate of compensation and, if not, ghe performer's established compensation. Disputes between the performer ^ Producer under this provision are subject to conciliation and arbitration.
’ft
IAL PERIOD OF EMPLOYMENT - PRORATING SALARY.
ieiffi
tin the case of a stunt performer employed by the week, the initial period of »yment must be at least a week in duration. Whenever it is necessary to &tbe’ workweek in order to determine an additional day of pay, such frig shall be on the basis of one-fifth (1/5) of the performer's weekly base nr either the studio or overnight location workweek; however, such proration
F
shall not in any manner change the performer's weekly base rate for eithe studio or the overnight location workweek.	.
With respect to prorating the performer’s workweek for the purpos paying the performer at the end of a payroll week, that portion of perforri studio workweek which is part of such payroll week shall be prorated on of one-fifth (1/5) of the weekly base rate for each such day (excluding-thr^ and seventh days in the workweek) in that payroll week. This is exclusiv overtime or premium pay, if any, due in such performer’s workweek. ^ "
6.
"CONSECUTIVE EMPLOYMENT" AND "RIGHT TO
WHERE APPLICABLE______________________
1 3?

Schedule H - Part HI
8. ADDITIONAL S’]
W
WORK
In the event stunt work is required by Producer beyond that which was agreed to by the stunt performer, the stunt performer shall have the right to negotiate additional compensation for the additional work required.
’■SB
A. Change? Required Ptipr to Performance
If such required change occurs prior to the photography of the stunt,. the stunt performer shall advise the Producer, before the stunt in question is photographed, if the performer wishes to negotiate additional compensation for additional work required. Such negotiation may occur either before or after. s performance of the stunt; however, it is expressly agreed that the production shall' not be delayed for the purpose of first determining the compensation for the stunt/J :,\Y A"
B. Changes Required During Performance
If the Producer requires a change during the photography of a stunt,-? z the stunt performer shall advise the Producer at the earliest reasonable time after completion of such stunt that he wishes to negotiate additional compensation for j.-the additional work and shall have the right to so negotiate such additional compensation after the stunt is photographed.
C. Applicability to Other Schedules

The foregoing provisions relating to additional stunt work shall be
applicable to Schedule A and B performers.

STUNT EERFORMERS -SANITARY WARDROBE
%
For scripted stunts, stunt performers shall not be required to wear wardrobe that has not been properly cleaned after prior use by another person.

DEFINITION
SCHEDULE I
AIRPLANE PILOTS


A. An airline pilot is a licensed aircraft pilot who is employed to tax aircraft (including helicopters) before the camera in the photographing, motion pictures.	i
B. The Union recognizes that it does not have jurisdiction over background actor work except to the extent provided under Schedule X,y Schedule X, Part II, in the zones described in Section 1(d) of Schedule and in Section 1 of Schedule X, Part II, and the provisions of this Schei only be construed as relating to acting work, and shall not apply to the background actors in aircraft, whether simulating the pilot or otherwise?
2.

terms, conditions and exceptions of this Schedule.

4.	RATE NOT SPECIFIED - EXTREMELY HAZARDOUS FLYDi
The compensation hereinabove provided shall include all types ofjfl| excepting only that which has customarily been classified in the motion^ industry as extremely hazardous. For extremely hazardous flying, the pilote Producer shall agree upon the compensation to be paid to such pilot beforeg work is performed, if they may readily do so; however, it is expresslyagrea production stall not be delayed for the purpose of first determining the compensation for such work. In the event that the parties have not agreedjtf the particular compensation to be paid for the work before the same has be® performed, then the matter shall be settled by conciliation between the^Prdffl and the Union by determining the compensation which has theretofore;been customarily paid in the industry for such work. In the event that the.niatta| be settled by conciliation, the compensation will be determined by arbitral the manner provided by Section 9 of the General Provisions hereof.

payment for the day in the example given of $1,653.86.

SCHEDULE J
dancers
1. SCOPE OF COVERAGE
V--"
This Schedule J shall be applicable only to persons employed as" dancers, as that term is hereinafter defined.	I
2.
aid
[TION

A "dancer" is a performer who is professionally-trained, doing

choreographed routines requiring rehearsals, such as ballet, chorus dancing, .: [ modem dance, tap dancing, jazz dancing, acrobatic dancing or skating. Exhibition level dancing is also included. Persons engaged to execute the choreographers dance directions during the development of dance routines of the nature describe above are dancers within the meaning of this Schedule, whether or not such 1
persons are photographed in the production.

3. Ml
MM

c. Rehearsal Rates
For rehearsals, dancers may either be employed on a weekly basis, as 'provided above, or at a daily rate of $374.00 per day ($385.00 per day effective ’ ly 1,2002 and $398.00 per day effective July 1, 2003).

AND OTHER SCHEDULES __________________________

! GENERAL CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT
fc
v The following shall apply to dancers if they are employed under this hedule:
-546-
Schcdule J
A.	"Dancers" shall include swimmers and skaters when the perfoi is choreographed.
J'
B.	The compensation payable to a dancer for a hazardous activity^ be $65 per day, with a minimum of $ 100 if only one (1) day's services is rend "Wire flying" shall in all instances be considered "hazardous.’’ '
C.	. Footwear provided by the Producer shall be appropriate to the wi and shall be clean, properly fitted, braced and rubbered.
Any dancer who is directed to and reports with his or her own/;, footwear shall be paid an allowance of $10. utilized in the performance.
80 per day for each pair of shoes
D.	Industry standards for dancers include adequate warm-up are^^ surfaces free and clean of debris and materials, adequate rest periods, and otKe such precautions as may be necessary to ensure the health and safety of dancers in light of the nature of the work performed.
(I)	Floors for Rehearsal Halls and Stages	$
'S.
Except when conditions are otherwise required for a scene:£ (a) Surfaces should be clean and free of splinters, wax, nails, and (b) floors ’’
be swept and mopped at least daily with a germ-killing solution.
(2)	Warm-up Spaces
Adequate space must be provided to permit all dancers to wan up (perform limbering exercises) thirty (30) minutes, at the beginning of the day;: (non-work time), prior to dancing.
(3)	Breaks
Dancers will have at least ten (10) minutes rest during each hour of actual rehearsal or shooting unless shooting is of a continuous nature. ID so, at the choreographer's discretion, dancers may continue until a total of ninety/ (90) minutes has elapsed after which a fifteen (15) minute break must be called!^
-547-
ScheduleJ
[	(4) Emergency treatment
&	A person or facility located in the general geographical area
^'qualified under the circumstances to provide medical care on an emergency ms shall be identified and such information shall be made available to dancers at [rehearsals and performances.
(5)	Safety of Equipment
Producers shall exercise care, including prior testing of [uipmcnt (breakaway props, etc.) to avoid injury to the performer.
(6)	Dancers doing knee work, including rolling, spinning, falling, jancing, hinging, walking, turning and/or performing a choreographed routine Fthe knees will be permitted to wear knee pads when practicable in rehearsal and rfcrmance.
r E. Dance rehearsals which are held in rehearsal halls shall be conducted (surfaces which are resilient.
F. For dancers engaged as assistant choreographers, Producer shall make ntributions to the Pension and Health Funds on the accounts of such individuals ho have had prior contributions made in five (5) out of the last ten (10) years as iicers.

SCHEDULE K INCLUDED IN INDIVIDUAL CONTRACTS
Ek. The provisions of this Schedule shall apply to stunt coordinators employed ^the day at less than the "flat deal" minimum (specified in Schedule K, Part IH) gimotion pictures covered by this Agreement. Such provisions shall be deemed hcbrporated in the individual contract of employment between Producer and each coordinator employed by the day at less than the "flat deal" minimum; the coducer and the individual coordinator shall each be bound thereby.

The minimum wage for a stunt coordinator employed by the day shall be 36.00 per day for the period July 1,2001 through June 30,2002; $655.00 per |ibr the period July 1, 2002 through June 30,2003; and $678.00 for the period |Ti, 2003 through June 30, 2004.
^ENGAGEMENT - DELIVERY OF CONTRACT
KK A stunt coordinator shall be considered definitely engaged in any of ^following events:
BF (1) When the coordinator is given written notice of acceptance;
(2)	When a form contract signed by Producer is delivered to ggmtor or when an unsigned contract is delivered by Producer to coordinator mfeiecuted by coordinator as so delivered and returned to Producer, or K-
(3)	When the coordinator is actually called by the Producer and iggsto report on the commencement date for which the call is given; however,
K	‘ 553 ‘
KI	Schedule K - Pan I
-552-
Schedule K - Part I
until noon of the day preceding such commencement date, either the Produc^ the coordinator may cancel such employment. If the Producer is unable tore; the coordinator personally, either by telephone or otherwise, notice of such * cancellation may be given to the coordinator by telegraph, in which evem thc when such telegram is given by the Producer to the telegraph company, addn to the coordinator at his address last known to the Producer, shall be thejM® such cancellation.
Neither auditions nor interviews shall constitute an engagement^ It is agreed that a stunt coordinator hired and not used is entitle^
B.
C.
one (1) day of pay, or his guarantee, whichever is greater.
D.	W-4 forms shall be presented to coordinator no later than the^fig
of employment. A W-4 form may be given to coordinator on the set on theft
day of employment.

W-4 forms shaft be available on every set'. It shall be the coordinator's responsibility to return a completed W-4 form to Producer irra timely manner. It is understood that when a coordinator fails to do so, theng be no retroactive adjustments to the withholding required by law. W-4fqrrn be attached to day coordinator and three-day coordinator contracts. . fr; * *
4.
HOURS FER DAY

The work day shall be an eight (8) hour day, continuous from the-f except for allowable meal periods.	,
If the coordinator is working at midnight of any day, then his hpurs c for such day shall be computed until the coordinator has been dismissed.;..J subsequent to midnight, subject to all exceptions and deductions provided! this Schedule. Hours of work for the following day shall, except as otHer^ provided in this Schedule, be computed from the time the coordinator,-ufto been so dismissed subsequent to midnight, is required to and does report^

jf BAILY CHECK FOR STUNT COORDINATORS
The stunt coordinator employed by the day shall receive separate checks for | day of employment.
g OVERTIME
A.	A stunt coordinator shall receive time and one-half for the ninth and
Sth hours of work time, and double time thereafter, except that stunt wrdinators receiving more than two (2) times the day performer minimum rate erday shall receive time and one-half instead of double time after the tenth hour, er the purposes of such calculations, the maximum daily rate shall be two (2) gies the day performer minimum rate.
B B. Overtime pay for stunt coordinators shall be computed on the basis of le-tenth (1/10) hour units. Compensation for travel time shall continue to be rated to eight (8) hours in any day (period of twenty-four (24) hours). Travel jaeshall be computed and paid for pursuant to Section 22 of this Schedule. All ^eitime pay and all premium pay, unless otherwise specifically provided in this ^lulc, shall be based upon the stunt coordinator’s aggregate or adjusted

10. MEAL PERIODS
14. PUBLICITY INTERVIEWS


Allowable meal periods shall not be counted as work time for any
A meal period shall not be less than one-half (14) hour nor more than one (1) hotu; in length.
11.
INTERVIEWS^ AUDITIONS^ TESTS.


Time spent in interviews, auditions or tests shall not be counted as weak* time for any purpose. Time spent supervising the fittings of stunt performers,., when requested by Producer, shall count as work time.
12. STORY, SONGAND PRODUCTION CONFERENCES
Story, song and production conferences on any day on which the coordinator is not otherwise working shall not be counted as work time for any J purpose.
13. STUDY OF LINES OR SCRIPT
Study of lines or script, except during the period between reporting and dismissal, shall not be counted as work time for any purpose.	. f

Schedule K - Part I
Ju. Time spent by the stunt coordinator in publicity interviews, whether on a gay the stunt coordinator works or otherwise, shall not be counted as work time any purpose, but the stunt coordinator shall be under no obligation to report for such interviews.
If the Producer desires the services of the stunt coordinator in making publicity stills, the stunt coordinator agrees to render such services. If the desires such services of the stunt coordinator without the payment of Compensation therefor, it may request from the Union a waiver for such purpose, and the Union agrees to grant such waiver if it considers it to be of benefit to the stunt coordinator. If the Union does not grant such waiver, and the Producer uses & services of the stunt coordinator for publicity stills, the stunt coordinator shall Jie paid for such services a minimum of two (2) hours of compensation, and for

17.
MGHTWRK
A.	Night work is defined as work between 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m?| except that a first call for the day at 5:00 a,m. or thereafter shall not constitute^
’fe'
night work.
• • •
There shall be no premium payable for night work,	-
B.	To the extent known, Producer shall provide advance notice, i.e., the day prior, that night work will be required and whether such night work will involve interiors or exteriors.
C.	Dismissal - New York City. Any stunt coordinator required to work at night and not dismissed by 9:30 p.m. will be provided transportation by. Producer to Grand Central Station, Penn Station or the Port Authority, unless place of dismissal is within a zone bordered by 34th Street on the south, 59th; igu Street on the north, and Third and Eighth Avenues on the east and west, respectively.
18. WORK ON SIX (6) OR SEVEN (7) DAYS IN A WORKWEEK
The studio workweek shall consist of any five (5) days out of seven (7) consecutive days as designated by the Producer on each production unit. The sixth and seventh days in the designated workweek shall be the regular days off.-■ i-
A. A stunt coordinator employed by the day shall be paid time and one- ' half for the sixth day worked, if such stunt coordinator works six (6) days within a > studio workweek. For work on any other sixth day of a studio workweek, the
stunt coordinator shall be paid at straight time. Overtime shall be paid at the same^ ’ rate as for the first eight (8) hours if premium pay is received. If the stunt J“ * coordinator does not work, he shall not be paid. For purposes of such calculations, the maximum daily rate shall be $1,200.00.

-560-	•
Schedule K-Part I
K) B. A stunt coordinator employed by the day shall be paid double time for: ■he seventh day worked, if such performer works seven (7) days within a studio Kirkweek. For work on any other seventh day of the workweek, stunt coordinator ■Sall be paid at straight time. Overtime shall be paid at the same rate as for the ■first eight (8) hours if premium pay is received. If the stunt coordinator does not ■Fork, he shall not be paid. For purposes of such calculations, the maximum daily Kate shall be $1,200.00.
■	|: C. For any sixth day on an overnight location, worked or not worked, ■stunt coordinator receives what he would receive for a week day. A sixth day ■worked on an overnight location shall not be a premium day.
kp
K D. An "overnight location sixth day," as used herein, shall be deemed to ■mean any of the following:
■	&-	(I) Any sixth day spent or worked by the stunt coordinator on an
■	overnight location or on an exploitation tour;
(2)	A sixth day which is the day of departure for such location ^provided the stunt coordinator does not actually work in the studio on such day); For g- ■
B- (3) A sixth day which is the day of return from such location ^(provided the stunt coordinator does not actually work in the studio on such day).
All other sixth days shall be deemed to be "studio sixth days."
E.	PremiuiTLftayg - Holiday
The parties agree that a stunt coordinator shall be treated as having f worked six (6) days in a studio workweek (seven (7) days in an overnight location i workweek), and shall be entitled to payment for the sixth day worked in a studio । workweek (the seventh day worked in an overnight location workweek) whenever ■a holiday falls on a regularly-scheduled work day and the performer is required to work five (5) days in the holiday week in a'studio workweek (six (6) days in an overnight location workweek).

■■o
F.	Once during the production of a motion picture, or in.the caseof^ episodic television, once between hiatus periods (i.e., between the commencem^ or resumption of production and a cessation of principal photography for the-^ser for at least one week), the Producer may shift the workweek for performers*#!^ without incurring extra costs, by adding one (1) or two (2) days off consecutive!^ with the sixth and/or seventh days off in the prior workweek and/or by shiftingla workweek commencing on a Tuesday to a workweek commencing on a Mbricla)| provided that the intervening Sunday is a day off.
If the Producer otherwise shifts the workweek such that the newy4 workweek invades the preceding workweek, the Producer shall pay the premium; for the sixth and/or seventh day worked of the preceding workweek.	j W
The performer shall be advised of any shift in the workweek prioptc commencement of that workweek.
19. WORK ON HOLIDAYS: WORK BEFORE AND AFTER HOLIDAYS :
A.	If a stunt coordinator works on any of the following nine (9) holiday!?; to wit: New Year’s Day, Presidents’ Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, July Fourth, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, the Friday after Thanksgiving, or j Christmas Day, he shall receive double what he would receive for a week day: j Whenever any of said holidays falls on a Sunday, such holiday for all purposes ofx:; this Schedule shall be deemed to fall on the Monday next succeeding.	’
B.	If the stunt coordinator is employed by Producer the day before and^K the day after any one (1) of the above nine (9) holidays, the continuous :	•;
employment rule shall apply over such holiday, except when any such holiday J occurs on a studio sixth day on which stunt coordinator does not work.	?
C.	If a stunt coordinator is required to spend any of the holidays abovet^j
mentioned on an overnight location and does not work, he shall receive a day
pay.

-562-

Schedule K - Part I
. WEATHER-PERMITTING CALLS
k’ Weather-permitting calls are allowable for stunt coordinators subject to the Slowing limitations and conditions:
i A. Weather-permitting calls to stunt coordinators receiving $750.00 per y.or less shall not be issued for stages in studios. The Union has heretofore, on request, issued waivers permitting the giving of weather-permitting calls for jrk on certain stages, such as the so-called "Phantom Stage" at Universal City idios where rain, wind or hail rendered sound recording unusable. Similarly, livers have been granted authorizing weather-permitting calls when caused by wind, rain or hail on uncovered, tarpaulin-covered or open structures. It is reed that weather-permitting calls within the limits provided by this Agreement may be given to stunt coordinators on such or similar stages and on open or uncovered structures where the making of usable sound track is rendered impossible because of rain, wind or hail, or where usable photography on an ^uncovered structure is rendered impossible by fog, wind, rain or hail. Disputes which may arise hereunder are subject to the arbitration provisions of this
Agreement.
B.	A stunt coordinator receiving $750.00 per day or less shall be paid a half (‘/j) check upon the cancellation of any weather-permitting call. This check I shall entitle the Producer to hold the stunt coordinator for not exceeding four (4) hours. The stunt coordinator shall receive a half (‘A) check for each additional I'four (4) hours, or portion thereof, during which he is held by the Producer. During i this waiting period, the Producer has the privilege of rehearsing stunt coordinators |br making other use of their services. If, however, any recording or photographing is done, whether still pictures or otherwise, the stunt coordinator shall be paid the agreed daily wage.
C.	Weather-permitting calls may not be issued to a stunt coordinator j after the commencement of the stunt photography he is coordinating.

21.	OVERLAPPING ENGAGEMENT
In any case in which the engagement of a coordinator under a freelance!.'. contract extends into or overlaps any other engagement of such coordinator as ai freelance coordinator or day coordinator	1
(1)	because of any unanticipated delay in production or dona

mistake, or
(2)	because of any failure of such coordinator to disclose his other engagements at the time of accepting any engagement, or	►
(3)	in any case in which, as an accommodation to such coordinatdr,tsud] coordinator is permitted to work currently in two pictures,
it is agreed as follows: For any day or days on which such coordinator rehders m services for the Producer of the picture in which he has first rendered his sefvicel
he shall receive compensation from such first Producer. For any day or days which such coordinator renders services for the Producer of the second picture^ which he has rendered his services, he shall be compensated by the Producer of

such second picture. For any day or days on which the coordinator does not render his services either for the first Producer or for the second Producer,‘he sh be compensated by the second Producer, unless the first and second agree between themselves (and notice thereof is given to the coordinator^ compensation for such additional day or days shall be paid by the first Pn The compensation to be paid by the first Producer shall be paid at the rate, specified in the coordinator's contract with the first Producer, and the compensation to be paid by the second Producer shall be at the rate specifi the coordinator's contract with the second Producer, provided, however,', tha^: rate paid by the first Producer is less than the rate specified in the coor contract with the second Producer, the difference shall be paid by the secant Producer and, provided further, that for any day or days on which the co
does not render services either for the first or for the second Producer, hasfia compensated at the rate of compensation which is the higher of the two.uTiiii paragraph does not affect such coordinator's right to receive compensation f both Producers when the coordinator, while employed by one Producer,;ma

2.	TRAVEL TIME - RULES AND DEFINITIONS
A. Travel to Location - No Services Rendered on Day of Departure
If a coordinator is transported to location and such traveling is ced on any day on which he does not render services, he shall be ted at a day's pay.

Pay for Day of Arrival

If a coordinator is transported to or from location and he does not at the destination on the day of departure, any travel time past midnight of
£day preceding the day of arrival shall not be work time or travel time for any tirpose whatsoever with respect to the day of arrival, but such coordinator shall eless be entitled to not less than a full day's pay for the day of arrival, .
ther or not he renders any services on such day.
C. Pay for Intervening Days of Travel
If a coordinator is transported to or from location and does not arrive sthe destination on the day following the day of departure, he shall be entitled to (1) day of pay for each intervening day of travel.
1
-565-
Schedule K - Part I
D.
&
If a coordinator departs from location, he shall be entitled to a full of pay for such day of departure, but if he has not otherwise rendered services^ such day, his travel time on such day shall not be counted as work time or travel^ time for any purpose. If a coordinator departs from location on a day on which*he has rendered services, then, for the purpose of computing his pay for the day of, departure, his travel time, if any, past midnight of such day shall not be work trr or travel time for any purpose unless he arrives at the destination and renders 5$. services on the day next following the day of departure; but if, in such event, lie u does arrive at the destination and renders services on the day next following the, day of departure, his travel time past midnight of the day of departure shall be|, included in his travel time for the purpose of computing his pay for the day of| departure; it being understood that for the purpose of computing his pay for the day of departure as aforesaid, such coordinator shall in no event be entitled to/’ ; more than one (1) day of pay on account of all such travel time.

(1)	With respect to studios situated in Los Angeles, California, qi its environs, the "studio zone" shall include all territory within the radius of (30) miles from the intersection of Beverly Boulevard and La Cienega Bouleya Los Angeles, California, and such other territory (such as the present Columbia Ranch and Disney Studio) as is generally recognized as being within the studfro, zone. With respect to studios not situated in Los Angeles or its . environs, a sun territory as the studio zone and similar rules in relation thereto shall be agreed-upon between the Union and the Producers, and in default of such agreement,' territory and such rules (which shall conform as nearly as possible to the rules^ herein set forth) shall be determined by arbitration under Section 9 of the * Provisions whenever the situation arises.
(2)	With respect to studios situated in New York, New York,' "studio zone" shall include all territory within the radius of eight (8) miles fr Columbus Circle.

(The Reporting site must still be within the thirty (30) mile zone.) Producer shall give pior notice to the Union of the point so designated. F. Location and Overnight Location
Location shall mean any place of work not at the Producer's studio^ which is outside the studio zone. Overnight location shall be any location where^ the coordinator is lodged or offered lodging by the Producer at or near the location for one (1) or more nights, or any location which takes overnight to reach byj£?3 ordinary means of transportation.	■
G. Near Location
4^
A near location shall be any place which can be reached from the; Producer's studio within twenty-four (24) hours of travel by ordinary means of transportation. If the Producer instructs the coordinator to fly to a location and th trip takes less than twenty-four (24) hours by air, the same shall be deemed to bej
near location.

H. Pistant Location
A distant location shall be any place which cannot be reached frony the Producer's studio within twenty-four (24) hours of travel by ordinary transportation.
-568-
Schedule K - Part I
| I. Place of Reporting and Dismissal
>	Except when already at an overnight location, coordinators shall be
^required to report only at the Producer's studio or within the studio zone, and shall jf be dismissed only at the place of reporting within the studio zone or the Producer's ^studio. When the coordinator is returning from such overnight location, he shall j|be dismissed only at the Producer's studio or the place of reporting within the i J studio zone, and not at the overnight location.
J. Travel Time is Work Time
Except as otherwise provided in this Agreement, all time spent by any
^coordinator in traveling at the request of the Producer, between any place at which h he is required to and does report and any location, both to and from, shall be travel l^time and, as such, shall be work time, subject to all deductions, limitations and i’lexceptions for which provision is made in this Agreement.
K. Maximum Travel Time
■ Time spent in traveling shall not be included as travel time or work
f Aime to the extent of more than eight (8) hours in any twenty-four (24) hours.
L. Intervening Time between Dismissal and Travel
(1) Time intervening between the completion of a coordinator’s
..work on any day and the commencement of travel on the same day shall be travel ; time except as otherwise provided in this Agreement.
F '	(2) Travel to Overnight Location: Except as otherwise provided in
j^this Agreement, the period of time intervening between the coordinator’s dismissal |for the day and the commencement of travel to an overnight location on the same [day shall be travel time. This provision shall not affect the coordinator's right to a ^minimum of one (1) day of pay for such day.
(3) Travel from Overnight Location: The period intervening
etween the coordinator's dismissal for the day and the commencement of travel

U.	EngaeemenLof Coordinators - Other Areas

(1)	If a coordinator, residing or working in any area in which SAG^
maintains a branch, is brought to Producer’s base or distant location in a different area of the United States for any purpose, the coordinator shall receive transportation and a $75 per day allowance from the time he commences travel at^. Producer's request until the time his salary commences.
(2)	If Producer is photographing on a location in the United S and brings a coordinator to such location from anywhere in the United States;^ coordinator shall be provided transportation to and from such location.
(3)	Except as otherwise provided in (1) and (2) above, nothing^ herein contained shall prevent a Producer from engaging a coordinator outside, qfj California (if such coordinator has not gone out of California for the purpose df^ evading this rule) to report in California or to report at any location and, in any such case, the Producer shall not be required to pay for or provide transportatianj| of such coordinator to the place of reporting, or to pay such coordinator forany^ time spent in traveling thereto; nor shall the Producer be required to pay fqror provide transportation of such coordinator, at the end of the engagement backtd the place where such coordinator was engaged, or to pay such coordinator for an} time spent in traveling back to the place where such coordinator was engaged;1 such coordinator may be dismissed on location. This does not limit the second sentence of subsection E. hereof.	;
(4)	Coordinators shall not be held on a per diem longer than
(3) days.
•V.

This Agreement uses the expressions "reasonable transportation’ "first-class transportation." The terms are intended to be synonymous. The; of transportation required can best be illustrated by examples: Bus transportatio for a relatively short distance (Hollywood to Lake Arrowhead) meets these “'
-572-
Schedule K - Part I
krequirements; bus transportation for a long distance (Hollywood to San Francisco) pfloes not. Pullman accommodations to San Francisco, or any other long distance, mneet these requirements; deluxe transportation (e.g., Super Chief) is not required. Pransportation on a commercial airline without sleeper accommodations is first-Itclass transportation. First-class transportation shall be provided on commercial primes when the coordinator is required to fly at the request of the Producer. The ^foregoing shall apply to jet flights as well as to prop-driven aircraft. The tforegoing shall not apply when first-class transportation is not available or six (6) more of the company are being transported. Charter flights may be used which Iprovide substantially equivalent accommodations. Notwithstanding the foregoing, |first-class air transportation need not be provided with respect to auditions and fmterviews.
|b. TIME OF PAYMENT
■t ’ Paychecks shall be mailed or delivered to the coordinator within five (5) jerking days after completion of his day's work, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays Eexcepted.
Ka--.
«4. PROTECTION OF STUNT PERFORMER; SAFETY
A.	All reasonable requests and requirements for safety equipment in connection with the performance of stunts shall be complied with by Producer or Eroducer's representatives on the set or location.
B.	Equipment provided by Producer, for example, autos, cycles, wagons, shall be in suitable repair for the safe and proper performance of the stunt.
BETTER CONDITIONS
I
Ig-- Any better condition terms negotiated by a stunt coordinator must be reflected in his/her deal memorandum or personal service agreement and in his/her Schedule K employment contract.

IKIUAUE
UAL CONTRACTS
The provisions of this Schedule shall apply to stunt coordinators employed by the week at less than the "flat deal" minimum (specified in Schedule K, Part in’ on motion pictures covered by this Agreement. Such provisions shall be deemed.^ incorporated in the individual contract of employment between Producer and each-coordinator; the Producer and the individual coordinator each shall be bound ^.7 thereby.
2.
hMljJli
SALARY
.W
■
The minimum salary for a stunt coordinator employed by the week shallbe-$2,369.00 during the period July 1,2001 through June 30, 2002; $2,440.00 dunhg the period July 1,2002 through June 30, 2003; and $2,525.00 during the paiod/K July 1,2003 through June 30,2004.	' ‘
W-4 forms shall be presented to coordinator no later than the first day of employment. A W-4 form may be given to coordinator on the set on the fiisfday J of employment.
■■
W-4 forms shall be available on every set. It shall be the coordinator’s^’^ responsibility to return a completed W-4 form to Producer in a timely manner^i^ is understood that when a coordinator fails to do so, there shall be no retroactive'^ adjustments to the withholding required by law. W-4 forms shall be attachedtq. jffl three-day coordinator contracts.

" MI
!j.	DAILY RATE OF COMPENSATION ■ ADDITIONAL DAY OF PAY
f
| A.	Except as provided in subsection B. hereof in the case of premium
pay, and except for a waiver of the eight (8) hour rest period, whenever a weekly |stunt coordinator is entitled to an additional day of pay, this shall mean one-fifth |(l/5) of his weekly base rate.
1
SB. Whenever a weekly stunt coordinator is entitled to premium pay, such premium pay shall be an amount equal to one-fifth (1/5) of his weekly ^condensation except in those instances in which the amount of premium pay is ^limited to a maximum of $950.00.
INITIAL PERIOD OF EMPLOYMENT - PRORATING SALARY
In the case of a stunt coordinator employed by the week, the initial period of 7 employment must be at least a week in duration. Whenever it is necessary to pprorate the workweek in order to determine an additional day of pay, such ^'prorating shall be on the basis of one-fifth (1/5) of the coordinator's weekly base pi.rate for either a studio or distant location workweek; however, such proration shall Knot in any manner change the coordinator's weekly base rate.
O With respect to prorating the coordinator’s workweek for the purpose of -’paying the coordinator at the end of a payroll week, that portion of coordinator's /.studio workweek which is part of such payroll week shall be prorated on the basis ;"of one-fifth (1/5) of the weekly base rate for each such day (excluding the sixth ,‘ ahd seventh days in the workweek) in that payroll week. This is exclusive of any ^ overtime or premium pay, if any, due in such coordinator’s workweek.
. Weekly overtime shall not be prorated except on a fractional week at the end of the coordinator’s engagement; weekly overtime shall only be computed on \the basis of coordinator’s week, as fully set forth in Section 5, ’’Overtime.*' h ■
u
-579-
Schedule K - Part D
-580-
Schedule K - Part H
5.
OVERr

Overtime shall be computed and paid pursuant to the following:
A. Rate
Except as otherwise provided by the provisions of this Schedule K: ‘
(1)	Daily Overtime
Two (2) times the straight time rate for hours worked in excess’ of ten (10) hours in any day. Hours paid for as daily overtime are not to be included in computing weekly overtime.	. J
(2)	Weekly Overtime
(a)	With respect to coordinators on a studio five (5) day< T-i| forty-four (44) hour workweek, one and one-half (11/2) times the straight time rate?, for hours worked in excess of forty-four (44) hours in the week of such coordinator.
(b)	With respect to coordinators on an overnight location, six (6) day, forty-eight (48) hour workweek, such workweek shall include an !<■ additional four (4) hours overtime (4/44) at the straight time hourly rate, whether^ worked or not. Weekly overtime shall be paid at one and one-half (1 */i) times the J < straight time hourly rate for hours worked in excess of forty-eight (48) in such workweek.	-
(3)	Travel Time
To the extent that any weekly or daily overtime is causedhy'^ ; travel time at the beginning or at the end of the day, such overtime shall be ; computed as provided in Section 27 relating to Travel Time.	1
-581 -
Schedule K - Part D
B.	Units of Overtime and Computation
|	Overtime payable on the basis of time and one-half or double time
i shall be computed in one-tenth (1/10) hour units.

I	For the purpose of accumulating the number of hours worked during
| any week, the number of hours worked each day during such week shall be t accumulated on the basis of six (6) minute units; there shall be excluded all time •
K during such week for which any daily overtime compensation shall be payable to || such coordinator. For the purpose of computing such overtime, such coordinator's H week in each instance shall commence on the day of the week on which such H coordinator is first placed on salary. In case of any suspension or interruption of B such coordinator’s employment at any time for seven (7) consecutive days or more, It for any reason whatsoever, such coordinator's week shall thereafter commence on H the day of the week when he is again placed on salary.
C.
[I?	When compensation is payable for less than a full workweek, the
H number of hours worked shall be prorated on a forty-eight (48) hour basis when P coordinator is on an overnight location six (6) day week and shall be prorated on a forty-four (44) hour basis when coordinator is on a studio five (5) day week. To
K illustrate the foregoing, if the final fractional week of a coordinator's employment H on an overnight location six (6) day week consists of Thursday, Friday and » Saturday, overtime shall be computed only as to the period beyond twenty-four H (24) hours. As a further illustration, on such six (6) day basis, if the final fractional week of a coordinator's employment consists of Friday, Saturday and
: | Sunday, overtime shall be computed only as to the period beyond twenty-four (24) ■'(•hours.
D.	Effect of Error in Computation
Any failure through error to pay all or any part of overtime compensation shall give the coordinator no right except to collect the amount so f | unpaid.
te'
-582-
Schedule K - Part II
I
E.	Date When Due
•
The overtime accruing under the provisions of this Section shall be payable not later than the studio pay day of the calendar week next following^ expiration of the coordinator’s week in which such overtime accrues. -
F.	Guarffiteed-Empfoyment nat Affected
Whenever a coordinator receives overtime or an additional day-ST pursuant to the provisions of this Schedule, such overtime or additional day’s | shall not be deemed to reduce such coordinator's guaranteed employment <jf|j compensation.	:
