6. EXECUTION OF AGREEMENT - ENGAGEMENT - DELIVERY. 0» CONTRACT_____________________________________\
A.	If said freelance contract is delivered by the Producer to the coordinator and if said freelance contract is executed without alteration by the coordinator and is so returned to die Producer by noon of the next succeeding business day after its delivery to the coordinator, it shall thereupon constitute:; contract binding on both parties even, though not executed by the Producer,*;bu Producer, on demand, shah deliver a signed copy to die coordinator; '1^
B.	Freelance coordinators under this Schedule B shall be consider definitely engaged in any of the following events:	.
(1)	When the coordinator is given written notice of acceptance
(2)	When a form contract signed by Producer is delivered to y; coordinator or when an unsigned contract is delivered by Producer to coordiiia and is executed by coordinator as so delivered and returned to Producer.
C.	. Delivery, of Cootragts ' ■
(1)	Producer shall deliver a copy of the agreement between
Producer and coordinator to the coordinator not later than the first day of •

coordinator’s employment or four (4) business days after such agreement has been reached, whichever is later.
A coordinator may not be required to sign contracts on the set. Delivery to a coordinator’s agent constitutes delivery to the coordinator.

When Producer chooses to deliver a copy of a contract to the set, an extra copy for retention by the coordinator shall be
D.	Better Conditions
Any better condition terms negotiated by a stunt coordinator must be reflected in his/her deal memorandum or personal service agreement and in his/her Schedule K employment contract.
STUDIO PAYROLL WEEK - TIME.OF PAYMENT
A.	The studio payroll week shall be deemed to start at 12:01 a.m. on ■^Sunday and end at 12:00 midnight of the succeeding Saturday.
B.	Compensation, including daily overtime, if any, earned by the
^coordinator under a freelance contract shall be payable on the regular studio pay fiay for services rendered up to and including the preceding Saturday.
L THE COORDINATOR’S WORKWEEK: STUDIO FIVE (5) DAY WEEK; OVERNIGHT LOCATION-WEEK_______________________________
A. Dsfiniimn^^ieneral
j	(1) An "overnight location workweek," as used herein, shall be
fleemed to be a workweek consisting of six (6) overnight location days or six (6) days of any combination of studio and overnight location days, which combination includes a sixth day overnight location day.
I	-584-
t	Schedule K - Part n
3
Any workweek, other than such an overnight location workweek, for the purposes of this Section, shall be deemed to be a "studio q 4 workweek." The studio workweek shall consist of any five (5) days out of seven J'
(7) consecutive days as designated by the Producer on each production unit The; j sixth and seventh days in the designated workweek shall be the regular days off.,	;
.4
(2)	An "overnight location day," as used herein, shall be deemed mean any of the following days, if the coordinator is on salary that day, as	,
provided in the Basic Agreement:
£
(a)	Any day spent or worked by the coordinator on an overnight location or on an exploitation tour;
(b)	The day of departure for such location (provided the $ coordinator does not actually work in the studio on such day); or
(c)	The day of return from such location (provided the j coordinator does not actually work in the studio on such day).
(3)	For all purposes, the coordinator's weekly base rate shall be his£
weekly rate of salary as specified in his contract; the coordinator’s straight	1
hourly rate shall be one-forty-fourth (1/44) of his weekly base rate.	- i";? J
b. Studig-Eiyg (S) Pay Workweek	1
(1)	The coordinator’s studio workweek shall be a five (5) day V workweek.	4“'
(2)	The regular studio workweek shall be forty-four (44)
Ci ■ L -a

cumulative hours commencing with the first day of the coordinator's workweek;; weekly overtime shall be at one and one-half (114) times the straight time hourly;
rate for hours worked in excess of forty-four (44) hours in such workweek, as X’.* ’
provided in Section 5 entitled "Overtime."	£ $


-585-
Schedule K - Part H
»«	(3) Work on Six (6) or Seven (7) Days in a Workweek
|.	If the coordinator works six (6) or seven (7) days in the
| workweek and coordinator is on a studio workweek, he shall in each case be [ entitled to premium pay in accordance with the following rules:
|	(i) The coordinator shall receive a premium of an additional
| one-half (H) day of pay for the sixth day worked, if the coordinator works six (6)
I days within a studio workweek. The coordinator shall receive a premium of an
* additional day of pay for the seventh day worked, if the coordinator works seven
(7) days within a studio workweek (in addition to the one-half day of premium pay I’ for the sixth day worked in the workweek).
The following are examples of the foregoing:
(1)	If the coordinator works seven (7) days in his
workweek, he shall be entitled to an additional two (2) days of pay for work beyond five (5) days plus one and one-half (1 &) days of premium pay or a total of r eight and one-half (814) days of pay. Hours worked on such sixth and seventh | days shall not be included in calculating coordinator's forty-four (44) hour week. ( The other five (5) days in the week will constitute the workweek for such purpose.
r	(2)	If the coordinator works six (6) days in his
| workweek, he shall be entitled to an additional day of pay for work beyond five | (5) days plus one-half (‘/i) day of premium pay, or a total of six and one-half (654) days of pay. Hours worked on such sixth day, to and including ten (10) hours, shall be included in calculating coordinator's forty-four (44) hour week.
(ii)	Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of ^subparagraphs (i) and (ii) above, a sixth day worked on an overnight location shall not be a premium day.
(iii)	For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any sixth or seventh day in a workweek for which the coordinator receives a premium of one-half (!4) day of pay or one (1) day of pay as above provided, the coordinator shall ^receive double the weekly straight time hourly rate, including overtime caused by | supervising fittings.
-586-
Schedule K - Part II
C.	' Overnight Location Six (6) Day Workweek
(1)	The overnight location six (6) day workweek shall be fortyeight (48) cumulative hours, commencing with the first day of the coordinator's . workweek, which forty-eight (48) hours include an additional four (4) hours overtime at the straight time hourly rate (whether worked or not).
(2)	If the time included in calculating the coordinator's forty-eight (48) hour week, as above provided, exceeds forty-eight (48) hours, such excess time shall be paid for at the rate of one and one-half (1 l/z) times the weekly straight time hourly rate, except as otherwise provided in Section 5 entitled, "Overtime."
(3)	Work on the Seventh Day in a Workweek
(a)	If a coordinator works seven (7) days in an overnight location workweek, he shall be entitled to a premium of an extra day of pay for the seventh day of work within his workweek.
(b)	For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any seventh day, for which the coordinator receives a premium of one (1) day of pay as above provided, the coordinator shall receive double the weekly straight time hourly rate, including overtime caused by supervising fittings.
D.	Premium Days - Holiday Weeks
The parties agree that a stunt coordinator shall be treated as having worked six (6) days in a studio workweek (seven (7) days in an overnight location workweek), and shall be entitled to payment for the sixth day worked in a studio workweek (the seventh day worked in an overnight location workweek) whenever a holiday falls on a regularly-scheduled work day and the performer is required to . work five (5) days in the holiday week in a studio workweek (six (6) days in an overnight location workweek).
E.	Shift in Workweek
Once during the production of a motion picture, or in the case of episodic television, once between hiatus periods (i.e., between the commencement -
-587-
Schedule K - Part n
or resumption of production and a cessation of principal photography for the series for at least one week), the Producer may shift the workweek for performers without incurring extra costs, by adding one (1) or two (2) days off consecutive with the sixth and/or seventh days off in the prior workweek and/or by shifting a workweek commencing on a Tuesday to a workweek commencing on a Monday, provided that the intervening Sunday is a day off.
If the Producer otherwise shifts the workweek such that the new workweek invades the preceding workweek, the Producer shall pay the premium for the sixth and/or seventh day worked of the preceding workweek.
The coordinator shall be advised of any shift in the workweek prior to commencement of that workweek.
F.	Recall on the Sixth or Seventh Day in the Workweek
If a coordinator is recalled to work on a day or days that would constitute the sixth and/or seventh day worked in a workweek by such coordinator for that Producer (for which the coordinator receives a premium of one-half (14) day or one (1) day of pay, as above provided) for any purpose mentioned in Section 21 of this Schedule K and, therefore, receives day coordinator conditions, the premium for the sixth or seventh day so worked shall not exceed $950 for the first eight (8) hours worked. Overtime in such case shall be paid at the same rate as for the first eight (8) hours.
G.	No Compounding
There shall be no compounding of the foregoing premiums and the penalty or premium prescribed by Section 20, it being understood that, if, for example, a coordinator works seven (7) days in a studio workweek, he shall be entitled to only eight and one-half (814) days of pay, plus overtime, if any.
h. Union Branches
Any area in which the Union maintains a branch shall be deemed a five (5) day workweek area for coordinators employed in such area, when principal photography for a picture is substantially photographed in such area.
-588-
Schedule K - Part H
The scope of such>areas is defined in General Provisions, Section 14, "Preference of Employment."
9.
COORDINATOR'S WEEK
The coordinator’s week in each instance shall commence on the day of the week on which such coordinator is first placed on salary. In case of any suspension or interruption of such coordinator's employment at any time for seven (7) consecutive days or more, for any reason whatsoever, such coordinator's week shall thereafter commence on the day of the week when he is again placed on salary.
10.	REST PERIOD
A.	A stunt coordinator shall be entitled to an eight (8) hour rest period from the time dismissed until the first call thereafter, subject to the following:
(1)	When more than one (1) night of travel (by ordinary means of .
transportation) is required to reach a location and the coordinator is given a berth on a boat or train for each night of traveling, the time spent in such traveling, to or from such location, shall not be work time or travel time for the purpose of computing the eight (8) hour rest period.
(2)	When an overnight trip to or from a location is required, and the same takes at least seven (7) hours to reach, and the coordinator is given a berth on a boat or train, or if the coordinator elects to travel by first-class plane accommodations, the time spent in such traveling to or from such location shall not be work time or travel time for the purpose of computing the eight (8) hour rest period.
(3)	The first call at the lodging for work (including travel) determines the time of first call for the next day for the purpose of computing the rest period.
-589-
Schedule K - Part II
B.	Whenever the stunt coordinator has been authorized in advance by the Unit Production Manager to report without having received the rest period prescribed above, the coordinator may waive the rest period without the Union’s consent but, if he does so, he shall be entitled to one (1) day of pay or $950, whichever is the lesser sum. A coordinator may be required to waive the rest period if the violation, in case of the eight (8) hour rest period, is not over two and one-half (214) hours or, on an overnight location, not over two (2) hours. In any case in which the coordinator waives the rest period, the payment of one (1) day of pay, not exceeding $950, shall be automatically incurred. The payment may not be waived without the consent of the Union.
C.	It is understood that the foregoing provisions are not applicable when a stunt coordinator is also acting as a second unit director.
11.	WORKTIME
A.	The provisions of this Section shall apply only to television freelance coordinators whose weekly guaranteed salary is $4,400 or less per week and who are guaranteed less than $32,000 per television picture and to freelance coordinators whose weekly guaranteed salary is $5,500 or less per week and who are guaranteed less than $55,000 per theatrical picture.
B.	For the purpose of ascertaining and computing hours of work, the rest
period and overtime, the period from the time the coordinator is required to and does report, as directed, until the time such coordinator is finally dismissed for the day, shall constitute work time, continuously and without interruption, except as follows:
(1)	Allowable meal periods, as provided by Section 13;
(2)	Fittings, as provided by Section 14;
(3)	Story, song and production conferences, to the extent provided in Section 15;
(4)	S tudy of lines or script, to the extent provided by Section 16;
-590-
Schcdule K. - Part U
?,i ■■
(5)" Interviews for publicity purposes, as provided by Section 17;-C ;
1 ;
(6)	Publicity stills, to the extent provided by Section 18; and
(7)	Travel time, to the extent provided by Section 28.	’’W* ■
s;.
C.	Any period during which the coordinator fails or refuses or is unable*? ' because of disability to render services, and any period during which the	'
coordinator at his own request is excused from rendering services, shall not be work time for any pinpose.	;
' ’ ' '-X- i
2 - -wst'
12.	MEAL PERIODS ' -
Allowable meal periods shall not be counted as work time for any purposed A meal period shall not be less than one-half (14) hour nor more than one (1) hour) * in length.	■
13.

ERVIEWS, AUDITIONS, TESTS.


£S
Time spent in interviews, auditions, or tests does not count as work timeTor any purpose.	, .L
Time spent supervising the fitting of stunt performers, when requested by7
Producer, shall count as work time.

14.	STORY. SONG AND PRODUCTION CONFERENCES
Story, song and production conferences on any day on which the	;
coordinator is not otherwise working shall not be counted as work time for any ’ purpose.	. \'1
Ar
i1
■_ 41. .
■'J
J
-591 -
Schedule K - Part II
15.	STUDY OF JUNES QBJCRIPT
Study of lines or script, except during the period between reporting and dismissal, shall not be counted as work time for any purpose.
16.	PUBLICITY INTERVIEWS
Publicity interviews held at a time mutually satisfactory to the coordinator and the Producer shall not be work time for any purpose unless held on a day on which the coordinator is otherwise working for the Producer. Such interviews for publicity purposes held on any day on which the coordinator is otherwise working for the Producer shall not be counted as work time if held after the coordinator’s dismissal for the day, if such interview is held at a time mutually satisfactory to the •coordinator and the Producer. If the interview is held during a meal period, it shall not be deemed to constitute a violation thereof.
17.	PUBLICITY SJJLLS
■ If the Producer should desire the services of a freelance coordinator for ^making publicity stills either before the commencement of his term of employment j)r after the expiration thereof, the coordinator shall render such services without [compensation for one (1) day, as and when requested by the Producer, unless the [coordinator is otherwise employed, but if otherwise employed, the coordinator will [cooperate to the fullest extent in the making of such publicity stills.
18.	REHEARSAL TIME
A.	Rehearsals shall be counted as work time.
B.	Interviews do not constitute rehearsals.
l C. Neither publicity stills nor pre-production stills, after employment but |tfore the starting date of such employment, shall start the employment period of
-592-
Schcdule K - Part H
such coordinator. Compensation, if any, for any of such services shall be as otherwise provided in this Schedule.	! j
.Jo
19.	NIGHT WORK
Night work is defined as work between 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., except that-'^ a first call for the day at 5:00 a.m. or thereafter shall not constitute night work, ■	■ J
There shall be no premium payable for night work.	Jl
To the extent known, Producer shall provide advance notice, i.e., on the dayft -Ja prior, that night work will be required and whether such night work will involve^ interiors or exteriors.	.
Dismissal - New York City. Any coordinator required to work at night and^' JB not dismissed by 9:30 p.m. will be provided transportation by Producer to Grand Central Station, Penn Station or the Port Authority, unless such place of dismissal' is within a zone bordered by 34th Street on the south, 59th Street on the north, andfU^B Third and Eighth Avenues on the east and west, respectively.

20.	WORK ON HOLIDAYS, OR HOLIDAYS AND SIX (6) OR SEVEN'(7) . Jfl DAYS IN A WORKWEEK____________________________________________
A. Holidays	.
■
The nine (9) holidays hereinafter referred to are the following: New Year's Day, Presidents' Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, July Fourth, Labor Dayf '^^B Thanksgiving Day, the Friday after Thanksgiving and Christmas Day. Whenever any of said holidays falls on a Sunday, such holiday for all purposes of this Schedule K, Part II shall be deemed to fall on the Monday next succeeding.
-593-
Schedule K - Part n
I B. Studio Five Day Workweek: Work on Holidays, or Holidays and g Six (6) or .Seven (7) Days in a Workweek
K •	(1) If a coordinator works on any of the nine (9) holidays, or a
[| holiday and six (6) or seven (7) days in a workweek, he shall, in each case (that is, K separately for the holiday and for die sixth or the seventh day, if he works on each k such respective day), be entitled to premium pay, in accordance with the following [I rules:
rr
A coordinator shall be entitled to a premium of one (1) additional day of pay for work on a holiday. If a coordinator works six (6) days within a studio workweek, including work on a holiday, he shall receive one and & one-half (1 Vt) days of premium pay; except that if such holiday is the sixth day B worked in the workweek, the coordinator shall receive only one (1) day of premium pay. If the coordinator works seven (7) days within a studio workweek, B including work on a holiday, he shall receive two and one-half days (27a) of premium pay; except that if the holiday is the sixth or seventh day worked in the workweek, coordinator shall receive two (2) days of premium pay. The following g are examples of the foregoing:
(i)	If the coordinator works seven (7) days in his workweek, including work on such a holiday, which holiday is not the sixth or seventh day p; worked in the workweek, he receives two and one-half (27i) days of premium pay plus two (2) additional days of pay for two (2) days beyond his five (5) day week 11 or a total of nine and one-half (9!4) days of pay. Hours worked on the sixth and seventh days worked in the workweek shall not be included in calculating l^coordinator’s forty-four (44) hour workweek. The other five (5) days shall be used 1 (for this purpose.
(ii)	If the coordinator works seven (7) days in his workweek, ■^including work on such a holiday (which is the sixth day worked in the workweek) i^and on the seventh day of the workweek, he receives two (2) days of premium pay E fplus two (2) additional days of pay for two (2) days beyond his five (5) day week Ipfir a total of nine (9) days of pay. Hours worked on such sixth day holiday and the g jseventh day shall not be included in calculating coordinator’s forty-four (44) hour E^workweck. The other five (5) days shall be used for this purpose.
E	'594'
E	Schedule K - Part n
(iii)	If coordinator works five (5) days or less in his workweek, he receives a premium of an extra day of pay for each day worked which is a holiday.
(2)	If the time included in calculating the coordinator's forty-four '< (44) hour week, as above provided, exceeds forty-four (44) hours, such excess i $ j time shall be paid for in one-tenth (1/10) hour units at the rate of one and one-half $ times the weekly straight time hourly rate.	vt■’
(3)	For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any such holiday, > *
sixth or seventh day, for which the coordinator receives premium pay as herein	a
provided, the coordinator receives double the weekly straight time hourly rate 3 including overtime caused by supervising fittings.
■ J
(4)	Notwithstanding the foregoing, a sixth day worked on an overnight location shall not be a premium day, unless it is a holiday.	.
C.	Overnight Location Six (6) Day Workweek: Work on Holiday or Holiday and Seven (7) Daxs-jn the Workweek	s#
If a coordinator works on any of the nine (9) holidays and seven (7)^ £ days within a workweek, he shall, in each case (that is, separately for the holiday^ J and for the seventh day), be entitled to a premium of an extra day of pay, in	J
accordance with the following rules:
(1)	If the coordinator works seven (7) days in his workweek including such a holiday, he receives two (2) premium days of pay plus one (1)^M additional day of pay for one (1) day beyond his six (6) day week or a total offline^ (9) days of pay. The hours worked on the seventh day shall not be included in'i^ calculating coordinator's forty-eight (48) hour workweek. The hours worked on.,» such holiday, up to and including ten (10) hours, shall be included in calculating^^ coordinator’s forty-eight (48) hour week.
(2)	If the coordinator works six (6) days or less in his workweek,^ including work on such a holiday, the coordinator receives a premium day of-pay or a total of seven (7) days of pay for that week, and the hours worked on suc&M
-595*
Schedule K - Part II
holiday, up to and including ten (10) hours, are included in calculating the coordinator's forty-eight (48) hour week.
(3)	If the time included in calculating the coordinator's forty-eight
m (48) hour week, as above provided, exceeds forty-eight (48) hours, such excess
H time shall be paid for in one-tenth (1/10) hour units at the rate of one and one-half times the weekly straight time hourly rate.
(4)	For work time in excess of ten (10) hours on any such holiday
or seventh day worked in a workweek, the coordinator receives double the weekly straight time hourly rate including overtime caused by make-up, hairdress, wardrobe or fittings.
D.	If the coordinator is not required to work on such a holiday, no
deduction shall be made from his guaranteed weekly pay.
£ E. If a coordinator works on such holiday and six (6) and/or seven (7) days in his workweek, he shall be entitled to the premiums provided by this subsection, but insofar as the holiday and sixth or seventh day worked premiums
11 are concerned, there shall be no compounding of such premium and the penalty or Egpremium prescribed by Section 5; it being understood that if, for example, a coordinator on an overnight location workweek works seven (7) days in his week, including work on such a holiday, he shall be entitled to nine (9) days of pay, plus kiovertime, if any.

22.	OVERLAPPING ENGAGEMENT	'
■	2
In any case in which the engagement of a coordinator under a freelance ' afc i contract extends into or overlaps any other engagement of such coordinator as a W 1 freelance coordinator or day coordinator	r I
(1)	because of any unanticipated delay in production or bona fide	j
mistake, or
(2)	because of any failure of such coordinator to disclose his other j engagements at the time of accepting any engagement, or	-dfc- i
(3)	in any case in which, as an accommodation to such coordinator; such ^ coordinator is permitted to work concurrently in two (2) pictures, • K- r
it is agreed as follows: For any day or days on which such coordinator renders! his| services for the Producer of the picture in which he has first rendered his services^ he shall receive compensation from such first Producer. For any day or daysbn which such coordinator renders services for the Producer of the second picture in which he has rendered his services, he shall be compensated by the Producer of
■s”-	i-1
Schedule K - Part n
such second picture. For any day or days on which the coordinator does not render his services either for the first Producer or for the second Producer, he shall be compensated by the second Producer, unless the first and second Producers agree between themselves (and notice thereof is given to the coordinator) that compensation for such additional day or days shall be paid by the first Producer. The compensation to be paid by the first Producer shall be paid at the rate specified in the coordinator's contract with the first Producer, and the compensation to be paid by the second Producer shall be at the rate specified in the coordinator's contract with the second Producer, provided, however, that if the rate paid by. the first Producer is less than die rate specified in the coordinator’s contract with the second Producer, the difference shall be paid by the second Producer and, provided further, that for any day or days on which the coordinator does not render services either for the first or for the second Producer, he shall be
? compensated at the rate of compensation which is the higher of the two. This r Section does not affect such coordinator’s right to receive compensation from both Producers when the coordinator, while employed by one Producer, makes retakes, | added scenes, etc., for the other Producer after the expiration of his term of employment with such other Producer, in any case in which the coordinator is
I otherwise entitled thereto. Nothing in this Section contained shall be deemed or construed in any way to limit or prejudice any right or remedy of any Producer, either with respect to any of the contingencies hereinbefore specified or otherwise. ¥ Freelance coordinators may be required to state on their contracts the starting date of their next engagement by inserting such date in the following statement, which , >may be endorsed or printed on such contracts:

Sj23. DAMAGE TOWARDROBE
Any loss of or damage to costumes, wardrobe and other property furnished O’Jby the coordinator necessarily arising through the performance of the coordinator’s X ^services, or through lack of due care on the part of the Producer, shall be paid for the Producer to the coordinator. All costumes, wardrobe and other property | .furnished by the Producer shall belong to the Producer and be returned promptly 11 to it, and any loss of or damage thereto arising through lack of due care on the part
O	‘598'
K.	Schedule K - Part II
of the coordinator, or not necessarily arising through the performance of the coordinator's services, shall be paid for by the coordinator to the Producer. Any loss of or damage to wardrobe, for which either party hereto may be liable, shall be computed on the basis of depreciation schedules to be furnished from time to time by the American Appraisal Company.
24.	RIGHTS GRANTED TO PRODUCER
The term "photoplay," as used in said freelance contract, shall be deemed to include motion pictures produced and/or exhibited with sound and voice recording, reproducing and/or transmitting devices, radio devices and all other improvements and devices, including television, which are now or may hereafter be used in connection with the production and/or exhibition and/or transmission of any present or future kind of motion picture production. The Producer shall have the right to photograph and/or otherwise produce, reproduce, transmit, exhibit, distribute and exploit in connection with the said photoplay any and all of the coordinator's acts, poses, plays and appearances of any and all kinds hereunder, and shall further have the right to record, reproduce, transmit, exhibit, distribute and exploit in connection with said photoplay the coordinator's voice and all instrumental, musical and other sound effects produced by the coordinator in connection with such acts, poses, plays and appearances. The Producer shall likewise have the right to use and give publicity to the coordinator's name and likeness, photographic or otherwise, and to recordations and reproductions of the coordinator's voice and all instrumental, musical and other sound effects produced by the coordinator hereunder, in connection with the advertising and exploitation of said photoplay. The rights in this Section granted to the Producer shall inure to the benefit not only of the Producer, but also to the benefit of all persons who may hereafter acquire from the Producer any right to distribute, transmit, exhibit, advertise or exploit said photoplay.
25. GENERAL RIGHT OF TER
iSiiS
ATION
A.	The Producer may terminate the coordinator’s employment at any time, either prior to the commencement of production of said photoplay or during the course of production.
-599-
Schedule K - Part II
B.	If the Producer elects to terminate the coordinator’s employment under the freelance contract prior to the commencement of the term thereof, the Producer shall be obligated to pay the coordinator compensation during the minimum guaranteed period provided for in said freelance contract, but if the coordinator receives other employment during such period, the compensation received by the coordinator from such other employment shall be applied in reduction of the Producer's liability.
26.	ILLNESS OF COORDINATOR (SUSPENSION OF SALARY AND TERMINATION)_______________________________________________________
The Producer need pay no salary during any period that the coordinator is incapacitated, by illness or otherwise, from performing the required services under a freelance contract and, in the event of such illness or incapacity, the Producer, at its option, may terminate such employment without further liability.

27.	TRAVEL TIME
A.	Application of Rules
The provisions of this Section shall apply only to freelance coordinators included in this Schedule K.
B.	Studio Zone
(1)	With respect to studios situated in Los Angeles, California, or
its environs, the "studio zone" shall include all territory within the radius of thirty (30) miles from the intersection of Beverly Boulevard and La Cienega Boulevard, Los Angeles, California and such other territory (such as the present Columbia Ranch and Disney Studio) as is generally recognized as being within the studio zone. With respect to studios not situated in Los Angeles or its environs, a similar territory as the studio zone and similar rules in relation thereto shall be agreed upon between the Union and the Producers and, in default of such agreement, such territory and such rules (which shall conform as nearly as possible to the rules

To illustrate the foregoing, a coordinator, a resident of Los Angeles, irily in San Francisco. Within three (3) months from the close of his hgagement, he is recalled by the Producer as follows: On a Monday, directs the coordinator to report at the Los Angeles studio of 111:00 a.m. on the following Thursday for retakes. The coordinator vel by train. He departs from San Francisco on Wednesday night, Los Angeles Thursday morning, and reports at 11:00 a.m. The ismisses the coordinator at 2:00 p.m. on the same day. The coordinator to San Francisco by train. The coordinator shall be entitled to one iay at the same rate as was paid for his original engagement, plus the rtation by commercial airline.
^Transportation shall mean first-class transportation.

Schedule K - Part II
(1) This Agreement uses the expressions "reasonable ion" and "first-class transportation." The terms are intended to be
. The type of transportation required can best be illustrated by Bus transportation for a relatively short distance (Hollywood to Lake meets these requirements; bus transportation for a long distance to San Francisco) does not. Pullman accommodations to San isco, or any other long distance, meet these requirements; deluxe
tion (e.g., Super Chief) is not required. Transportation on a commercial without sleeper accommodations is first-class transportation. First-class station shall be provided on commercial airlines when the coordinator is red to fly at the request of the Producer. The foregoing shall apply to jet as well as to prop-driven aircraft. The foregoing shall not apply when first-ion is not available or six (6) or more of the company are being
Charter flights may be used which provide substantially equivalent ions. Notwithstanding the foregoing, first-class air transportation t be provided with respect to auditions and interviews.
ROTECTION OF STUNT PERFORMER: SAFETY
| All reasonable requests and requirements for safety equipment in n with the performance of stunts shall be complied with by Producer or t representatives on the set or location.
- Equipment provided by Producer, for example autos, cycles, wagons, pjbe in suitable repair for the safe and proper performance of the stunt.

-5. RIGHTS GRANTED TO PRODUCER
Wi

The term "photoplay,” as used in said freelance contract, shall bedee^ include motion pictures produced and/or exhibited with sound and voiced recording, reproducing and/or transmitting devices, radio devices and improvements and devices, including television, which are now or may hert$ be used in connection with the production and/or exhibition and/or transjroi any present or future kind of motion picture production. The ProducershaJ the right to photograph and/or otherwise produce, reproduce, transmit, exh^J distribute and exploit in connection with the said photoplay any and all oM coordinator’s acts, poses, plays and appearances of any and all kinds herein^ and shall further have the right to record, reproduce, transmit, exhibit,^ and exploit in connection with said photoplay the coordinator’s voice andr; instrumental, musical and other sound effects produced by the coordinator^ connection with such acts, poses, plays and appearances. The Producerstey likewise have the right to use and give publicity to the coordinator’s n likeness, photographic or otherwise, and to recordations and reproduction^ coordinator's voice and all instrumental, musical and other sound effectsggj by the coordinator hereunder, in connection with the advertising and exj of said photoplay. The rights in this Section granted to the Producer sh the benefit not only of the Producer, but also to the benefit of all persons^ hereafter acquire from the Producer any right to distribute, transmit, e advertise or exploit said photoplay.
(1) When more than one (1) night of travel (by ordinary means of tion) is required to reach a location and the coordinator is given a berth boat or train for each night of traveling, the time spent in such traveling, to or such location, shall not be work time or travel time for the purpose of tputing the eight (8) hour rest period.
(2) When an overnight trip to or from a location is required, and. me takes at least seven (7) hours to reach, and the coordinator is given a on a boat or train, or if the coordinator elects to travel by first-class plane rmodations, the time spent in such traveling to or from such location shall jejwork time or travel time for the pinpose of computing the eight (8) hour
(3) The first call at the lodging for work (including travel) nines the time of first call for the next day for the purpose of computing the seriod.
6.
BETTER CONDITIONS
Any better condition terms negotiated by a stunt coordinator musyj reflected in his/her deal memorandum or personal service contract and ir Schedule K employment contract.
jB. Whenever the stunt coordinator has been authorized in advance by Production Manager to report without having received the rest period i>ed above, the coordinator may waive the rest period without the Union’s tbut, if he does so, he shall be entitled to one (1) day of pay or $950, ryer is the lesser sum. A coordinator may be required to waive the rest if the violation, in case of the eight (8) hour rest period, is not over two and If (214) hours or, on an overnight location, not over two (2) hours. In any /which the coordinator waives the rest period, the payment of one (1) day of ptexceeding $950, shall be automatically incurred. The payment may not iyed without the consent of the Union.
It is understood that the foregoing provisions are not applicable when ^coordinator is also acting as a second unit director.

1-	SCOPE OF SCHEDULE AND RECOGNITION
(a)	The Union is recognized by the Producers, andeacfioftiS r vmS1VC bargaming agent all background actors described ihTui^ (c)(1) and (c)(2) below who are employed on theatrical and televisions pictures, other than television motion pictures made for basic cabl^ifS picture industry in the "background actor zones" as defined in subparaa hereof. The term "background actor" means all persons performing^ defined in the certification of representatives dated April 2,1946 m^tt^ RKO Pictures, Inc., Case No. 2I-R-3206, before the National LaborR® Board, including all classifications listed in Paragraph 3 hereof.
(b)	The term "motion pictures," as used herein and in all pmS Agreements between the parties, means and includes, and has alwayvrng included, motion pictures, whether made on or by film, tape or dthenral whether produced by means of motion picture cameras, electrons darfel devices, tape devices or any combination of the foregoing or any otherm methods or devices now used or which may hereafter be adopted. '7^'.

le; and
| (2) to the first forty-five (45) background actors (excluding 2 skaters and dancers, but including stand-ins) employed each day on ^motion pictures.
I Producer may hire background actors in excess of the foregoing ,on such productions, but such additional background actors (referred to |non-covered" or "waiver" background actors) shall not be covered by md conditions of this Agreement.
The applicable terms and conditions of this Agreement shall be elnd apply only within the "background actor zones" as defined m $aph (d) hereof.

(1)	"Background actors" shall be paid at the rate of $105.00 per ng the period July 1, 2001 through June 30,2002; $110.00 per day during «1 July 1,2002 through June 30,2003; and $115.00 per day during the lly 1,2003 through June 30, 2004, with an eight (8) hour minimum call.
(2)	Swimmers and skaters, professionally trained, doing routines requiring rehearsals, shall be paid $269.00 for an eight (8) call.
Swimmers and skaters will have at least ten (10) minutes of rest h hour of actual rehearsing or shooting unless shooting is of a ^nature. If so, at the choreographer’s or director’s discretion, swimmers miay continue until a total of ninety (90) minutes has elapsed, after (15) minute break must be called.

uy (2) Dancing and skating Special Ability Background Actors doing rows, catches and falls shall be graded upward in accordance with the work m? This provision does not apply to background actors employed at the gSkaters and Swimmers.
(3)	Special ability background actors who are swimming, dancing will have at least ten (10) minutes of rest during each hour of actual |ng or shooting unless shooting is of a continuous nature. If so, at the grapheris or director’s discretion, swimmers, dancers or skaters may leuntil a total of ninety (90) minutes has elapsed, after which a fifteen (15) break must be called.

BIYERS
If a Producer requests a waiver affecting background actors, the pit believes that the Producer is entitled thereto, will issue the waiver, imposition of any conditions, which waiver, in the absence of gment or concealment of the facts, will be final. If the Union believes that Ewer is not entitled to such final waiver, it shall issue a reviewable waiver ^equivalent to a refusal of a waiver), or it may issue a conditional waiver Egtiwill designate the conditions upon which it is willing to have the Eproceed. Producer may either accept such conditions or refuse to accept Rif a conditional waiver be issued and the Producer rejects the conditions Euf the Union issues a reviewable waiver as aforesaid, the Producer may Kess proceed as though a final waiver had been issued. If the Producer Eetd without first obtaining a final waiver or without complying with the waiver, it shall notify the Union in writing to that effect within a Retime thereafter, and the Union, within twenty (20) days after receipt of ■jten notice, shall have the right to invoke the grievance procedure as mn Section 56 herein, which determination shall be made as to whether a Eer should have been given or whether the Union was justified in refusing Kirin imposing conditions. If the arbitrator finds in favor of the Union, Ealfdetermine the remedy to which the Union is entitled and make an

Schedule X - Part I
award accordingly. The Producer, if it so desires, may refer to the said gnq procedure of Section 56 at any time (including prior to photographing) ^}^ question with regard to the Union's refusal to issue a waiver or with referen^ any conditions imposed or sought to be imposed by the Union in connectjoj the issuance of any waiver and the decision reached in such grievance proci with respect to such matters shall be final. All waivers shall be requested^ as reasonably possible before desired and shall be acted upon promptly^bsj Union. If the Union shall fail to do so, the Producer may proceed in aUig| as though the Union had issued a reviewable waiver, so notifying theiUnjfl| writing and with the same effect as in the case of a reviewable waiver5tln3 application for a waiver by any Producer shall not be deemed an admission the Producer cannot proceed without obtaining such waiver, nor shall^thm by the Union in any instance of a waiver be an admission that the Produ^ entitled to such a waiver.

DANCERS* WORKING CONDITIONS
(a) Rest Periods Between Work Days
Producer shall provide a minimum ten (10) hour rest period for and, when practicable in scheduling, Producer shall use its best efforts to a twelve (12) hour rest period.
j) Standards - Cooperative Committee
Industry standards for dancers include adequate warm-up area, es free and clean of debris and materials, adequate rest periods and such precautions as may be necessary to ensure the health and safety of the ts in light of the nature of the work performed. The Cooperative Committee et and shall continue to meet for the purpose of developing specific irds in accordance with the foregoing industry standards. The Producer shall by the standards listed below and any further standards agreed upon by the rative Committee upon notice to Producer. The Cooperative Committee has to the following specific conditions:
i( (1) Floors for Rehearsal Halls and Stages
Except when conditions are otherwise required for a scene; (a) “s should be clean and free of splinters, wax, nails; and (b) floors should be and mopped at least daily with a germ-killing solution.
-639-
Schedule X - Part I
.	(2) Warm-Up Spaces
Adequate space must be provided to permit alldancei up (perform limbering exercises) thirty (30) minutes (non-work timej'pri dancing.	1
(3)	Breaks
Dancers will have at least ten (10) minutes rest during hour of actual rehearsal or shooting unless shooting is of a continuoiis na so, at the choreographer's discretion, dancers may continue until aTotafcS (90) minutes has elapsed, after which a fifteen (15) minute break must.he
(4)	Emergency Treatment
A person or facility located in the general geography! and qualified under the circumstances to provide medical care basis shall be identified and such information shall be made available:^ all rehearsals and performances.
(5)	Safety of Equipment	■
-
Producer shall exercise care, including prior testin g^ equipment (breakaway props, etc.), to avoid injury to the performenSSH

A
(a)	The Producer's representative will notify background acto^of.; nudity or sex acts expected in the role (if known by management at the thru time of the call.	•'
(b)	During any production involving nudity or sex scenes, theset i closed to all persons having no business purpose in connection with the*/ production.	'	' 1 / ‘
(c)	No still photography of nudity or sex acts will be authorized b Producer to be made without die consent of the background actor,
(d)	The appearance of a background actor in a nude or sex scene s conditioned upon the background actor providing prior written consenL’.Si consent may be obtained by letter or other writing prior to a commitment a written contract being made or executed. If a background actor has agreed appear in such scenes and then withdraws his consent, Producer shall have, right to double or replace, but consent may not be withdrawn as to film alre photographed. Producer shall also have the right to double or replace child tender years (infants) in nude scenes (not in sex scenes),
(e)	If not notified of nudity in advance, the background actor retai
right to refuse and is entitled to a full day of pay without prejudice, Produc retains the right to require the background actor to do other background^ work, in lieu thereof, if such other background actor work exists.

(f) Police Motorcycle
In the event that a background actor is required to report with hi^ automobile at a place outside the Studio Zone, his work day shall commence ; end at the time he would have normally been required to report and be dismb at the Producer’s studio or any other studio if he were to be transported to from the place of such reporting. The Producer agrees to pay thirty cents (30£ mile for all miles traveled by the background actor upon the Producer’s instai In the event that a background actor is required to report with his automobile outside fee Studio Zone, the mileage shall be computed from the Producer’s to the reporting site and return and shall be added to the total mileage traveled^ the background actor at the Producer's instruction during the day. Reimbursexn shall be included in the background actor's pay check.

A background actor who is directed to and who does report with'h trailer shall be paid a trailer allowance of $ 19.00 per day.

An automobile, motorcycle or moped is to be driven only by the kground actor supplying same and cannot be used for stunt work unless this is ~ d to by such background actor at the time of booking. 22. WORKWEEK. PAYROLL WEEK. REGULAR PAY DA
(a)	(i) The regular studio workweek shall consist of any-
consecutive days out of any seven (7) consecutive days, commencin; of such five (5) days. However, the five (5) consecutive day rei deemed satisfied when, on commencing employment, the backgrbui assigned to a schedule that calls for him to work, for example, on;M< Tuesday, with Wednesday and Thursday as the regular days off, an^ by work on Friday through the following Tuesday.
(ii)	The regular overnight location workweek shaU^j six (6) consecutive days out of any seven (7) consecutive days,tcamj the first of such six (6) days. However, the six (6) consecutiveday^ shall be deemed satisfied when, on commencing employment,;' actor is assigned to a schedule that calls for him to work, for exan and Tuesday, with Wednesday as the regular day off, and is Thursday through the following Tuesday.
-650-
-651-
Scheduie X - Part I
Schedule X-Parti
(iii)	One time during the production of a motion picture, or in the ;f episodic television, once between hiatus periods (i.e., between the icement or resumption of production and a cessation of principal
y for the series for at least one week), the Producer may shift the eek for background actors, without incurring added costs, by adding one (1) (2) days off consecutive with the sixth and/or seventh days off in the prior eek and/or by shifting a workweek commencing on Tuesday to a workweek incmg on Monday, provided that the intervening Sunday is a day off.
If the Producer otherwise shifts the workweek such that the [Orkweek invades the preceding workweek, the Producer shall pay the for the sixth and/or seventh day worked of the preceding workweek.
The background actor shall be advised of any shift in the prior to commencement of that workweek.
Ji) The payroll week shall be from midnight Saturday to midnight
),? The regular pay day shall be Thursday, except that Friday shall be the ay day on overnight locations. Each background actor shall receive t^on Thursday (Friday on overnight locations) for services performed in the payroll week.
VERTIME
kground actors employed in excess of eight (8) hours in any one (1) day, ne the background actor is required to and does report until dismissed, id daily overtime compensation as follows:

(6)	OR SEVEN (7) CONSECUTIVE DAYS IN A WORKWEEK; ^HOLIDAYS___________________________________

a) Sixth Consecutive Day:
(1)	All work performed on the sixth consecutive day worked for a ilar Producer, except on overnight locations, shall be paid at the rate of etime.
(2)	The sixth consecutive day worked for a particular Producer on hi location shall be paid for at straight time.
(3)	For a sixth consecutive day for a particular Producer not leu overnight location, when the background actor is required to remain lodged overnight at Producer’s expense, the background actor shall be paid nee of one (I) day of pay at straight time.


All work performed on a seventh consecutive day for a particular jshall be paid at the rate of double time. Background actors on overnight be paid an allowance of one (1) day of pay at straight time for a tive day for a particular Producer.

(c) Holidays:
(1)	New Year's Day, Presidents' Day, Good Friday, Memory Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, the day after Thanksgi Christmas Day shall be recognized as holidays. If any of the above holid on a Saturday, the preceding Friday shall be considered the holiday ahdjif holiday falls on a Sunday, the following Monday shall be considered except that on overnight location, Saturday holidays will be recognizedj Saturday.
(2)	Provisions for Holidays Not Worked:
Studio employment - Allowance of one (1) day dfpa straight time if the background actor is employed by Producer the day: the day after any of the above-named nine (9) holidays, except whefran; holiday occurs on a Saturday.
Overnight location employment - Allowance of one pay at straight time.
(3)	Provisions for Holidays Worked:
Double daily wage.
(d) Overtime premium payments under Sections 23 and 25 compounded or pyramided and shall be paid at the highest applicable rate only.

30. MEAL PERIODS
(a)	Meal periods shall be not less than one-half (14) houfhpfrijc one (I) hour. Not more than one (I) meal period shall be deducted time during the first eight (8) hours. When the meal period of any, crew is shorter than that for background actors, such crew members, sh; entitled to eat before the background actors.
(b)	The first meal period shall be called not later than six;(6 the time of call. All subsequent meal periods, commencing withthp.sec period, shall be called not later than six (6) hours after the termination^ preceding meal period. There will be a twelve (12) minute grace perr not to be a scheduled grace period, prior to imposition of any mear provided that the six (6) hour period between meals has not beenext permitted by the following sentence. If, upon the expiration of such si period, the camera is in the actual course of photographing a "tj&e/tjf a violation of the meal period to complete such take.	^1**

(d)	Whenever Producer supplies meals or other food or beverages to the Crew, the same shall be furnished to all background actors. Regarding this provision is applicable only in those situations in which the ct supplies beverages to the cast and crew and is not applicable when groups may supply their own beverages (e.g., prop truck with a cooler for s). When meals are served to background actors, tables and seats shall be available for them. No time shall be deducted from work time for any meal igd by the Producer until the background actors are given the opportunity to Ime for the actual feeding of background actors. "Meal" means an adequate, ahnced serving of a variety of wholesome, nutritious foods. The furnishing
3, such as hot dogs or hamburgers, to background actors by the Producer t constitute a meal period. Meals supplied by the Producer shall not be I from the background actors' wages.

40.	OVERNIGHT LOCATION TRAVEL

Travel time is the time consumed in transporting background&tbt from the studio or place of reporting and the overnight location, and! shooting site on the overnight location to the housing base.
Travel time begins when the background actor is directed to and report for travel, and ends when the background actor arrives at
Travel time shall in no event exceed eight (8) hours in any pen twenty-four (24) hours, computed from midnight to midnight.

42.	NOTICE OELQCATONS
The Producer or its hiring agency will notify the Union of all locations which the background actors have been assigned, at least twenty-four (24) hours-^ before shooting commences.
The Producer or its hiring agency shall, at foe time a call is given to a background actor, notify such background actor if such call is for work on location and shall also specify, insofar as it is then known, the whereabouts of such location as well as whether filming will be indoors or outdoors and if out-of- .■ season wardrobe is involved.	--’O
When background actors are on an overnight location and are to leave suejy overnight location at a time that would not normally permit them to arrive at theda Producer's studio or other place of dismissal prior to 6:30 p.m. of the day of suc^ arrival and, further, the background actors concerned do not have a call for worO on the next work day following the day of such arrival, then the Producer sha]]^ i make arrangements so that the hiring agency of the Producer will be notified as/J early as possible, but in no event later than 6:30 p,m. of the day of such that such background actors will be available for work on the next work day following foe day of arrival. The Producer will also request its hiring agency notify any other designated agencies engaged in the hiring of background actors.^

The exclusive remedy for violations |of the preference of employment provision shall be the Cooperative Committee.
|	(b) In foe San Francisco Background Actor Zone, to background actors

(a)	No background actor shall be employed on account of persona!
favoritism.
(b) Rotation of work shall be established to such reasonable; degns may be possible and practicable.	■
(c) No person having authority from the Producer to hire, eiriplo; direct the services of background actors shall demand or accept any-fee^ significant services (more than normal courtesy) from a background actor currently rendering services, or other remuneration in consideration'ofhir employing any person to perform work or services as a background actbt^ permitting such person to continue in said employment.
(d) Only the Producer or its hiring agency shall perform any; connection with the hiring or employment of background actors, whel remuneration or otherwise.
(e) Persons employed as members of the casting or producing® Producer will neither be engaged nor utilized as background actors irrarr on which they also render services.	’
1 (a)	(1)	The parties hereto reaffirm their commitment to a policy of
^-discrimination and fair employment in connection with the engagement and atment of background actors on the basis of sex, race, color, creed, national [gm, age, marital status, disability or sexual orientation, in accordance with plicable state and federal law; and (2) to continue the active promotion of ycrsity, as set forth herein, of background actors covered by this Schedule.
|| (b) Producer shall make every effort to cast background actors in cordance with the policy set forth in subparagraph (a) above in all types of roles, ring due regard for the requirement of, and suitability for, the role so that, for mile, the American scene may be portrayed realistically.
H.(c)	Consistent with the foregoing, every effort shall be made to include
mrities. women, performers with disabilities (defined as those covered under Employment provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act) and performers SBo and over who are protected under the Age Discrimination in Employment Kn the casting of each motion picture, thereby creating fair and equal mloyment opportunities and eliminating stereotyping in casting.
K(d) When applicable, and with due regard to safety of the individuals, Eand crew, women and minorities shall be considered for hazardous work and Bgnpted stunts on a non-discriminatory basis.
K(e) In accordance with the foregoing policy, the Union reaffirms its Ev.of non-discrimination with respect to admission to membership and rights Embership.

(i)	Industry-Union Cooperative Committee on Mediation
<
An Industry-Union Cooperative Committee shall be establishedfo the purpose of providing a forum for the discussion and resolution of dispute?-
relating to the provisions of this Section 45.

Either Producer or Union may submit a request, which shall teiti writing, that a dispute under Section 45 be brought before the Industry-Union? Cooperative Committee. The Cooperative Committee shall convene within* six (60) days after receipt by the non-moving party of such written notice, excepftl the parties may, by mutual agreement, extend such sixty (60) day period. If the meeting is not held due to the failure of the non-moving party to attend such-?' meeting, the moving party may refer the matter to a non-binding mediation witl independent mediator.
Producer and Union agree to seek funding for the mediation prog
. Y
from the IACF.
(j)	The matters covered in this Section are not subject to the provision of Section 56 herein.

Schedule X - Part I
I (a) Water Supply
| Every set or location shall be supplied with pure drinking water, ommon drinking cups are prohibited.
| (b) Seats and Cots
j. Every Producer shall provide an adequate number of suitable seats on its or locations for all background actors. On every set or location, a cot of a pe suitable for use as a stretcher, or a stretcher, shall be provided.
| (c) Dressing Rooms
| When a background actor is directed by the Producer to change .othes, either at foe studio or on location, foe background actor may refuse to Sage his or her clothes unless a place of reasonable comfort and privacy is rovided. A bus is not acceptable as a place to change wardrobe unless equipped ith appropriate changing areas. The parties reserve their respective positions as > the propriety of using a bathroom as a place to change wardrobe. Unless ressing rooms are provided adjacent to set or location on which background ctors are required to work, Producer shall be responsible for damage to ackground actors' personal wardrobe or property. Separate dressing rooms shall e provided at studios or locations for each sex. Dressing rooms shall be Sequately lighted. Any complaints of alleged breach of these provisions shall, at leoption of either party, be presented to foe Industry-Union Cooperative ibmmittee provided by Section 17 of foe General Provisions of this Agreement jr the purpose of mediating or adjusting such complaints, or the grievance rocedure set forth in Section 56 of this Schedule.
K (d) Locker Rooms
Adequate provisions shall be made for foe proper safekeeping of foe lathing of background actors during working hours. An adequate number of lothes racks shall be provided on sets or locations when background actors are inployed. If a locker is not provided on sets or on locations during time of
I	- 675 -
Schedule X - Part I
employment of background actors, a responsible party shall be put in charge of ’3 any clothing or property belonging to background actors.	ZC 5
(e) Toilet and Washing Facilities on Locations
Adequate toilet facilities shall be provided for all background actors,L-1 and toilets shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. The seats of these % toilets shall be screened between each one and in front. Toilet paper must be j provided. Sanitary napkins shall be obtainable. Washing facilities must be provided and either paper or individual towels supplied. Common towels will ncrt J be permitted. Soap must be provided. Appropriate time and facilities for clean up.! shall be afforded all background actors before departing from a distant location?^ | j (f) Reasonable protection shall be afforded background actors on all sets 1 and locations against severe climate conditions such as heat, cold, rain and snowPL^ Reasonable protection shall also be afforded background actors who are required 71 to wear out-of-season wardrobe.	,3
(g)	Vrelation of any of the provisions of this Section 46 shall entitle ally ? ^
background actors employed on the set or location involved to receive such amount of additional compensation as may be assessed by decision of the |
Industry-Union Cooperative Committee.

PAYMENT REQUIREMENTS

(a)	In the event that Producer fails to postmark a background actor’s 3 paycheck on the regular pay day, as provided in Section 22, there shall be a $3.00' j per day late payment charge paid to such background actor, commencing to accrue | on the day following the day of default for a period not to exceed twenty-five (25) J days, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, to a maximum of $75 per violation. Such late payment charge shall be in addition to any and all other -.SgS
-676-
Schcdule X - Part I
kmedies which the Union may have against Producer or its designated casting pgency under this Schedule.
I	The late payment charge provided herein shall not apply if the
background actor has failed to execute his W-4 form, 1-9 form or other [governmentally-required forms.
I	If there is a dispute over the amount due the background actor, and
me Producer or its designated casting agency pays the undisputed amount on time, | if there is a bona fide dispute as to the Producer's liability therefor, there will be late payment charge during the pendency of the dispute.
(b)	In order to enable the Union to determine if a violation of the pay-off requirements of this Schedule has occurred and to file its timely grievance with respect to same, if necessary, Producer or its designated casting agency agrees to pivise the Union, within five (5) days after a request is made, as to the name of [Sch background actor employed, the date(s) each background actor was employed land the date(s) each such background actor was paid on any particular picture or

(a)	The Producer agrees to notify the Union in the event a background actor is hospitalized as the result of an accident during the course of his employment.
(b)	A person qualified under the circumstances to administer medical . ^7 assistance on an emergency basis shall be present or readily available at all rehearsals and all performances during which hazardous action or work under. hazardous conditions is planned. Such person will have visible identification.':^ The Producer will provide readily accessible first aid equipment necessary to wt administer such medical assistance. In such circumstances, transportation to tin nearest medical facility providing emergency services shall be readily available;^ When such action or work is planned on location, the production company shall^ determine the nearest emergency medical facilities and capabilities thereof and communication therewith and assure that transportation to such facilities is readily available at all times during the performance of such work. The transportation vehicle referred to above shall be capable of accommodating a stretcher and first-aid equipment. The parties agree to recommend that the industry-wide Labor-Management Safety Committee develop appropriate guidelines as to firsts aid equipment and visible identification for the aforementioned person qualified administer medical assistance on an emergency basis.
(c)	The Producer shall obtain copies of all safety guidelines issued byfiie   industry-wide Labor-Management Safety Committee. Copies of such guidelines^ shall be available at the offices of the AMPTP and the Union. The AMPTP and - ' the Union agree to cooperate in disseminating such guidelines to Producers as are formulated during tire term of this Agreement.
(d)	If a background actor is rigged with any type of explosive charge ) £4? (including squibs), such background actor shall be permitted prior consultation^ with the stunt coordinator and the qualified special effects person. In addition;'
such background actor shall be upgraded to the day performer rate and added to the cast list for residual purposes for the day on which the background actor was so upgraded. If the background actor is called back the next day, he returns as a background actor.

All compensation paid to background actors employed by the Producer "through any agency shall be net to the background actor, except for such deductions or withholdings as may from time to time be provided by law or by this ’Agreement; it being agreed that the Producer, and not the background actor, shall bear the agency fee for obtaining employment, and that the background actor shall lot be required by the Producer to pay such agency fee directly or indirectly.
Producer agrees that reasonable access to the records of Central Casting ^Corporation, or any other agency used by the Producer for the employment of -^background actors, shall be afforded to die Union. The agency referred to in the preceding sentence means only an agency used regularly or customarily by one or
Producers, performing for such Producer substantially the same function as Central Casting Corporation, and does not mean agencies used casually but not Jy. Records does not mean financial records of the Agency.
The Producer or its hiring agency will furnish the Guild a list of all ackground actors engaged to render services, showing the date, the time and the reduction to which they are assigned.
No person who is not a "registered background actor" shall be requested by studio casting office from any casting agency, and each "registered background shall be provided with a card of identification; suitable regulations for arrying out this provision shall be adopted.

55. STATUTE OF UMHATIQNS
(a)	Any individual dispute or claim between a background actor and d Producer shall be deemed to be waived by such background actor and by; the Union in the event that a timely grievance is not filed either by such background actor or by the Union. In order to be timely, a grievance or dispute (other, tha^ relating to damage to or loss of the background actor's wardrobe or property).-® be presented to the employer in writing or orally, within thirty (30) daysaftc^ffi involved employee had knowledge, or reasonably should have had knowled^ the occurrence of the facts giving rise to the grievance or dispute. Claims f(^g| damage to or loss of the background actor's wardrobe or property must beW before the background actor leaves the set on the day on which the damageaS occurred. (The Producer shall furnish a claim form for the background.1 actc^a complete, which shall be countersigned by the Producer and a copy thereof^B furnished to the background actor prior to his departure for the day.) :s
■ 'W-®
(b)	In all other claims (other than an background actor's dispute), claims shall be deemed to be waived in the event that Step One proceeding^a not filed by the Union on or before ninety (90) days from the date thatthc^0L^ first has knowledge of such claim.
(c)	Any claim by the Producer shall be deemed to be waivedind^S that Step One proceedings are not filed by the Producer on or before ninet^M days from the date that the Producer first has knowledge of such clai^^^H

GRIEVA^F fbqcebube
In the event of any dispute between the Union or any background actor sloyed under this Schedule and the Producer with regard to the proper lication or interpretation of any of the provisions of this Schedule, the shall be as follows:
Stepl
An authorized representative of the Union and an authorized representative le Producer shall immediately discuss the matter and attempt in good faith to :t a settlement of the dispute.
It is the policy of the Union and the Producers not to permit undue delays in 'presentation and processing of claims.
p Step 2
| If the parties shall fail to settle the dispute in Step 1 within twenty (20) days ;the matter has been brought to the attention of the other party in Step 1, the ieved party may refer the dispute to Step 2 by delivery to the other party of a Jen statement of the dispute stating the facts giving rise to the dispute. In the it the necessary film or tape or other necessary evidence is not available for nination in Step 1, then the twenty (20) day period may be extended to a
d not to exceed ninety (90) days or, in the case of a feature film, to a longer d of time as may be agreed upon by the parties.
j:The dispute shall be submitted to a Grievance Committee which shall ist of two (2) representatives selected by the Union and two (2) isentatives selected by the AMPTP. A hearing before such Grievance nrittee shall, unless otherwise agreed by the parties, be held within ten (10) following the written request to proceed to Step 2. The decision of the nee Committee shall be determined by a simple majority of the Grievance ittee and shall be final and binding on the Producer involved in the dispute, ion and any involved background actor.

|; If any portion of this contract shall be held illegal, such portion shall be effective, but if such portion is a major provision of this contract, either party ay thereupon terminate the provisions of this Schedule X, Part I on ninety (90) iys written notice to the other party.
B In the event that any provision of this Schedule relating to the amounts and ament of wages or other financial benefits is affected by any legislation, vision of a court of competent jurisdiction, or governmental regulation in such jfinner so that such wages or other financial benefits would be increased over, or greased under, the amount intended to be paid by the parties hereto at the time me execution of this Agreement, then each of the parties hereto agrees that tan written notice from the other party setting forth the provisions to be potiated, they will renegotiate for modification of such provisions so that such ^visions will conform to such legislation, decision of a court of competent ^diction or governmental regulation, as the case may be, and will provide, as |rfy as possible, for payment of wages or other financial benefits, in the amount Siiided to be paid by the parties hereto at the time of the execution hereof. If the arSes are unable to arrive at an agreement within thirty (30) days after delivery of iHnotice, then such provisions in question shall be immediately submitted to an Eviration Committee composed of one (1) member designated by the Producer, mJ) member by the Union and an Impartial Chairman, to be selected by such ger two (2) members within ten (10) days following such thirty (30) day period awded above. This Arbitration Committee shall promptly proceed to hear and she such matter. The authority of this Arbitration Committee to decide shall be med solely to determining the appropriate modifications of such provisions so Ipuch provisions will conform to such legislation, decision of a court of Epetent jurisdiction, or governmental regulation, as the case may be, and will Svide, as nearly as possible, for the payment of wages and other financial Ketils in the amount intended to be paid by the parties at the time of execution of ^Agreement. The terms and conditions of such appropriate modifications, if
It	*683 * '
O	Schedule X - Part I

any, by the said Arbitration Committee, shall be effective and operative as ofthe date on which the provisions, so modified accordingly, were so affected by any$ such legislation, decision of a court of competent jurisdiction or governments^ regulation, as the case maybe, in such manner and to the extent as above- , described and provided; the amounts and payments of wages, or other financial benefits contained in such appropriate modifications, if any, made by such j Arbitration Committee, shall be computed and paid thereunder retroactive to the effective date of such modifications. In the event that no such modifications ca be made, as above provided, because of any legislation, decision of a court of^ competent jurisdiction or governmental regulation, Producer shall not be liable, any retroactive back-pay adjustments, or any other penalty, if any such modification is thereafter permissible. The decision of the said Arbitration Committee shall be final, and shall not be subject to the grievance procedure in Section 56 above, but its authority to decide shall be limited to the issue andjf remedy herein provided. The above procedure and conditions shall be the^, exclusive remedy for determining any dispute arising under this Section 57;#
Upon written notice by such Arbitration Committee to the respective^! hereto, the modification of such provisions as determined by said Committee, above provided, shall automatically become a part of this Agreement. 58.	CONSTRUCTION AND NOTICES
The provisions of Sections 38, 39, 41 and 42 of the General Provisioi this Agreement shall apply to the employment of background actors under-th Schedule. Should the Union enter into an agreement with ABC, CBS or N relating to the employment of background actors within the background ac zones described in Section 1(d) of this Schedule on terms other than as pic herein, it shall so advise the AMPTP, in writing, of the terms of such agree relating to such background actors within ten (10) days after ratification. / AMPTP shall have the right to elect such terms in lieu of those provided hi giving written notice to the Union within thirty (30) days after receipt of ft Union's notice.

PAY TELEVISION
(a) A "Post '60s picture" is any motion picture initially released for rical exhibition, the principal photography of which commenced after January 960.
The exhibition of any motion picture by television for which a charge id by or assessed to or collected from the viewing audience, including scription, telemeter or any other method whereby a charge is paid by the ;ving audience for the right to view such motion picture, is herein referred to as
^television.1
s A "free television" picture is a motion picture initially released on vision, other than pay television.

(b) As to all motion pictures, it is recognized and acknowledged that Producer has the unrestricted right to use, exhibit and market the same for any purpose, in any manner and by any method now known or hereafter developed, and that the Producer does not hereby relinquish or surrender any of its property^ rights therein. The exhibition of a motion picture by pay television is theatrical^ exhibition, and is merely an extension or substitute for the theatrical box office.^. 1
63. STANDARD OPENINGS AND CLOSINGS
In addition to the minimum rates and conditions otherwise provided by this1 y Schedule, up to a maximum of fifteen (15) background actors who are specifically^ selected for and are employed in any particular standard opening and closing shall receive additional compensation in the amount of the applicable background ac
rate then currently in effect under this Schedule.
64.
DOCUMENTARY FILMS
On each motion picture, a single background actor may be designated by the background actors on the set to place calls on behalf of such other ound actors to casting agencies in an endeavor to secure employment for background actors on the following day. It is understood that the Producer resumes no responsibility for any errors or omissions on the part of such designated background actor.
